TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Public Service Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned federal Public Servants respectfully submit that:

The introduction of a Public Service Act regulation removing appeals against higher duties of 12 months or less has the potential to undermine the principle of selection on merit and the principle of an apolitical public service and lead to staffing decisions based on patronage and favouritism.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate should:
Disallow the Public Service Act regulation removing the aforesaid appeal right.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Childs (from 81 citizens), Senator Cooney (from 18 citizens), Senator Sandy Macdonald (from 45 citizens) and Senator West (from 33 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PETITION.TITLE: Marks Royal Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community concern about the Federal Labor Government's decision to pay Dr Carmen Lawrence's legal expenses in her legal challenges to stop the Marks Royal Commission.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate:
(a)note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition; and
(b)call on the Government:

TAB.TAB: (i)to publish full details of the basis of the decision by Cabinet, including copies of official advice; and
(ii)to immediately reverse the decision and cease public funding of attempts to stop Commissioner Marks finding the truth about the Penny Easton petition.

TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is not the government's intention to refuse formality in relation to general business notices of motion No. 1860 on the basis that the tyranny of numbers once again indicates that, if we do that, there will be a very long and prolonged debate on this matter.
—You mean the democratic process rather than the tyranny of numbers.

—I was quoting Senator Baume's eloquence. I thought I would use the same words as the ones he used when he was about to lose a matter before the chamber. There is support by a clear majority of senators for this. For those reasons, I will make a couple of points. We will not be refusing formality. I want to place very clearly on the public record the government's position in relation to this matter. We know that we do not have the numbers to defeat this motion. We do not want to waste the Senate's time by debating it.

PARA.TAB: The government has no difficulty in informing the parliament of the outcome of the review process. In so far as the notice of motion assumes that there will be one report, it may be making the wrong assumption. The government's intention in conducting the review is to identify discrete areas of decision making and to remedy any problems. This process may not necessarily lead to the preparation of a report. Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Amendment Bill 1995
Social Security Legislation Amendment (Carer Pension and Other Measures) Bill 1995

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on record that this motion does not say that the Senate believes these bills should be treated as urgent, but that is the point of the motion, that these bills should be considered urgent and, therefore, need to be considered in this session—in the last three weeks of sitting before Christmas.

PARA.TAB: There are 15 bills listed in the motion. The Australian Democrats believe that two of these bills are, in fact, urgent and the rest of them have start-up dates way beyond what would make them urgent for the next three weeks of sitting. We do not believe that we will even get up to a lot of these bills on the program, because there are so many bills on the program. We believe it is just totally useless to put most of these bills through as urgent; they are not urgent bills. It is really very silly to add most of these to a program that is already so long that we will not get through what we have on it now. We will be voting against this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking briefly because my colleague also will speak to the particular lists mentioned in this motion. As a general principle, the Greens (WA) have expressed the view that at this late stage, with 16 days of the program left to go, to suddenly introduce more and more bills to be exempt from the cut-off means that there is no real prioritising and addressing of the problem but simply the creation of further problems by an ad hoc way of relating to bills.

PARA.TAB: So the proposal has been put that a meeting be held of all the groups involved in this chamber to set a consensus program which prioritises bills and actually puts a timetable in place for the remaining 16 days which is achievable, rather than add on to a list which makes addressing any of those bills of extreme urgency less and less achievable.

We do not support a motion that continues to add to the list of business which we have not had prior notification of, on the basis that we need to address the problem of the legislation that is pouring into the program. We need to look at a true way of determining a better priority.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition has tried to be particularly reasonable on these things. It was only a few days ago that we allowed, I think, a dozen or so bills through the cut-off. I might remind the Senate that the cut-off is to enable orderly planning and for the Senate to have reasonable time to consider the detail of legislation in order to do its job properly. The effect of the cut-off is that the government, basically, undertook to introduce bills in the session before that in which they wished to have the bills debated in the Senate. It was a very sensible and reasonable reform.

PARA.TAB: However, on today's order of business some 36 pieces of legislation are listed. The minister has come in here today and, in effect, asked us to agree to a further 14 pieces of legislation to be added to that list for debate in the next little over two weeks. It has become apparent that it will be impossible for the Senate to properly review those pieces of legislation. It has become a farce.

Any contemplation that the Senate will be able to carry out a proper legislative review function of some 50-odd pieces of complicated legislation in just over two weeks is ridiculous. This has been a longstanding complaint of ours. This government just does not seem to have been able to prepare a program for the orderly transmission of legislation through the parliament.

I know that the government is in something of a shambles at the moment. It seems to have abdicated the responsibility of governance in favour of a 12-month election campaign. Ministers are preoccupied with fighting the campaign out in the electorates, even to the extent of highly misleading television advertisements being launched in Western Australia on industrial relations. This is all part of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Watch out or I'll take a relevance point of order.

—It is very relevant to this. Instead of concentrating on what is necessary to properly govern this country, which includes the administration of a legislative program, the government has been distracted onto the campaign. This campaign is going to take approximately one-third of the whole cycle between elections: two years of government, one year of campaign. It is ridiculous. The legislative program, the process of government and the process of parliament suffer as a result of it.

PARA.TAB: Our position remains that, if a matter is critical and does need to be debated, we will allow it to be debated notwithstanding the protection. But there has not been much effort from the government to demonstrate that each and every one of these bills has to be debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that's wrong.

—Do you want to list these 14 bills before the 36 that are currently on the Notice Paper? When are we going to receive from you a program that will set out what you are seeking to achieve between now and the end of this session so that we can see what time you, as the minister responsible for the program, are applying to each of these bills and we can determine whether what you are putting to the parliament is reasonable or not? When are we going to receive that?

PARA.TAB: We have got estimates committees coming up, which are going to take the best part of half a week. That gives us just over two sitting weeks of this chamber before the Christmas break. I remind you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that we are now sitting three sessions a year in order that the government could better manage its program. It seems to have totally failed to achieve that objective. It seems to be beyond the wit of this government and, I am sorry to say, the wit of this particular minister. That is very disappointing from the point of view of good government.

Some of these bills actually, we think, ought to be debated this session and some of those that are on the Notice Paper at the moment ought to be the ones that are deferred to the next parliament. The sensible way to discuss that is not in this chamber but out of the chamber, when the government comes to us with what it believes are the critical bills. Even the minister will concede that, in this particular session, the coalition has been very cooperative in allowing the legislative program to flow; yet we are still heading towards this enormous legislative backlog. It is simply unsatisfactory management.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are going to make these points, be honest about the discussions that have been had that aren't on the public record.
—Like what?
—Like, for example, when you agreed with me that it would be appropriate late this week to have a discussion about the legislative timetable, something that you agreed to on Monday of this week.
—I said we should sit down and discuss the legislative program, if you remember correctly.
—Why don't you be honest about when you suggested it would be useful?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—This is a very interesting conversation. I would appreciate if it actually came through the chair and was fully in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring us into it.

—You should be in it. Every individual senator has got the right to be able to see that the program is manageable, otherwise the Senate cannot do its job properly and it reflects upon all of us. Unfortunately, it is the government that has responsibility for the management of the program, and that is where the failure is occurring. What is the urgency of the Australian Federal Police Amendment Bill?
—You sit down and I will tell you.
—If I sit down, will you tell us the urgency of each of these?
—I am more than happy to it, although it's unnecessary.
—Okay.
—Madam Acting Deputy President—
—You will require leave.
—No, I just wanted to close the debate.
—I think there are other people who might want to speak.

—I do not want to take the time of the Senate at this present point in time, but I might say that, frankly, it is a very difficult position that the Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) finds himself in. I would not like to be in his position. It is not of his doing that we are faced with this particular motion for the exemption of certain bills from the cut-off motion.

PARA.TAB: Of course, I was very much involved in discussions on the resolution relating to the cut-off motion. The reason for that is that, whilst the opposition might justifiably complain about the lack of opportunity they have had for examining bills and preparing their positions on the bills and discussing them, at least they have people who are able to deal with specific areas, and it makes it much easier for them; whereas it is more difficult for those of us who have to look at each and every piece of legislation that comes before this chamber and decide what we are able to assess as the merits of the proposals. So that is one of the reasons that I feel the government should make out a very strong case as to why certain pieces of legislation should be exempted.

Minister, my view would be the same as that expressed by Senator Chamarette and, I think, Senator Hill. From what I heard of your conversation across the table, I thought that you were indicating that it might be a good idea to sit down and have a talk about the program. In light of all of that, I would be prepared—unless you would like to do it, Minister—to adjourn this motion to the next day of sitting. Therefore, I move:
That the debate be adjourned.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [No. 2]FAMILY LAW REFORM (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 October, on motion by Senators Faulkner and Crowley:
That these bills be now read a second time.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making my comments on the Family Law Reform Bill, I want to commence my contribution by simply pointing out that 1995 is the 20th anniversary of the Family Law Act. Ever since its introduction, substantial amendments have been necessary. The act needs ongoing attention. Hardly a year goes by without a major change being required to the act, regulations or court procedures.

PARA.TAB: The family is the basic unit of society. Most people obtain their comfort, support and succour from their family. It is consistently ranked as the most important aspect of people's lives and as the institution that recognises their individual worth and to which they can retreat for support. It is therefore not surprising that when a family unit breaks down there is severe hurt, emotional trauma and bitterness associated with the demise of the family unit. I look forward to the day when we, in this place, devote as much time to bolstering our families and assisting them with government initiatives as we do to dealing with consequences of breakdown.

This bill provides for further changes to the Family Law Act. In providing a legislative framework for mediation and counselling to assist in the resolution of conflict rather than having recourse to the courts, the bill is enunciating an appropriate principle. This aspect of the legislation should not be seen as an attack on my legal colleagues who practise in the area of family law. As a practitioner myself, I have experienced the difficulties of trying to resolve matrimonial discord.

The vast majority of lawyers in this country act honourably and within the best interests of their clients. However, given the emotion charged atmosphere of matrimonial breakdown, it is often expedient to blame a lawyer or, even better, a judge for an unpalatable outcome. The one discipline in the law where clients are most likely to switch lawyers is the family law area. The reasons are manifold but I suspect emotion, anger, vindictiveness and other thought processes in this trying time are often the cause.

As an aside, I regret the increasing number of negligence claims against family lawyers which mainly arise from the one practitioner being engaged by both parties to tie up the loose ends and then one party crying foul after a settlement has been achieved. That adds to the costs and now makes it most unlikely that lawyers are prepared to sit down with both sides to achieve a fair, speedy and relatively cheap outcome because the threat of future negligence claims hang over their heads.

Clearly mediation and counselling will be a more edifying and dignifying approach to dispute resolution in an area of life where dignity is usually lost in the hurt and anger. However, mediation and counselling only work when both parties are willing to compromise and there is some reservoir, no matter how small, of goodwill. Even without these provisions these people would normally settle without the need for a formal court hearing. Where there is no goodwill, resort to the courts will still be necessary.

As a Tasmanian legal practitioner, I can boast that we in Tasmania have the highest rate of settlements in Australia in the family law area. It is undoubtedly indicative of the professional and commonsense approach adopted by my colleagues in Tasmania. Counselling and mediation are categorised in the legislation as primary dispute resolution mechanisms. Obligations are imposed on practitioners and the courts to consider the efficacy of these mechanisms and accordingly advise the parties to the dispute. For the mechanisms to be effective, the same immunity needs to be afforded to the counsellors and mediators as is currently enjoyed by court based personnel.

In general terms, this legislative scheme is welcome. What is not welcome in this bill is the draconian provision to allow for the imprisonment of registrars. As a practitioner, I sometimes fleetingly dreamt about the possibility of imprisoning a registrar or a judge when they made a wrong decision or asked me a question that I could not answer. But to seriously dwell on such a proposition would be absurd. To commit it to writing, and even worse into legislation, really does deserve the gold medal for absurdity.

Unfortunately, it seems to me to be another example of a bureaucracy steamrolling the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and recommending a sledgehammer to crack a nut. But what is the nut? In this case, the penalty is directed at the wrongful disclosure of information provided under a location order by a registrar. The penalty is two years imprisonment. A tariff of two years is clearly out of kilter with the tariffs applied to other offences. Usually periods of imprisonment are legislated to act as a disincentive to act in a particular way. If a registrar did disclose improperly the location of a child then I am sure the loss of job that would undoubtedly flow from that would be a sufficient penalty in itself.

In recent times, I find I have little to agree with the Chief Justice of the Family Court, but on this issue I am at one with him. He said in his submission to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee when talking about this proposed penalty:

SPEECH.PARA: This penalty is both unnecessary and objectionable, the Court objects strongly to it and points out that such a sanction is found nowhere else in the Family Law Act. The capacity in which Registrars will often deal with this type of information is in the exercise of delegated judicial power and it is particularly inappropriate that those with such power be liable to a criminal sanction arising out of its exercise. Under the Court's staff structure Registry Managers and not Registrars have line responsibility for registry staff and so for the recording and storage of Court records. The Registrar to whom the sanction would apply consequently has no capacity to direct the secure receipt, storage and handling of the information. Given the sensitive nature of the Court's records it is illogical that there be a criminal sanction in respect of the treatment of one type of information alone.

Finally, I know of no basis on which such provision is justified. Court staff, except in the exercise of delegated judicial functions, are subject to the disciplinary provisions of the Public Service Act. There is no indication that this type of information has been treated recklessly by Court staff or that the normal disciplinary provisions under that Act would be inadequate in the event that this did occur.

I trust that the government will not persist with this draconian section in this bill. Another major aspect of this bill is to change the terminology of custody and access in the hope that the new phrases of residence orders and contact orders will some how instil an attitudinal change. I know that a lot of my colleagues on both sides see the change in terminology as being beneficial. I must indicate that I have some cynicism about that, although I do not oppose the change in terminology.

PARA.TAB: I recall the change in terminology to the present guardianship and custody terms. At that time, that was regarded as being quite innovative and a way to ease the hurt in matrimonial cases where children were involved. My years of practice tell me, and I hope that I am not too cynical, that, no matter what sociological middle class terms we use, out on the street of the real world the orders made will still be distilled to `I got the kids' or `I didn't get the kids'.

If the new regime works, all well and good. I acknowledge the intent of the legislation is to reinforce to all parents the ongoing responsibility for their children after separation, and that of course is most worthy. All I say is that I will not be holding my breath.

The Family Court these days, for example, basically will not make a joint custody order unless the parties agree to such an order, its attitude being that if they do not agree on a joint custody order how on earth would it work in practice. That approach adopted by the family courts around Australia seems to be a very reasonable approach. Similarly, we can use fancy words and feel good phrases but I remain to be convinced of their practical outcome.

Do not think that the parents who successfully apply for orders that their children reside with them will not feel the same elation as those parents who win custody battles today. Can I say that the same tears of joy and the same tears of anguish will continue to be shed in the Family Court foyers around Australia as are shed today as a result of the court outcomes irrespective of the terminology that is employed in the legislation.

The issue of violence and access is also addressed in this bill. In the past there has been the potential for conflicting court orders relating to restraint of a party and an order for access. This is a sensitive and very difficult issue. As somebody who was involved in the setting up of a women's shelter and who was on its management committee for some years, I believe that I have some understanding of the social evil of domestic violence. Having been involved in obtaining restraint orders, I also know the very real trauma that is attached to domestic violence.

Clearly, there is a need for mechanisms to be in place for the granting of expeditious protection orders. However, the parliament should also keep in mind the possibility of protection orders being obtained on false information or embellished statements. Those of us who have practised in the family law area would from our own experiences be able to draw on examples where that has occurred.

In most circumstances it ought to be possible to immediately appeal an order suspending an access order made pursuant to a protection order and not wait the 21 days proposed in the bill. I look forward to developing that further during the committee stages. A three-day suspension prior to appeal is more appropriate and ought to be accepted by the government.

I note that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee unanimously made the suggestion to reduce the 21 day period to three days. I trust that the minister will advance the reasons for the government's determination to proceed with a 21 day suspension.

I note that the bill inserts an object clause in part 7 of the act which will provide that children should receive adequate and proper parenting to help them achieve their full potential. Nobody, of course, would argue with that. It is a most laudable objective. The bill makes it clear that this objective is based on principles which are consistent with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. The government's often slavish and manic recourse to international treaties is laughable. Quite frankly, there are more credible sources and authorities for those principles than a UN convention.

I am glad that the government did not have to have recourse to international treaties to finally grant the grandparents of this nation their rightful place in the Family Law Act. I am sure that the only moral persuasion was that of community pressure. The grandparents of this nation organised themselves into various groups, requesting recognition under the Family Law Act, and they made a very forceful presentation to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. I was privileged to be able to read their written submission and to hear their verbal submission.

Those of us who deal in the area of family law know that grandparents are often the backstop in marriage breakdown. It is very good for the children involved to have some stable relationship with a relative. Grandparents often baby-sit, undertake child minding and offer very real assistance in part of the lives of their grandchildren. Regrettably, when a marriage breaks up the in-laws quickly become the out-laws and access is denied to the grandparents. Whereas previously it was seen as beneficial for the children to have regular contact with their grandparents whilst the marriage was on foot, after a breakdown contact suddenly becomes impossible or too difficult, or the grandparents allegedly become too old or frail to look after the children properly.

I note that the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee unanimously recommended that the Family Law Act ought to be altered to provide for the special mention of grandparents. The government rejected this suggestion in its official response with a classic dose of Sir Humphrey Appleby gobbledegook. As the only senator to express my genuine regret at the government's response when it was before the Senate—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so. I raised the matter.

—I was the only one who initially addressed the government's response when it was before the Senate. The Hansard record will disclose that. As I was saying, as the only senator to express my genuine regret in the Senate at the government's response when it was before the Senate, let me now express my genuine appreciation at the government's change of heart on this issue.

PARA.TAB: On balance, the bill has my support. However, it could be vastly improved with further amendments. I trust that that will occur. I look forward to the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very short in my remarks on the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2] and the Family Law Reform (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. This legislation does a number of things. As well as tinkering with some of the provisions, it contains some benefits. It has come about as a result of considerable discussion in the Joint Committee on Certain Family Law Issues, in the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee, within the government and within the community.

PARA.TAB: On 25 September this year the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, said that `the institution of marriage is at the heart of this government's agenda'. I applaud that statement, but I have been waiting, frankly, for years to see any evidence of that assertion. I do not in any way reflect on the minister or on the intentions of the minister, but as things stand, the family is under attack. The family is under attack in a wide range of areas—from the moral area to the economic area.

I have stood in this place time and time again to show that the average family, particularly those on one income, is far worse off now than it was in 1982. I know that there are figures now being bandied about by certain people who suggest that that is not the case. They tend to use NATSEM figures, which the authors of those reports and that research admit are incomplete. To give you one example, they take into account the effect of direct taxation; they do not take into account the effects that certain substantial increases in indirect taxation and in user charges are having on the family. Nor do they take into account the effects of payments that are made by the family for compulsory superannuation at a time of their lives when many of them can ill afford such payments. That sort of debate is for another occasion.

There are pressures on families and there are pressures on one-income families. There are particular pressures on single-parent families. When we are at meetings of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards we hear all the time the film industry, the television industry and the computer network industry saying, `Why should there be regulations? It's for the parents to make sure that their children are not seeing things that are inappropriate for them.' You even get that response when you cite examples of depictions and writings of child pornography, hard-core material and extremely violent material being available on the Internet and so on. Some of the industries say, `It is for the parents to be observant.'

Parents, particularly those in one-parent families, find it extremely difficult to be mother, father, guardian and provider—going out to work and coming home—and to be able to do that. Obviously, it is their primary responsibility—I acknowledge that. But government and the rest of us who are involved in public affairs do have the responsibility to assist parents in what for them is the most important vocation that they have—that is, parenting. I suppose this is the basis for this legislation. It is attempting, I suppose, to assist parents who are separated and divorced with a parenting plan.

I hear the commendation around the chamber for the acceptance by the government of the work done by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee on the issue of grandparents. I acknowledge that, and I congratulate those responsible. I happen to be the grandfather of 16, and a proud one at that. I know the pressures placed upon families with young children at this point of time. It is important to acknowledge, which this bill does, the key role that grandparents can play in these circumstances. In normal circumstances grandparents, I can tell you, play a very enormous and rewarding role. It keeps you alive, I can tell you.

Another matter that hopefully is just not a platitude in this legislation is the section which places an obligation upon those involved, including judges and court counsellors, to show the way towards reconciliation of the partners. That is a laudable objective. It is high time that was done.

Last year marriage breakdown and divorce were the highest for any year since 1975. That is very distressing. It is distressing for those directly affected—not only the couples but also the children and the parents of the couples as well, namely, the grandparents of the children. There is that personal individual cost.

The direct cost to the taxpayer of marriage breakdown is over $3 billion. That figure demands consideration. It demands urgent action which is designed to assist parents and families to uphold the dignity of the institution of marriage. In this place I have queried the relatively small amount paid for marriage education. Whilst the direct cost to the taxpayer of divorce each year is over $3 billion, we spend a mere $10 on average for education and support per marriage.

It is very important, I believe, to put a new focus on that and to enhance the role of marriage education. I know the government is looking at that. I know the minister's intentions in regard to this matter. I feel that in the economic portfolios of cabinet this matter needs to be raised and focused. If it is going to prevent marriage breakdown and encourage communication between the couples, there is a need to make sure they have common interests, to encourage their love and devotion for each other.

The Family Law Act says that those involved in the administration of the law and the parties concerned should acknowledge that the family is the fundamental group unit of society, based on the union of a man and a woman voluntarily entered into for life. It is important to remind ourselves of section 43 of the act, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court shall in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this act, shall in the exercise of that jurisdiction have regard to:

PARA.TAB: (a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life.

SPEECH.PARA: That very important principle needs to be focused upon. I believe that there is a further need to give support and help to couples in the separation period, when both parties are going through enormous upheaval and turmoil, as is their family. Even from an economic point of view, if a reconciliation can be undertaken that is an enormous saving to the taxpayer. This legislation places an obligation on judges, counsellors and the like to put emphasis on reconciliation. It also places that obligation on lawyers. That might be whistling in the wind to a certain extent but I hope it is not.

PARA.TAB: Certain comments that have been made by His Honour the Chief Justice of the Family Court Chief, Chief Justice Nicholson, have been mentioned in the chamber. I do not want to say much about that but I feel that his comments were not entirely appropriate. With respect, I would like to suggest to him that that view is fairly widely held amongst people whom I know in the legal profession, in the counselling profession and in other areas. I know it must be an enormously frustrating job to be Chief Justice of the Family Court—it is a job that I certainly would not want to have responsibility for—but I feel that statements of the type which were voiced by Senator Brownhill and Senator McKiernan and maybe one or two other senators and statements made by Chief Justice Nicholson were not appropriate. I refer to a letter which appeared in the Australian newspaper on 23 September 1995. The letter refers to the statements made by Chief Justice Nicholson as not being appropriate. It states:

His Honour does not deign to offer reasoned responses to criticisms made of the Court and its performance. Instead, he blackguards "some of the Court's critics" as "dysfunctional, strident, unrepresentative and often irrational".

He surmises that much of the criticism of the Court "is an unfortunate manifestation of right wing groups demonstrating hatred of all government institutions, and particularly those they perceive may interfere with their so-called right to exercise power over people who are smaller and weaker than they are".

Of the tabloid press and television, he is reported as saying they were guilty of exploiting the views of aggrieved minorities and turning them into "a relentless and invariably ill-informed assault on the Court".

SPEECH.PARA: The letter goes on:

I wonder at my own courage in making a public response to one who himself responds to critics with such ill defined (right wing groups) and unqualified (invariably ill-informed) charges, which attack the critics without attempting to identify or answer the criticisms.
Here is the point of the letter:

PARA.TAB: The report of the Chief Justice's speech brings no credit on the Court. Many of his statements are clearly unjudicial and seem to me to be injudicious. God help us if this is the way ahead for critics of individual judges or of courts or of the laws that the courts are established to adjudicate on.
I should perhaps say that neither I nor any member of my immediate family has been engaged in any litigation in the Family Court. I have never practised in that Court.

SPEECH.PARA: That letter is from the former Crown Solicitor, Mr B. O'Donovan. I think people such as he should be listened to. I do hope that Justice Nicholson does have regard to these areas when next he puts pen to paper or makes a public speech.

PARA.TAB: There are a few things I want to touch on very briefly in regard to the legislation itself. One matter was dealt with by Senator Margaret Reid in relation to certain steps not being able to be taken within 21 days. As I understand it, that is by the Federal Court, but action can be taken in the magistrate's court, which may well be cheaper and more effective than in the Federal Court. I would like to have an explanation of that when we come to that particular clause.

Secondly, I will be seeking explanations about the absolute privilege that has been given to discussions between husbands and wives with family counsellors present as compared with what occurs in discussions which are otherwise admissible between husband and wife. Also, I will be seeking information as to why action is not being taken to deal with recommendation 1(b) of the Family Law Council, that legislation should provide that it is unlawful to sterilise a child under 18 years. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —These family law bills are the latest pieces of legislation introduced into the parliament in the context of the Family Law Act. They certainly will not be the last, because this is an area—as those who have spoken before me have made so clear—where you can never get it right because of the problems that come about when a couple divorces or separates. As has been said by both previous speakers this morning, Senator Abetz and Senator Harradine, this is an area where tragedy looms large, where there must be compassion for people going through the dreadful traumas that are no doubt related to the break up of a family.

PARA.TAB: I agree with Senator Harradine that more should be done to see if a marriage can be preserved and, even before that, that the marriage sets out in a way that makes it last. I think what has to be changed is the culture of marriage. There is, I think, an understanding when people marry now that if things go a little harshly at times, then there is nothing much wrong with separating. I think that is a culture that has to change. Whether the government or we as legislators can do much about that, I do not know.

It is quite clear that this is a very difficult area and we tend in those circumstances to blame particular individuals. I noticed this morning that Senator Harradine referred to the Chief Justice of the Family Court, Alastair Nicholson. Senator McKiernan, whom I greatly admire, took him to task yesterday. May I say that I have known the Chief Justice for many years now and watched him, both on the Supreme Court of Victoria and on the Family Court of Australia. Given the difficulties that we have spoken about, it is my opinion that he has performed outstanding service on that court and that indeed he has performed outstanding service outside it. From that statement, I go on to say that other judges in the Family Court, both men and women, have done us proud as a nation in the way they have gone about the very difficult task that they have had to perform.

In this context of giving praise, in the circumstances of the present legislation, another group that I think often gets criticised, and criticised unfairly, are the people from the Attorney-General's Department who actually have to get what we legislators think about and talk about into a form of legislation that comes before us. Oftentimes they are criticised for that, but I would have thought that the efforts by Mr Richard Morgan and Amanda Davies in this particular bill deserve commendation. They have had to go through a long and difficult period to get the legislation we presently have before us. I see Peter Trahair and others here this morning. He was more than gracious in giving me some help before I got to my feet to speak.

Can I say about judges generally, because they are coming in for some criticism around the place, that they do perform great service to this country and in different areas. I was speaking this morning to my son Justin, who is an associate to the Deputy President of the Industrial Relations Court, Simon Williams. Again, he is a person who is in a very difficult area. With due respect to people who work in the industrial area, which I used to do myself, so I include myself in this, they do not have the difficulty that I think people who deal with the break-up of marriages do, but nevertheless, they have a most fundamental job to perform in this society, and they do it well. Certainly Deputy President Williams is one of those.

One of the good bits of news in this legislation that everybody has commented on is the fact that we give special recognition to grandparents. May I commend Senator Harradine on being a grandparent. It is something that I unfortunately have been denied to this point of time. Certainly, in respect of my own mother-in-law, Lalla Gill, the one remaining grandparent of my children, inasmuch as they are good citizens of this country and decent people, it has much to do with her. In respect of two of them, who were born when my mother, Corrie Cooney, was alive, it had much to do with her as well.

So I do mark the great importance of the role played by grandparents. In this culture of cohesion that we should try to develop to keep families together, grandparents and, indeed, the wider family play a very big role. We have to start concentrating on that idea of the wider family—people who are related getting together—and perhaps not be quite so nuclear as families seem to be these days.

There has been a lot of deep, good thinking about this, much of which has been carried out by the people on the legal and constitutional committee—and Senator Abetz has played a great role in that. So has Senator Spindler who has put forward some amendments to this bill. I must confess that anything that Senator Spindler puts forward is a matter that I take most seriously.

However, one matter that concerns me is the way Senator Spindler wants to go around the registering of parenting plans—and this has been dealt with in the debate so far. The idea is that if husband and wife are to break apart and they want to register a parenting plan as to how the children should be looked after, then they should be able to do so in the court.

It is suggested in the amendments put forward by Senator Spindler that, if they are to do that, both parties have to get independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the agreement before entering into the agreement, the plan itself has to be certified by the legal practitioners who gave that advice, and the court has to be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the party's child or children.

That is a very good idea indeed, the thrust of which is that children should be protected—and nobody could doubt that. I would have thought that children should be protected whether or not their parents break up. I would have thought that children should be protected whether or not the parents register a parenting plan.

It seems there is nothing peculiar in the act of registering a parenting plan which makes the children the subject of that parenting plan any more or less in need of help than any other child in the community, excepting perhaps that they are the people who are affected by the splitting up. But the very act of registration does not seem to have anything peculiar about it that should visit upon the process an examination by the court of that arrangement.

As Mr Trahair told me as I came in, 95 per cent of the cases in the Family Court are settled. That would be consistent with what happens in courts generally—most disputes are settled. So the court deals with that small percentage, five per cent or less, of all disputes that come before it. I should have thought it was those disputes that ought to attract the court's attention because it is disputes that courts are about.

In the end, the Family Court is a court. That means it has to resolve disputes between the parties. It is not there as a reservoir of social workers; it is not there as a reservoir of clergymen and women; it is not there as a reservoir of psychologists or psychiatrists; it is not there as a reservoir of people who want to do the right thing socially. The court is there to decide disputes between citizens—a task that has been going on since Australia was founded and in England, from which we get our legal system, for many centuries before that.

It is my own view that, if you are going to have a legal system run by courts, the courts ought to act as courts and not in these other characters that I have spoken about. It seems to me that, if there is no dispute brought before the courts, then the courts should not have any part in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I acknowledge with thanks Senator Abetz's interjection. If there is a dispute about the agreement, if there is a dispute whether an agreement should be entered into the first place or not and the matter should be disposed of by other means, then, of course, the courts should come into it. But I am concerned that taking away the great function and character of the court—which is, as it were, to stand above the parties; to let them put their case; and to have that case disposed of with parties introducing evidence and bringing their legal problems forward to be resolved by the court—is very dangerous not only for the Family Court but also for the whole legal system that has served us, in my view in any event, very well over the years.

PARA.TAB: From a practical point of view, it seems to me to be taking us down a path that will be very expensive—in terms of the number of judges we would have to have as well as the buildings to house them and their staff—if we are going to require the court to be satisfied that the arrangements are likely to promote the best interests of the parties' child or children, as required by the Democrats' amendment. Indeed, it would seem to me there is little point in having an agreement if the court has to be satisfied that it is one that is likely to promote the best interests of the parties' child or children, because the court would have to have a full-scale hearing to satisfy itself that that was the situation.

That leads us into two problems. Firstly, there is the overwhelming amount of resources that would be needed in terms of judges, buildings and things like that. Secondly, there would be no point having an agreement, because the court has to satisfy itself that the arrangements are in the best interests of the child or children. If the court has to call evidence to decide that, why not just hear the matter and make the decision itself?

It could be argued, of course, that it is best for parties to agree and then for the court to look at that agreement to see whether it is proper. I go along with the point that it is best for parties to agree. Most people that split up—not all, but most—split up with sadness, no doubt, in their hearts but with sense in their heads and come to a proper arrangement. They ought to be able to pursue those arrangements that best suit them. If they do not, if there is a dispute, then the court ought to move in. But there ought to be a dispute before the court does so.

If I can leave the bill with those few remarks, then I am well satisfied. It is a big issue and, as I said before, it is an issue that will be pursued hereafter. I think the present legislation is a right step, a proper step and a good step along the road. Unfortunately, with marriage breakups, I think it is very hard to make straight again the line that is bent. There is just so much difficulty in trying to get back to how things were before such a fundamental step as marriage—I see it as the most fundamental step—was, as it were, stopped from operating. That must leave tragedy in the heart. Unfortunately, marriage breakups must leave resentment at times, which sometimes even bubbles over to hatred. Those are emotions which do not make it easy for the Family Law Act to operate as people want—and it never will. But, given those parameters, I think the act does operate well.

I think we have to give our judges encouragement rather than criticism. I think we have to understand the families that the court deals with and tries to help. I think we have to thank those who, as I say, get the legislation to a form where it operates well. I think that the Attorney-General's Department, under Richard Morgan, has done that well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the Family Law Reform Bill, which is the most far-reaching legislation amending the Family Law Act since the act's introduction. As with almost every wide-ranging bill of this type, this bill has generated an enormous amount of discussion within the community. There are parts of the bill which have been hailed as being very positive, while other parts have been condemned.

PARA.TAB: It is to the government's credit that it has provided ample opportunity for community feedback on this bill. I want to foreshadow that the Greens will be putting various amendments to the chamber in committee, but first I want to make some comments on the general issues raised by the bill.

The emphasis on primary dispute resolution by non-litigation methods in the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 is very welcome. We support a consensual approach to dispute resolution in all areas of law. This is so in family law matters, where the parties often need to establish terms for ongoing cooperation, particularly if children are involved. Many parties continue to negotiate their own resolution, and it is to be hoped that the amendments to regulations, which have yet to be finalised, will facilitate self-help in filing for consent orders.

I was reminded on many occasions during the discussion about the bill that some 95 per cent of divorce cases do not go to the court. That is a most encouraging situation. But we have to acknowledge that there remain many matters which will require professional help, and it is to be hoped that the primary dispute resolution methods which are a focus of the legislation will add to the structures available to people who are facing up to a marriage breakdown.

The use of the term `primary dispute resolution' rather than `alternative dispute resolution' gives these services the priority they deserve. Similarly, we see the provisions for funding of counselling organisations and mediation organisations as worthy of support in principle, since they give a welcome emphasis to accessible, community-based dispute resolution services and reduce the focus on the institutions of the state with their tendency towards expense and complexity.

We believe, therefore, that the whole bill should be evaluated in terms of what it achieves for access to justice. Despite the government's recent initiatives on access to justice, the practical difficulties for a substantial part of the population remain. In total, under present funding arrangements, despite the 1995-96 increases, primary dispute resolution services are inadequate to meet the need in terms of location, waiting periods and cost.

We are likely to be left with a parallel situation to that which presently exists in the provision of legal services; that is, that the wealthy and the legally aided low-income recipients receive legal services, but to the average income earners they are prohibitively expensive. Similarly, persons living in the country are disadvantaged relative to city dwellers.

There needs to be a large low cost network of primary dispute resolution providers so that everyone, irrespective of means or location of residence, is able to access them. Clearly, it is time for the government to look into creating a means of providing sessional payment of private mediators and counsellors.

The bill leaves the way open for individuals to provide mediation services in private practice. This is a welcome position subject to suitable funding being made available as per my comments earlier. However, using a mix of mediators, counsellors and arbitrators within court, community and private categories has implications for issues of immunity and accountability.

Withholding immunity from private mediators and counsellors, as per the amendment foreshadowed by the Australian Democrats, would not be an issue if such people were accredited by the Family Court on the basis of skills and training. This would not prevent non-accredited persons mediating or counselling, and we accept that these non-accredited private mediators and counsellors should not have immunity conferred by this law. The government has advised that the regulations will set out appropriate guidelines within which private mediators must work and that their immunity will be limited to the extent to which they adhere to the regulations. While we would definitely prefer an accreditation structure, we are prepared to support the government's stance on this.

With respect to the proposed part VII of the bill, the principles in section 60B(2) are ones which most parents today will support and work towards in their negotiations following separation. A minority will not. The question is, how should the law treat such situations? During discussion of the bill in the community there has rightly been an emphasis on ensuring that application of the principles does not compel a parent or a child to suffer abuse and violence after separation. There has been some recognition by the courts that in some circumstances the drastic step of depriving a parent of access is necessary for the protection of the child. This bill presents an opportunity to reinforce the protection given to those—whether children or parents—who may be subject to violence or abuse.

In the bill there is recognition that not all matters are suitable for mediation. While the bill does appear to address the current problem of mediation agencies taking on clients despite the history of abuse in a relationship or continuing power imbalances, we understand the desire of groups such as the National Women's Justice Coalition to strengthen the relevant provisions. Therefore, the Greens will be supporting a number of the Democrat amendments in this regard.

However, we should recognise that the victims of violence are sometimes left without the means to go through litigation because of expense and a lack of legal aid funds. They are doubly victimised. I urge the government to consider a special allocation of funds for legal aid applicable to circumstances where the primary dispute resolution means are inappropriate and litigation is the only means of resolving issues.

We also support provisions for separate representation of children. Again, they will not work unless the government is prepared to allocate adequate and specific funds for legal aid. Court protection of the rights of children in situations of separation has not been adequate. I believe that there has been an improvement but only in relatively recent times. Legal aid funding for this purpose has yet to catch up with the courts' recent decisions.

We welcome the government's proposed amendment giving recognition that the indigenous people of Australia have particular needs in terms of attachment to a particular part of Australia, a particular cultural group or extended family. The Family Law Act should not add new generations to those who have already been deprived of growing up in their own communities. Cultural connections as provided by the government's amendment should be taken into consideration equally with a number of other factors with respect to the best interests of the child.

The Greens will be putting an amendment specifically to incorporate the Convention on the Rights of the Child into the act. In particular I refer honourable senators to article 9(3) of the convention which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Parties shall respect the right of the child who is separated from one or both parents to maintain personal relations and direct contact with both parents on a regular basis, except if it is contrary to the child's best interests.

We will also be putting amendments which would allow the court to assess the effectiveness of a parent's access when the likelihood exists that the parent providing accommodation to the child will move interstate or to faraway places. The fact is that some parents do decide to limit or prevent regular access by moving. Ulterior motives are difficult to prove but on occasions it seems that the right of the child is overridden by the selfish motivation of a parent. I do not refer here to situations where a parent flees in fear of spousal violence or in situations where they are concerned about the wellbeing of the child. I am referring to actions motivated by malice towards a former spouse. The child's best interests should not be overruled in instances of this kind.

PARA.TAB: In Western Australia, we are acutely aware that a move interstate or even from the south to the north of the state, let alone overseas, can make access prohibitively expensive. The practice has been to seek injunctions preventing this where the interests of the child, supported by expert evidence of, for example, counselling reports, suggest the child's need to retain regular contact with both parents.

In summary, we support the principles underlying the bill. The amendments that we seek and support are those which emphasise the principles favouring the responsibility of parents to reach an agreement in the best interests of the child and much improved access to justice and those which place a precautionary principle in the legislation in relation to family violence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those members who have spoken in the debate on the family law legislation for the very constructive comments they have made. Once again the members of this chamber have demonstrated their bipartisan approach to the resolution of the very difficult issues associated with family law.

PARA.TAB: The family law legislation gives effect to a large part of the government's very positive response to the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, in light of the further advice of the Family Law Council on the operation of UK's Children Act 1989. It is hoped that a bill to implement the second part of the government's response will be introduced later in the sittings.

The point that was made by a number of speakers was the need for the government to monitor the effectiveness of the changed approach to issues affecting children. Everybody recognises that the old connotation of children being property needs to go. The government's approach takes that line. Large sections of the community currently deal with their children using the very principles that this bill is now enshrining. Unfortunately, there are members of the community who are not so enlightened and who continue to adhere to the notions of children as property.

The government expects that community change for that segment which needs to change will take time. The government has contracted with the Australian Institute of Family Studies to undertake in the next few weeks a survey of community attitudes to the way in which we think about and treat children. That survey will form a benchmark for gauging community attitudes to the changes in a longitudinal study to be undertaken at a number of points over the next five years.

Comment was also made of the need to regulate the qualifications and training of counsellors and mediators. Where the government is funding community counselling and mediation organisations, the government has had for some time criteria for approval of those organisations, including qualifications and professional development of individual counsellors and mediators. The Family Services Council will be providing advice on the appropriateness of these criteria as part of a review as a consequence of the increased reliance upon the primary dispute resolution emphasis in this bill.

In relation to mediators there is not an agreed qualification or training which provides professional qualifications as a mediator. The government will be laying down broad guidelines for the delivery of mediation services and providing accountability for that delivery through consumer protection mechanisms. The Attorney-General's Department has currently distributed for comment to over 400 relevant professional, community and interested groups a discussion paper outlining the draft proposals in this regard.

Senator Spindler's comments focused on his proposed amendments and in particular a prescriptive regime to deal with cases involving family violence and abuse. The government takes the view that this is the wrong approach and that the issues of whether or not particular primary dispute techniques should be utilised in a particular case is a matter for the professional judgment of the deliverer of the services. The government's approach is shared by the Family Law Council, which is a multidisciplinary body which considered the suggestion for the prescriptive regime made by the National Women's Justice Coalition which are embodied in the Democrats' amendments. In advising the Attorney-General in respect of the NWJC suggestion, the Family Law Council stated:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the council's view that it is not appropriate for judges, registrars, legal practitioners and others to be making such mediation intake decisions. The proposal of the NWJC would impose a barrier pre-intake. Council considers that it would be most inappropriate for, say legal practitioners, to be saying to clients that mediation would not be appropriate in their case. Mediators are specially trained to properly address such questions and the matter should be left in their hands at the time of intake.

The government is pleased that a number of speakers expressed approval of the change in terminology adopted in this legislation to get away from the concepts of custody and access. I note that the Democrats intend to move amendments based on a suggestion of the NWJC to reinstate the existing system under another name. This system has been rightly criticised by most of the speakers in the debate because of the negative effect and the entrenchment of treating children as a possession.

PARA.TAB: Some speakers in the debate have taken the view that the government's approach of allowing parents to work out their own solutions and arrangements in respect of children following the break-up of a relationship without the input of lawyers is an attack on the legal profession. Nothing could be further from the government's view in this matter. Parents should be able to obtain assistance from whoever they feel is appropriate in reaching decisions and developing their parenting plans. This may be lawyers, counsellors, mediators or other professionals. Parents should be able to expect that the decisions they arrive at will be respected within the community.

Just as in intact families, governments and bureaucracies leave decision making about children to parents without any interference and/or intrusion unless the child comes to attention as needing protection of the state, so separated parents ought to be afforded the opportunity to decide arrangements for their children without intrusion from the law, the court, the legal profession or the government.

The shadow Attorney-General's concern about registration of parenting plans is not shared by government. So long as the parties voluntarily comply with the plan, there is no intrusion. However, if one party does not comply or wishes to change the plan without the other's agreement, the court will then consider whether the arrangements are, at that later time, in the best interests of the child.

Deputy President Reid correctly saw the need for parents to be given this flexibility to make agreements and not to have the court examine them to see whether it would agree to those arrangements. Experience shows that once parties are involved in the court system their flexibility in reaching solutions is reduced. The adversarial nature of litigation may lead to consideration of issues or the taking of positions more suited to an adjudicated position rather than a solution which they can consider to be their own.

Senator Harradine has asked the minister what progress has been made in relation to the implementation of the Family Law Council report, Sterilisation and other medical procedures on children. It is currently with the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. The WA Law Reform Commission report had some conflicting recommendations on this matter. The Commonwealth is preparing a Standing Committee of Attorneys-General paper on the issues to be considered at its February meeting.

Finally, the debate has raised clause 67P of the bill, which makes provision for penalty to be imposed on court officials who intentionally or recklessly disclose information about the location of a person where that information has been located under a location order. The person seeking a location order needs to convince the court that there is a proper reason for the issuing of such an order. In many cases the need to locate has arisen because the parent with the child has gone into hiding to avoid family violence or abuse. The providing of information to the abuser in those circumstances reduces the protection that that parent has sought. The government is concerned to ensure that protection from family violence is not diminished by the actions of court processes or improper disclosure of information. Clause 67P as it stands will achieve that purpose. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PARA.TAB: "`68K.(1) In considering what order to make, the court must, to the extent that it is possible to do so consistently with the child's best interests being the paramount consideration, ensure that the order:

TAB.TAB: (a)is consistent with any family violence order; and
(b)does not expose a person to an unacceptable risk of family violence.

PARA.TAB: `(2) For the purposes of paragraph (1)(b) the court may include in the order any safeguards that it considers necessary for the safety of those affected by the order.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to advise the Senate that the Democrats will be supporting these amendments and withdrawing my amendments Nos 36 and 37, because they are largely the same.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 7, page 8, proposed section 14, at the end, add the following word and paragraph:
"and(c)to ensure that the court, lawyers, counsellors, mediators, arbitrators and others are sensitive to factors relevant to the selection and utilisation of primary dispute resolution options.".
2.Clause 7, page 11, proposed section 14F, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(2) For the purposes of any consideration under subsection (1), the court must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 7, page 11, proposed section 14G, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(2) For the purposes of any consideration under subsection (1), the legal practitioner must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 9, page 11, proposed section 16A, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(3) For the purposes of any consideration under subsection (1), the court must take the following matters into account in considering what is in the interests of the parties or their children:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 5.Clause 9, page 12, proposed section 16B, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(3) For the purposes of any consideration or advice under subsection (1) the court must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 9, page 12, proposed section 16C, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(4) For the purposes of any consideration to be made under subsection (2) or (3), a court or legal practitioner, as the case may be, must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 7.Clause 17, page 13, proposed section 19BA, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(3) For the purposes of any consideration to be made under subsection (1), the court must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments set out the relevant factors that are to be taken into account by the court and by other persons, for instance, legal practitioners and counsellors, when they are considering what primary dispute resolution mechanisms, if any, may be suitable for the parties. The Democrats felt that it was important to have the factors that are to be taken into account transparent in the bill, on the face of it, bearing in mind that what is in the bill very often sets the climate and influences the understanding of people who are in court or who are dealing with a dispute, are seeking to make a decision and are seeking to be advised as to whether a primary dispute resolution mechanism is suitable for them or whether they should proceed to court.

PARA.TAB: The factors that the Democrats believe should be taken into account are, first of all, the degree of equality or otherwise in the bargaining power of the parties, the risk of child abuse, the risk of family violence, the emotional and psychological state of the parties, whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method possibly to gain delay or to achieve some other advantage, and any other relevant matter.

We are concerned that the parties which seek to shortcut in some way the proceedings and use alternative methods of dispute resolution, while we support the principle, may not be in a position of equal knowledge or equal power. We believe that the alternatives should be assessed carefully before they are entered into.

Therefore, we suggest that the bill should make quite clear that that is done both as a reminder and to set the tone and the culture. We have talked about the culture of the Family Court and the proceedings. We believe that it is very important to have that in the bill.

This is also the view of many women's organisations which have contacted us. No doubt they have contacted other people as well, including the Attorney-General's department. They are concerned that in many situations it is the woman who could be at a disadvantage in these proceedings. They have suggested very strongly that it is necessary to set the tone in the bill and to warn all the parties in this process that these matters should be taken into account. I commend the amendments to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. I do not know that I need to speak at length. I anticipate that much of the consideration of these amendments has already been deliberated upon by members of this place who are interested in them.

PARA.TAB: We see the move by the Democrats as an unnecessary encumbrance to the process. In essence, we have amendments which seek to insert into the act sections relevant to primary dispute resolution methods. The factors are currently contained in order 25A, rule 5. This rule applies to court mediators and specifies the factors that a mediator must consider when determining whether a dispute is appropriate for mediation.

The amendments would require the court to give detailed consideration to these factors. In essence, that would mean that the primary dispute resolution methods which might be available would not be available, if these amendments were passed, until an advanced stage of the proceedings. It is important for us that the primary dispute resolution methods be considered early in the process. We see that the move by Senator Spindler could mean in many instances that would not be the case.

We do anticipate problems in terms of people being denied those primary dispute resolution methods at an early stage. This would have an important impact on the process. We recognise it is important to tread warily in this area. The Attorney-General's Department has prepared a discussion paper on the proposed regulatory requirements to apply to mediators. The paper proposes that before conducting a mediation the mediator should consider the factors that Senator Spindler seeks to have inserted. The paper also gives a higher priority to safety and violence issues than the amendments do. We think that the factors should be taken into account earlier. As a consequence, we oppose Senator Spindler's move at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the minister that only a couple of the amendments seek to have the court address these matters. There are amendments which call upon legal practitioners, counsellors and mediators to give attention to these factors. That goes to the question that it could obviously be dealt with at an earlier stage. I do not think that we should rush into this matter and, for administrative ease and efficiency, neglect the very important issues that are at stake here.

PARA.TAB: Could the minister expand on exactly how these matters are to be brought to the attention of the court—I take his point that that is at a later stage—or, earlier, to the attention of a counsellor, a mediator and a legal practitioner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two points, I think, were raised. With respect to your first point that sometimes legal practitioners would have the screening role, it would probably put them sometimes in an invidious position to determine whether or not to provide information and whether or not to invoke those primary dispute resolution mechanisms. It would, I am sure, create problems, particularly for those who might be self-represented. So there are those sorts of mechanical problems with your amendment.

PARA.TAB: The other aspect is that at the intake level in the screening process the mediators and counsellors would consider the sorts of issues you are concerned about. They have a capacity to ensure that the issues are followed up through the court process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister is not offering any commitment that these matters will be brought to the attention of the various parties in an organised manner when people are in the very traumatic process of a dissolution of marriage. I would be more sympathetic to the minister's arguments if he could indicate a commitment to do that as part of the process. At the moment he is simply saying that the legal practitioner, the media and the counsellors are aware of all these things. We believe we need to go a step further and make sure that they are aware of it. I would like an assurance from the government that steps will be taken to see that this is done in each case.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think part of the process you are talking about here is the initial part of the process, where you are concerned that these factors are taken into account, particularly by counsellors and mediators. That is already accommodated in the government's proposals. We have to separate this part of the process from the latter part of the process that you might be referring to. These sorts of matters, I am informed, are taken into account by mediators. We will ensure that they are taken into account by counsellors as well.

—I did not want to cut across any questions that Senator Spindler wished to ask the minister; I just want to indicate that the Greens support the Democrat amendments. I take the opportunity of asking the minister, because this is the appropriate time, what the government's view is on looking at the sessional payment of private mediators and counsellors and at the fact that there is inadequate funding available.
