So there are two matters. One is any provisions the government might have in mind for increasing the level of funding in the light of the changes that are being made, which are very welcome. We believe it is desirable that people should have greater access to primary dispute resolution processes. So the first question relates to funds and the absolute necessity to address that funding need. If we are going to bring new measures within the reach of people then we ought to allow them the capacity to take them up.

PARA.TAB: The second matter relates to accreditation. We need to look at a system of accreditation which may operate from within the Family Court process or have some kind of link to that. There should be the ability to find approved counselling or mediation organisations or the capacity to refer to a private mediator or counsellor if the court or an approved counselling and mediation organisation is unavailable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can answer in part the first two parts of the question, and I undertake to come back to you with some of the finer details. In respect to payments, my understanding is that people do pay on an income basis and that money goes to counselling organisations. The justice statement, you might remember, also allocated extra resources for counselling in this area. At the moment we cannot locate the actual amount of extra resources through the justice statement, but I will come back to you with that. I will probably come back to you on the third point you raised as well during the course of the day.

—While you are seeking to answer that question, I might spell out a little more detail for the ease of the people providing the answer. Basically, the Greens see the need to permit sessional payment of private mediators and counsellors. Family Court counselling services, we think, should not only be a direct provider of services and should not be the only point for services but a point of contact at which primary dispute resolution, if the client is suitable, is guaranteed irrespective of means, and I understand that the minister is looking at the means.

PARA.TAB: I think the way in which that funding is given is also of concern. If the court itself, or an approved counselling or mediation organisation is unavailable, then the client should be able to be referred to a private mediator or counsellor. But, for the system to work, maybe this bill should be amended to provide, firstly, a system of accreditation and, secondly, to provide for payment on a sessional basis, albeit with partial cost recovery or means testing of the client. I know that has not been proposed, but I seek the minister's advice on it because I believe that mediation services would then be much more widely available. This is of particular importance to country residents who may have to travel considerable distances to attend the Family Court or a community mediation service but who may have an accredited mediator—whether, for example, a lawyer or a social worker—in the vicinity.

I think the family law is a discrete area in which it would be relatively simple to establish an accreditation system administered by the Family Court. The Supreme Court of Western Australia has a panel of accredited mediators for civil disputes, so there is no reason why the Family Court should not do likewise. I think the restrictions of this bill, which place restrictions on funding counselling and mediation organisations—that is, that the whole or substantial part of the organisation's activities be family counselling or mediation respectively—will thus be overcome, and funds could be distributed to any accredited primary dispute resolution provider in accordance with the amount of family law mediation provided. That would expand the network of services quite greatly.

So, in putting that to the minister, I point out that I would like to see those matters responded to by the government. The Greens are not putting up amendments to that effect; we see the amendments put up by the Democrats as addressing similar concerns but not exactly tackling them in that way, so we would like a government response to these suggested improvements. No doubt the government has been lobbied in this area and may already have a view, but it would be good to have this added to this committee consideration.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think I can give you an answer that will satisfy you. What I can say, as is reflected in this legislation, is that the government has recognised the three different tiers of counselling provision—court, community based and private. With respect to the justice statement which I mentioned earlier, an extra $12 million over four years has been provided for court and community-based counselling services. The private ones are not being assisted in that way, and that is obviously your concern. It is one that we cannot accommodate at this particular time.

PARA.TAB: Accreditation in the absence of a national body, as you will realise, is difficult. What we are doing with this particular legislation is approaching the need for standards and performance benchmarks by having regulations in place and, further on during the course of some of the amendments, I think we will be discussing the way that regulations cover, for instance, private counselling services. That is the way the government thought best to achieve the best balance of providing and encouraging the interplay of the three levels of counselling.
Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Clause 25, page 14, after mediator (second occurring) add "(other than a private mediator)".

This amendment will delete a government proposal to extend immunity from suit presently enjoyed by approved mediators and arbitrators to those private mediators and arbitrators who do not enjoy any form of accreditation, in other words, private mediators. With the bill's greater promotion of primary dispute resolution, the number of mediators in private practice will obviously increase, leading to a real risk of an increase in inadequately trained and unsupervised mediators.

PARA.TAB: In this bill the government is proposing to provide total immunity to these private mediators despite there being no comprehensive system of regulation or accreditation in place. It seems to the Australian Democrats that we are rather premature in doing that unless and until we have a proper system of accreditation in place. I would have hoped that the government would support this amendment and realise that it was trying to rush into matters a little too quickly. It seems to me that to extend total immunity to private mediators is not the way to go at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the coalition is not minded to support this amendment. I understand the position that Senator Spindler puts but, equally, there is another perspective. That is that while we are trying to encourage people to not go through the full court process—and we are trying to encourage them to do that by taking alternative primary dispute resolution measures—to, in effect, build in another dispute mechanism is, I think, in a sense what you are doing.

PARA.TAB: I understand the argument you make with respect to the delay the government is taking, but at this stage we are happy to take the government's commitment that they will in fact have that in place in the near future, and it just seems to me that the concept of mediation in which you say to people, `You should be able to sue your mediator,' is not going to work on that basis. It is just not going to work. If you are sitting there trying to come to some resolution of these matters that are necessarily very difficult—there is a lot of personal animosity and bitterness in many of these cases; otherwise they would be resolved and parties would come to an agreement. What you are, in effect, trying to do is say, `If you are not happy with the mediation, if at some later period you decide that it all would have gone another way if only the mediator had done A, B, C or D, you should then put them at risk.'

I honestly believe that what you are doing is limiting the capacity of a mediator to properly do their job. That is what I think you are doing, albeit I understand the complaints you make with respect to the government not having complied with not so much a bargain but the commitments it made earlier with respect to getting that system in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reinforce the comments made by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. I find the intent of the amendment, that we give the capacity to those fronting up to mediation to be able to sue their mediators, somewhat incongruous. As I said in the second reading debate, in the past family lawyers have in fact been pretty immune from negligence claims, whereas now unfortunately they are starting to come in. Most of them are based on those situations where, in smaller towns or practices, a husband and wife have come in together seeking the assistance of the one lawyer to tie up the loose ends, to get a quick response. They want it fair, they want it cheap. But then, after the fullness of time, bitterness takes over and one of them cries foul.

PARA.TAB: As a result, the cost of these agreements is now becoming a lot more expensive because no lawyer will ever again, I would assume, act for both sides in a dispute because they do not have that protection from being sued. Quite frankly, nobody in the private sector would ever engage in mediation in trying to bring the couple together to resolve outstanding differences on children, parental agreements, or whatever other matters if there was that possibility of being sued.

To say that a private mediator ought be submitted to that sort of possible legal challenge really pulls the rug out from underneath any private mediation service playing a useful role at this stage. I should have thought that, with the increase in mediation that we want to see, we ought be encouraging private mediators. If we want to encourage mediators, we do need to provide them with a protection so that they can go about their job without fear or favour, or the concern that they may be sued at a later stage when they have acted within the best interests of everybody but one of the parties does not consider it to have been within his or her best interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just add to the previous comments of Senator Vanstone and Senator Abetz, that the atmosphere of mediation and negotiation is a very important one. It is different to the atmosphere one gets in litigation where you have advocates contesting each other. In the sphere of mediation you have an environment where things are said in a candid and forthright fashion in an effort to try to sort things out and different rules apply. When you are at that stage, it is on a without prejudice basis, so that what either party says to the other cannot be held against the other party. That is the environment which leads to possible resolution of disputes.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, if you cast upon the participants the same burdens or onus that exists in an environment of litigation or contest, then your mediation atmosphere flies out the window. You end up with people watching their own backs, more than keeping their eye on the goal of arriving at a resolution. That is one problem with this.

I can understand Senator Spindler's approach to this, and perhaps it is something the government could monitor. I ask the minister that this be done, that we look at how this whole new regime operates if we find people participating in mediation do complain that they have been let down and there is no avenue of redress against the mediators.

I do not normally say let's enact the law and see how it operates. I have always said in this chamber let's get it right in the first instance. But this is an example where we could introduce the measure and then ascertain how it works in the community without prejudice suffered to the community at large. So I do think it is an aspect that we can monitor and look at. For those two reasons, I support the comments of Senator Vanstone and Senator Abetz.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this point has really gone awry, to some extent. I would point out to Senator Abetz, Senator Ellison and Senator Vanstone that the Democrats are not suggesting that every mediator be denied immunity. We are perfectly happy that the bill would continue to provide immunity for a court mediator or a community mediator—a court mediator being a court appointed mediator and a community mediator being a mediator that is provided by an approved organisation for mediation.

PARA.TAB: What we are against is a free-for-all, for Joe Bloggs hanging up the shingle saying, `I am a mediator,' and taking people through a mediation process without the court or anybody else checking on his qualifications or accrediting that particular person in whichever way. We are not saying to the government, `Don't extend immunity to mediators'; we are saying, `Don't extend immunity until and unless you've got a system of accreditation in place so that the community can have some confidence that the mediators that are going to be functioning will provide a reasonable and a professional service.' That is really the point.

I would call on the coalition senators who have spoken to have another look at their position, because that is what we are saying. As long as there is a court mediator or a mediator from a community organisation appointed for the purpose, then that is fine because we at least have some sort of a check on whom they are and what their qualifications are. But it is foolhardy to extend immunity to someone who can simply say, `I am a mediator. I will practice as a mediator. I can do what I like because I've got total immunity.'

It is all very well for Senator Ellison to say, `Let's try it' but, in his support for that, he would be letting the community take the risk of that particular provision. It is saying, `Well, let's see. If there are too many cases where they foul it up and where they should have been sued for negligence, then we will change it.' But, meanwhile, who protects and compensates those people who, at a very traumatic stage in their lives, have been ill served by someone who is not adequately qualified and whose qualifications or experience have not been checked by anybody.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to support what Senator Spindler was saying in bringing the discussion around. The very statement that Senator Abetz made, which was, `Nobody would engage in private mediation if there were a possibility of being sued' is exactly the point. It is a difficult issue. But we have to have a balance between the absence of an accreditation system and a licence that is being provided by immunity to anybody to conduct mediation in a private capacity, which cannot be challenged.

PARA.TAB: The government, by having this in the law and extending that practice to anyone who is involved in it without having some kind of accreditation system and also, as I mentioned earlier, some kind of sessional payment basis to make that accessible to people, is actually doing a disservice to members of the community who may unwittingly be unaware that, when people do claim to have those skills and if they are not under supervision or under any kind of regulation mechanism, they are still immune from any possibility of being sued if they do not act in their clients' best interests.

It is an invidious situation. That is why the Greens are at the moment supporting the Democrats' amendments. We do not see the logic—as has been referred to by Senators Vanstone, Abetz and Ellison—in withholding immunity from private mediators and counsellors, provided that they have been accredited by the Family Court on the basis of skills and training. We agree that this would not prevent non-accredited persons mediating or counselling but we feel that such non-accredited private mediators and counsellors should not have immunity by this law. That is what we are giving them, and that is what Senator Spindler's amendment seeks to address.

I think it is one which our opposition colleagues should look at quite seriously, because the very reasons they oppose it are the very reasons why it is a useful amendment to have. It will try to ensure that a quality of care is available in the community. The fact that it is actually being so liberal in distributing the quality of immunity to people without any kind of responsibility being exercised actually goes against the principle of giving immunity. It should be given very carefully. It should be given in cases where it can be supported and not just given to anybody who has the capacity to take on that role in a self-appointed fashion. That is exactly the purpose of the Democrats' amendment, and I would urge opposition senators to reconsider it on the very logic that they have just espoused to the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I at this stage just handball and ask the minister if he can advise the committee as to what the immunity actually involves and entails. Does it include immunity from, for example, defamation proceedings?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I intervene and also ask the minister, whilst he is giving an answer to Senator Abetz, to indicate to the chamber precisely what this immunity means as it relates to the communications made at such a conference between husband and wife. For example, is that to be absolutely privileged? As I read it, 19N(2) says:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence of anything said, or any admission made, at a meeting or conference conducted by a person to whom this section applies while the person is acting as such a person is not admissible:
(a)in any court . . . or
(b)in any proceedings before a person authorised by a law of the Commonwealth or of a State or Territory, or by the consent of the parties, to hear evidence.

Admittedly, the section applies to a family and child counsellor; a court mediator; a community mediator or a private mediator; or a person nominated, or acting on behalf of an organisation nominated, for the purposes of paragraph 14. It does say that evidence of anything said or admissions made at a meeting shall not be admissible. That is giving absolute privilege to what may be said by husbands and wives in that particular conference. That is in contradistinction as to what might be said between husband and wife in their kitchen or in their lounge room, because that is not privileged. I believe it should be privileged, but it is not privileged.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I will contrast that with what is in the Evidence Act. Honourable senators will recall that I really wanted to have the parliament look again at the evidence legislation when it came before this chamber so as to allow spouses to retain marital privilege, but that did not occur. That bill, as honourable senators will remember, was rather rushed when it eventually came before the chamber, and it went through.

I believe that we have to look at all these implications—the implications of what we are discussing now—and the inconsistencies that are developing in law in respect of spousal privilege. I simply ask the minister: does this provision mean that there will be another level of treatment of statements made between husband and wife at such a conference, vis-a-vis statements made between husband and wife at any other time?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer, Senator Harradine, is very clearly, no. That is because the point you are addressing relates to the next set of amendments rather than these. The amendments before us at the moment do not raise the particular point that you raised. I could go to your point at this stage, pre-empting Senator Spindler moving the next set of amendments, or it might be best for me to defer consideration of that until the next set of amendments are put up.

PARA.TAB: Here, we are talking about the question of removing the immunity from suit for private mediators. Senator Abetz asked for me to give an account of how the law will operate. I will do that. I think it is worth putting on record that section 19M of the Family Law Act does provide that any approved mediator has the same protection and immunity as a judge of the Family Court. This means that the mediator, in performing the functions of a mediator, is protected from civil suits such as defamation, negligence and related matters such as breach of confidence. Under the bill, it is proposed to extend the immunity to all categories of mediators—to court mediators, to community mediators and to private mediators.

The proposed amendments of Senator Spindler's to section 19M would discriminate against private mediators by removing the immunity from this category of mediators. I must say in passing that if there is anything that would act against encouraging private mediators in this area, it would be this set of amendments together with the next set that Senator Spindler is to move. It is important that the immunity protection be extended to all categories of mediators, to facilitate the greater use of mediation to resolve family law disputes. It is a major plank of the bill, a plank to which Senator Vanstone, Senator Abetz and Senator Ellison have referred.

If immunity is not extended to private mediators, they may decline to take on family law mediation. This could lead to problems in accessing mediation for family law disputes. It could mean the shift to greater use of dispute resolution mechanisms is not able to be achieved. One of the fundamental objectives of the bill could be undermined.

Private mediation, we should keep in mind, would be subject to regulations. These regulations would provide for consumer protection requirements to be met. If met, the mediator would then be able to rely on confidentiality provisions in the bill, such as proposed section 19N. It provides that anything said during a mediation which is conducted in accordance with the regulations cannot be used in evidence in later proceedings, subject to an exception for domestic violence matters and for serious criminal offences. So the Democrats have moved an amendment with respect to this, and we will be getting to that aspect later.

Senator Ellison, I think it was, raised the question of monitoring how this part of the bill would operate. It is something the government is keen to do. We will ask the Family Services Council and the proposed ADR advisory council to examine the operation of the regulations to see, for instance, whether further consumer protection provisions such as the imposition of penalties or any other matters are necessary. We recognise that it is important to keep an eye on this area but, reflecting what others have said earlier, if this amendment is carried one of the major objectives of the bill could be undermined. I hope, Senator Abetz, I have placed on record the information you requested.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful that this discussion has clarified the very limited nature of our amendment. We are not trying to remove immunity for court mediators or community mediators—in other words, mediators that are offered to the public by voluntary organisations as well as by the courts. The minister really confirmed what I said before and that is that, under these provisions, anybody can put out a shingle and say, `I'm a mediator.' The government is prepared to extend total immunity to those people.

PARA.TAB: The minister is saying that there will be other provisions under consumer protection legislation. That is fine and I welcome those. If those provisions were on the table maybe that would change our view. It is possible that they would offer adequate protection. However, they are not on the table for us to consider. The government has not offered us any protections. They are certainly not in this bill or in the main bill.

I would have thought that the time for us to retreat from this amendment is at a later date when the government has provided the details of the consumer protection legislation, the accreditation schemes or the supervision of mediator provisions it is prepared to put in place. If those regimes were put in place we would be happy to support an amendment by the government to knock off this amendment, which I hope will be passed. I hope the coalition will reconsider its position.

What the government proposes to do is let loose on the community people who are not qualified. Certainly their qualifications will not be checked. Anybody can do this and you are prepared to extend total immunity to them. I really fail to see the logic of that argument. I do not believe that the Senate should pass legislation which places the risks associated with this procedure entirely on the consumers who are going through a very traumatic stage in their lives.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Spindler is exaggerating the situation enormously by saying that what we are doing here is allowing anyone to put up a shingle—
—You are. What is the bar to it?

—If you listen you might learn something. If you had been listening earlier then maybe you would not have made the contribution you just made. What we have said is that the immunity applies in situations where people conform to the regulations. In relation to drafting the regulations, it should be recognised that the government has already issued a discussion paper on aspects of accountability, consumer protection and so on. That discussion paper has been distributed for comment to over 400 relevant professional, community and interested groups.

PARA.TAB: That paper contains draft proposals governing the regulations that would provide the sorts of consumer protections and standards you are concerned about. Those regulations have to come back for stamping through this place so you will have an opportunity to scrutinise them to see what sorts of provisions would be put in place. It is not as simple as saying that it is a matter of people putting up their shingles. People will have to conform with the standards before they get the immunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has asked me to listen and has suggested that I should have listened earlier. I did, but I did not hear him spell out any of the regulations that the government is drafting. I know that a discussion paper has been released to the public, but I believe the regulations should be spelt out here. I ask the minister to give us some of the main provisions that those regulations will contain so that senators have some concept of what the government is intending to do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had been listening to my colleague Senator Schacht you would have heard what I just put on the record in terms of the discussion paper. We can do better than just give you an idea of what some of the regulations are—we will make the discussion paper available to interested senators, including Senator Chamarette, Senator Harradine, Senator Abetz, Senator Ellison and you. We will do that and obviously welcome your input.

—Just in case I have not understood the implications of this—as the minister has implied—from what professional training backgrounds are the people who may be in a position of being in a private capacity and conducting mediation which is being covered by the immunity provisions of this bill likely to come? Are they likely to be only lawyers, who may already be covered by it, or are they going to be social workers, psychologists, non-government agency trained people, physiotherapists, occupational therapists or people who do not have to comply with professional codes of conduct? I would just like to know whether there are any restrictions that apply to this or whether it simply relates to the work they are engaged in at the point in time when this provision will provide them coverage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —One point worth putting on the record is that at the time of providing the service and beforehand they would have to make known what their professional qualifications are. They will not be limited to legal qualifications. They could be all those qualifications that you mentioned.
—Clergy, I forgot clergy.

—Clergy could come within the category as well. But the important thing is for people to know what the background experience and qualifications are of a very diverse range of people who would put themselves forward to provide the service. Senator, I am sure you would also appreciate that co-mediation is important as well, so sometimes you would have a mix of qualified people providing it. That will also be accommodated for.

—I thank the minister for his answer because it did reassure me that I had a proper understanding of the breadth of the immunity that is being covered in this bill. The aspect I want to ask about is: at what point will people become aware that the service that is being provided is subject to immunity and that material that is raised in discussion cannot be used?

PARA.TAB: On the basis of this provision, or on what the minister just said, it really means that providing they have said to the people what their professional background is, providing they have engaged in this particular activity of co-mediation or mediation, they will have that immunity. How will a client know that that exists, apart from the fact that everybody has blanket cover? How will they know the people for whom it would not be possible to claim it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —This, of course, will be defined clearly in the regulations, but the government's objective is to ensure that people know what the qualifications are before the service is provided at the intake level. So before you actually get the service provided to you there would be some capacity for people to be alerted to the qualifications of the mediator or the person providing the service. As I say, this is part of the discussion paper and any input you might have in terms of that would be listened to.

—I believe that it is important that the private mediators be given immunity, especially in relation to such things as defamation and not only in relation to whether they might act in a professionally negligent way. With respect, even those of us who do have qualifications behind our name or might be registered do make mistakes and errors of judgment. I would imagine that anybody who has practised in the area of family law has undoubtedly made mistakes, although they were very well intentioned.

PARA.TAB: I recall a conciliation conference, or a registrar's conference, where it was suggested by the registrar, all well meaning, that undoubtedly a court would make a certain determination on the matter. My own view was that the registrar was right so I advised my client accordingly and she wisely said, `No, take it to court,' and we won. My view and the registrar's view were in fact wrong in the view of the judge. Just because somebody has the imprimatur of being a professional in a particular area, even with all the best will in the world, errors will still be made.

I do not think you can say that just because you have that piece of paper you are going to be better. It will mean that there is a less likelihood of a mistake occurring. It is worthwhile to keep in mind that people who will embark on mediation activities will do so with the best will in the world and with the hope of assisting couples who are genuinely interested in coming to a resolution of the outstanding differences between them. I ask if the minister can indicate when the regulations are to be promulgated and whether assent to this bill will be deferred until such time as the regulations are fully in place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the regulations will be in place at the time when the bill has an operation date. They will come into effect together.

—In my past life as a practising clinical psychologist I often viewed the immunity coverage of lawyers with great envy. It is absolutely amazing to me that we have three members of the legal profession who are so kindly giving this away in the interests of people having access to counselling. Within my own profession we were aware of concerns about people who were able to take on that role. We believed that there should be some provisions covering that area.

PARA.TAB: It is an extraordinary state of affairs. I should be supporting the government's willingness to extend this coverage to people like myself and other professionals. In the past we would not have dreamed of gaining this coverage. However, I am opposing it. Ironically, the lawyers, whom I often found were so jealous in guarding it, are generously giving it away.

I urge the coalition to rethink the situation and consider supporting the amendment on the basis that, in the time it takes to go back to the House of Representatives and be checked, they might have time to ascertain whether they are in error in supporting it. If the amendment does not succeed, I want to place on the public record that I believe that the government—and the coalition in supporting the government—is trying to do the right thing. The government is trying to make mediation accessible. However, what it is doing is protecting the mediators without necessarily thinking through the protection of the people who are trying to get access to this help.

Members of the community will be unaware, until after the fact, that the people they are seeking may or may not fall within the cover of the immunity provisions. It could be disadvantageous that the government has not set up a proper accreditation scheme to which the immunity provision can be connected and more logically linked. That is the position I am supporting. It is the point of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might briefly reply to the allegation that the argument I put forward earlier was to `try it and see': that is, using it as a social experiment and then tailoring the legislation after one sees how it goes. I think the government has sufficiently outlined the safeguards for the community in ensuring that these mediation organisations will be appropriate and will be qualified. They have to be approved by the minister.

PARA.TAB: The new section 13C states that certain standards must be met by any such organisation. The minister has said that, prior to the enactment of the bill, these regulations dealing with the whole process of accreditation will be in place. We are not unleashing unqualified people on the community. We are not unleashing on the community any social experiment which could perhaps go drastically wrong and cause great social damage. I do not believe that it is in that context at all.

I believe the government has indicated in the first instance sufficient safeguards in relation to this whole question of mediation, both to the mediators themselves and to the community at large, that are quite balanced. Therefore, I think that any argument that this might be some sort of social experiment—that we look at it and see how it goes—is unfounded. I think there are adequate safeguards here for the community. I take on board the minister's comments, and welcome them, that this aspect of mediation will be monitored by the government, and monitored continuously.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to what Senator Ellison has just put on the record, I would like to ask the minister to refer the committee to any section in the bill which actually says that private mediators, as distinct from court or community mediators, have to be approved in any way.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are asking a question to which you know the answer already. The whole structure of the bill is such that they do not have to be approved. We made this clear earlier. We have said that regulations are in place and that immunity depends on conformity with the standards reflected in the regulations and so on. I do not know why you are asking this question—you know the answer.

—Thank you, Minister. I just wanted Senator Ellison to have the benefit of your answer, because it sounded as though Senator Ellison believed that the private mediators are to be approved. And that is not the case.
—As I understand it, the question of the approval of any organisation would entail the question of the mediators it thereby employs. For instance, if one looked at a church group which had—
—They are the community ones, Senator; not the private mediators.
—You're talking about community organisations and he is talking about private ones.
—Perhaps if we look at just the private mediators, I ask the minister: would private mediators be covered in any way by the regulations that we have been talking about?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, they would. That is exactly what we have been talking about. I think earlier on—and without checking the Hansard record, I cannot be a final arbiter on this—one person was talking about private people and another was referring to the operation of the act on community-based organisations. There is a difference in the approach in the act to one and to the other. That, I think, has been the essence of the dispute between both of you.
—But as I understand it, the regulations will cover private mediators as well and thereby offer safeguards in relation to the private mediators. That is, as I understand it, the position.
—That is right.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 9.Clause 26, page 15, proposed subsection 19N(2), at the end, add "except for the purposes of proving negligence, professional misconduct or unlawful behaviour by such a person".

This amendment deals with the admissions made to counsellors and mediators and whether or not they may be used in subsequent court proceedings. My amendment would exclude the prohibition on the admissibility in court of information raised in the course of mediation, arbitration and counselling if it is in connection with the right to sue a mediator or counsellor for negligence, professional misconduct or unlawful behaviour.

PARA.TAB: I expect that, in view of the debate we have just had, this amendment is unlikely to pass. But when we look at the words `negligence, professional misconduct or unlawful behaviour', we should be aware of the gravity of the situation that members of the community may find themselves in.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government essentially opposes this amendment for much the same reasons as the ones that have already been discussed in relation to the earlier amendment. At this stage I will answer the point that Senator Harradine's raised earlier. He linked the issue of the confidentiality of discussions between husbands and wives before counsellors with the issue of admissibility in evidence of other discussions or communications between husbands and wives. Whether discussions between husbands and wives would be admissible in evidence will depend on the application of the rules of evidence in proceedings before the Family Court. They are set out in the Evidence Act. There has been some discussion of them in deliberations on this bill.

PARA.TAB: A related issue is whether a husband or wife can compel his or her spouse to give evidence of a communication made between them during their marriage. Section 100 of the Family Law Act provides that parties to a marriage are competent and compellable to disclose such communication. There is here a fundamental difference between the confidentiality provisions in the act relating to discussions before counsellors and the compellability of spouses to disclose marital communications in family law proceedings.

In respect of the former, the confidentiality provisions encourage candour and frankness during the conciliation stages of court proceedings. Without such provisions, subsequent court proceedings would be able to traverse matters discussed and statements made during conciliation conferences. One can very readily understand the impact of this. The compellability of spouses prevents, once conciliation efforts have not secured the settlement of Family Court proceedings, one spouse being able to frustrate the presentation of the case of the other by refusing to give evidence of statements made to each other during the marriage.

It is worth placing on notice for the Senate that this compellability aspect of evidence law has been Commonwealth policy for over 30 years. It is reflected in section 100 of the Family Law Act, and it reflects the pre-existing provisions of subsection 97(3) of the now repealed Matrimonial Causes Act 1959. So for a long time this compellability question has been reflected in that legislation. The confidentiality of provisions in respect of proceedings before counsellors is quite different from that. Having said that, the government feels that the Democrats amendments would, in essence, frustrate the private counselling and mediation service in a way that we do not accept.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I can understand the question of negligence and professional misconduct relating to immunity, the question of unlawful behaviour gives rise to this question: under the proposed immunity intended by the government, would such unlawful behaviour include a criminal act by the person concerned? If a mediator was guilty of unlawful behaviour by, for instance, an act of duress, or the mediator had a relationship with one party and committed some criminal act in dealing with another party, would that immunity exclude what was said in the process of mediation from being used in any prosecution?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The immunity does not cover the conduct which is referred to in proposed new section 67ZA of the bill. That proposed new section provides an exemption for notification of matters such as suspected child abuse, risk of abuse, ill-treatment or anything which might cause psychological damage to the child; that is one important category. Another important category is the general common law exemption for evidence of serious criminal offences. My advice is that that general common law exemption would also not be overridden by the operation of this bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 10.Clause 31, page 27, proposed section 62B, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(4) For the purposes of any consideration under subsection (2) or (3), the court or the legal practitioner, as the case may be, must take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.".

SPEECH.PARA: 11.Clause 31, page 27, proposed section 62C, at the end, add the following subsection:
"(3) For the purposes of arranging an interview under subsection (2) the person making the arrangement must, as far as possible, take the following matters into account:

TAB.TAB: (a)the degree of equality (or otherwise) in bargaining power of the parties;
(b)the risk of child abuse (if any);
(c)the risk of family violence (if any);
(d)the emotional and psychological state of the parties;
(e)whether one of the parties may be seeking to use a primary dispute resolution method to delay proceedings or for some other advantage;
(f)any other relevant matter.''.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments are similar to amendments that I have moved earlier in this chamber and relate to the requirement to take account of the degree of equality or otherwise in the bargaining power of parties, the risk of child abuse, the risk of family violence and so on when arrangements are under consideration for interviews and for other meetings that are to be arranged by legal practitioners, mediators and counsellors.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 31, page 30, omit proposed section 63D, substitute the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Registration in a court

SPEECH.PARA: "63D.(1) A parenting plan may be registered in a court having jurisdiction under this
Part if:

PARA.TAB: (a)it is signed by the parties; and

(b)the copy of the plan submitted for registration is accompanied by a statement, in relation to each party, that is to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the legal practitioner who provided that advice; and
(c)the court is satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child.

SPEECH.PARA: "(2) In determining whether the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child, the court may, but is not required to, have regard to all or any of the matters set out in subsection 68F(2).
"(3) The Rules of Court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court.".

The amendment circulated in my name to clause 31 on page 30 is to admit a proposed section 63D and substitute the following section. There are basically two things that we seek to achieve in this respect. The first is that when any parenting plan is going to be registered by the court it will be signed by the parties; a copy of the plan will be submitted for registration and accompanied by a statement in relation to each party to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan; it will be signed by the legal practitioner who provided that advice; and, lastly, the court is to be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the government is not disposed towards being supportive of this amendment. This would mean that an amendment that Senator Spindler has worked quite assiduously to encourage us to accept would no longer be relevant. But what is important is that the Democrats and we agree on these two things: that it is important that the parties receive independent legal advice, and there are competing arguments in this respect—Minister, why are you frowning?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a big gap in your argument.
—I haven't even started on it.
—It is pretty evident already so it must be—

—The importance of both parties receiving advice is this: it is well understood by anyone with an interest in family law matters that it is frequently the case that one party comes to any negotiations in a much weaker position than others, and I know that even the minister would not disagree with that. We are certainly of the view that if parties, husband and wife who are now separating and divorcing, want to come to their own arrangements and do not want to have any association with the Family Court, fine, they can come to their own arrangements and make whatever plans they want with respect to their parenting. But, once they come and want the imprimatur in any way of the court, and there are any consequences that flow from registration, then it is important that each of those parties have independent advice as to the consequences of what they are doing.

PARA.TAB: If, Minister, you want to make a case when we come back to this matter this afternoon that there are no consequences at all from the registration of a plan, you might convince people to think differently, but if you say there are no consequences in the registration of a plan it raises this question: why do you bother to do it in the first place? So I will be interested in the arguments that the minister will be putting forward in that respect.

It is important that each party gets independent advice. The party who comes to the negotiations in a weaker position may well, for a whole variety of reasons, agree to a plan that subsequently they want to undo with all the consequent difficulties. I understand the argument that says, `Look, when parents are agreeing we should let them agree and not have the bureaucracy or the court interfering'—and that is right. But it is not the court that is stretching its arm out here and saying, `If you come to some agreement you must come and register it with us'; it is people who want to avail themselves of the court and register their plan. On that basis I think it is fair enough to say, `Look, each party should have separate advice; one is definitely going to be stronger than the other, and it is important that both parties at the time of agreeing to that plan understand the consequences of what they are doing'.

The analogy has been drawn by a number of people between parenting plans being registered and consent orders. Amendment 63D(1)(c) combined with 63D(1) and (2), as I am advised, will put the registration of these plans and the court's consideration thereof in the same category as consent orders. There is some difficulty in saying that a Family Court which obviously has the interests of the children at heart will simply register a plan without even having the slightest interest in the contents thereof, that a plan could be registered by two weirdos, or one weirdo and a weaker party who was an absolute disaster, and the court would in any event just register it. The court has to have some interest in this matter, otherwise why is its name being lent to the plan by virtue of its registration?

They are the matters, Minister, I would be happy for you to give some indication of the government's view on. I might also flag that, while I understand the government is not going to agree with this amendment, it has been put together with some advice and/or assistance from them. But, Minister, I think you must acknowledge that, of the proposals put forward, you prefer this one to the Democrat one. I would be grateful for your advice in that respect. It is certainly what I understand to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Vanstone, I am not quite sure why we are dealing with this amendment out of order, because I was dealing with amendments 11 and 12 and we have jumped to Democrat amendment No. 25. However, be that as it may, the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone is identical to the first part of the Democrats' amendment in that it requires that a parenting plan should be signed by the parties; the copy of the plan should be accompanied by a statement certifying that each of them has had independent legal advice; and the court should be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child.

PARA.TAB: I am grateful to Senator Vanstone for putting such an eloquent and erudite argument in favour of these provisions, because it is quite clear that this is a very basic, major issue. Should we treat children as chattels? Should we allow parents to make arrangements without the court or anyone else really assessing whether the prime purpose of the Family Law Act—namely, that it should operate to preserve and promote the best interests of the child as a priority—has been taken care of in that particular aarrangement or agreement?

This is why the Democrats put forward that amendment. In discussing it with Senator Vanstone, as she said, she basically agreed with that, but is suggesting an additional subsection which says that the court may, but is not required to, have regard to all or any of the matters set out in subsection 68F(2). That is a slight softening of the provision; it does not lock the court into a lengthy proceeding and I am certainly prepared to accept that—I think it is useful.

Finally, subsection (3), the other section that Senator Vanstone is adding, says that the rules of the court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court. That also is useful. There has been quite a lot of discussion about how the court can best handle this. Suggestions were made of devising checklists which perhaps the registrar can deal with at first instance, and only when the registrar is unhappy after a fairly automatic check of a checklist is it brought to the attention of the court as a whole.

That provision too, as a machinery provision, promotes the acceptance of the basic principle that the court has a responsibility to ensure that the interests of the child are at all times given priority and are safeguarded by the court. We should not allow the court or the government to say, `We will not take account of that responsibility. We will allow people to make whatever arrangements they wish and we are prepared to stamp it with a court's approval, as it were, by registering it.'

I know that people say that the court will become involved if one of the parties comes back to the court and says, `The other party is not performing. We want to enforce it.' But the reality is that most people will not do that. They take the view that an agreement has been made, the court has stamped it, it is a semi-official document and, `We will not disturb it', unless the circumstances are very extreme indeed. It seems to us that that precaution should be taken not when there is a complete breakdown of the agreement, but when the court is asked to rubber stamp it and to say, `This is an enforceable agreement.'
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the matter of the University of Queensland's move to take over Bond University. This is anything but simply a straightforward matter of national educational policy, crucial though that is. At the heart of the matter is not only educational policy but also the issue of the behaviour of foreign investors in this country. Looming in that is possible unlawful behaviour and even criminal activities.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee now has a specific reference on Bond University for early examination and report. The immediate concern of that reference is the proposed major shift in the way in which higher education is offered in Australia. That issue cannot be allowed to go by default. Any move to allow public universities to operate or in any way become involved in private universities must be a compromise of the traditional charter of free, secular and public education which has existed in Australia for decades.

My purpose is to go wider—to look at the agendas of foreign investors and their agents which have generated the present takeover. I think we neglect at our peril what these reveal. Until these aspects have been thoroughly examined and the work of the Senate committee concluded, I believe that, out of respect for Australia's national interests, neither the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan nor the University of Queensland should seek to proceed to finality and, indeed, should not be permitted to do so.

I note reports that the university has tendered $109 million for the land and buildings of the Bond University project and has taken the Delfin Property Group to develop the land which is surplus to university requirements. The University of Queensland is reported as regarding its projected investment in Bond University and its operation of Bond University as being outside the public purview. It needs to be said that there is simply no money, nor are there any assets, under the control of the University of Queensland which do not belong to the public register. It is simply nonsense to say, as has been reported in the media, that public funds are not involved.

The reports suggest that the university will still have to find about $80 million for the campus segment. At current market rates such a borrowing would mean an annual interest bill of over $8 million. Since start-up in 1989, Bond University's recurrent accounts show a series of heavy losses, even though the university paid nothing towards its establishment nor any annual charge in respect of the land and buildings it occupies. The short-term gain from the cost cutting in which Bond has recently engaged may be at the expense of long-term viability and therefore merely costs deferred. Bond is massively in debt—some $94 million—though this debt has been subordinated and is no immediate burden.

Bond's 1994 company returns, having this somewhat unreal basis, show an operating `profit' of some $6.4 million. But allowance needs to be made for the recurrent costs—rates and the like—on the land and buildings now met by the Japanese companies in receivership. These may be as much as $3 million per annum. This would mean only $3.4 million per annum towards interest charges of over $8 million. This makes no allowance for the impact of additional costs for additional infrastructure, nor does it make any allowance for diminution in student numbers which might follow a change in the character of the university.

It would seem to an observer from the sidelines that the University of Queensland is heading itself into a difficult financial situation with real risk of being forced back on the public purse. That, of course, is something the government has said emphatically it will not accept. However, if one turns to the wider context, it is not difficult to sense how this financial backdrop has come about, how Bond University has come to this difficult juncture.

Bond University is a surprising creation—a singular and atypical flowering out of the entrepreneurial excesses and misdeeds of the 1980s. Its unlikely genesis was as a land development catalyst created by two notable corporate high-fliers of that time, Mr Alan Bond and Mr Harunori Takahashi. Mr Bond became bankrupt and served time in prison; Mr Takahashi did not face any bankruptcy process but is now embroiled in criminal indictment in Tokyo for breach of trust and fraud.

By January 1991, the game was up for the Australian Bond Corporation. It also appeared to be up for Japan's EIE International—Mr Takahashi's vehicle. The Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, as EIE's leading creditor, had moved in its own officers and taken charge of EIE's small headquarters in Tokyo and thence its huge operations elsewhere. Curiously, the bank seems to have left Mr Takahashi to go about freely—his lifestyle not much disrupted. Mr Bond's creditors were less kind.

The true relationship of Mr Takahashi and his EIE corporation with the Long Term Credit Bank is a matter of some conjecture. Certainly it is a curious relationship for a bank, given Mr Takahashi's meteoric rise from relative obscurity and his incredible appetite for borrowings for grandiose risky investments. Mr Takahashi is rumoured to have some family connections with senior officials of the bank. Whatever of that, such were his powers of persuasion with the Long Term Credit Bank that his Australian subsidiary, EIE Australia, alone accumulated debts to the bank of around $1 billion.

I find it astounding that, despite the publicised bankrupt state of EIE International and the known fact of the Japanese bank's officers controlling its operations, our Foreign Investment Review Board gave approval for EIE Australia to purchase the Australian half-share of the Bond project partnership. This is the more remarkable since at that time, December 1991, an Australian group—and I understand one of the recent contenders for Bond University—was actively seeking to buy these assets. This was known to the bank's officers. The administration of Bond Corporation had wished to sell to the Australian group but the Japanese partner, by then the Long Term Credit Bank, withheld agreement. It is to be noted here that EIE and Mr Takahashi had come under regulatory scrutiny by the Tokyo stock exchange and the Japanese ministry of finance as far back as 1989.

The parliament and the Australian community deserve to be told why the Foreign Investment Review Board gave such an approval and on what representations and documentation. The Long Term Credit Bank action which followed is even more bizarre. The agents of the bank, for it was the bank calling the shots, acted in a brutal fashion to force out of office the independent members of the Bond University governance, on the university company and the council, and to replace them with the bank's nominees. Whether all requirements of the Queensland act and the memorandum and articles were met in this case is another question. I think it outrageous that a private Australian university, operating independently under an act of the Queensland parliament, could have been thus treated by a large and reputable Japanese bank—one of Japan's most prestigious.

Having busied itself with the new governance of Bond over the next 18 months, the bank suddenly changed tack. In Japan at that point, the bank reportedly walked away from EIE International—though, curiously, EIE is still trading. It has been alleged that the bank has continued to be involved and to support the company through the back door. The latest Australian Securities Commission return for EIE Australia—for 1994, but signed in Tokyo by Mr Takahashi in May this year—shows known bank people as directors: Mr Ogawa and Mr Yaginuma. The unfortunate young Mr Yaginuma suicided in January 1994 in ominous circumstances.

What we can say with certainty is that in August 1993 the bank put into receivership the EIE Australia subsidiaries Limgold, Nista and Jadekent, which held the land and buildings of the Bond University project. The bank did not put EIE Australia into receivership even though that company was massively in its debt. Nor did the bank attempt to put the Bond University company into receivership. It seems that the bank was inhibited by a subordination deed drawn in May 1990 between Limgold and the university company. The terms of that deed made virtually worthless the bank's security of the university debt of nearly $100 million. Spice is added here by the fact that the Japanese subsidiary Limgold and the university company—the authors of the deed—had, and continued to have, certain common directors, including Mr Takahashi.

I would have thought that the Australian Securities Commission would be interested and have a responsibility to be interested in this whole saga. After receivers were appointed to the Japanese subsidiaries in August 1993, the nature and active personnel of the governance of Bond University appear to have changed. According to a Queensland Supreme Court writ lodged on 28 September 1995 by the Bond University company, its board members ceased after August to be agents of the Japanese defendant, the EIE subsidiary, Limgold.

The 1994 company returns for Bond University Ltd mention Japanese directors—Mr Oba; Mr Lievre, as alternate for Mr Oba; and the inevitable Mr Takahashi—as directors when the 1994 returns were lodged; namely, on 22 September 1995. These are the directors of Bond University Ltd, along with Messrs Wran and Turnbull, and Professors Messel and Farrar. This is the company which is negotiating with the University of Queensland for the takeover of Bond University. Excepting Professor Farrar, all these were directors at the time of the changeover in August 1993, as was a further Japanese director—the unfortunate Mr Yaginuma. Mr Takahashi, as it happened, did not attend any board meetings in 1994. He had his own problems in Tokyo.

How, in the light of all this, one should assess the standing of members of the present governance of the Bond University company and the university council is a question to be answered. What relationship, if any, has remained between the Long Term Credit Bank and the directors, including the Australian directors Messrs Wran and Turnbull, who were previously its agents? What process has been invoked to change the earlier relationship?

I understand the Long Term Credit Bank is in some trouble in Japan. I am not surprised. Press reports say that Japan's financial system is in serious crisis. Having regard to the activities of the Long Term Credit Bank in Australia, I would think the Australian government ought to take a close look at what is happening in Japan and what the implications may be for Australia. I will not dwell on the sale process of the land and buildings of the Bond University project, nor will I go further afield to say anything about the other great arm of Mr Takahashi in Australia—Sanctuary Cove development. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a diagram showing, with some explanatory detail, EIE's company structure in Australia.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: [DOCUMENT OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 2465]

TALK.START.PARA: —I do say, however, that the process of the sale of the Bond project land and buildings has not diminished the bizarre quality of the whole saga. To mention just one aspect of the sale, there is a bid from the present governance of the Bond University company—whatever be the standing of that governance. It is a bid to buy the assets from the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan when the Bond University company is massively in debt to the bank, when the bank's nominees are seemingly on the board of the university company, and when that company has directors in common with the companies in receivership. In this whole matter there is a smell—a smell wafting all the way from the Gold Coast to Tokyo. In Australia's interests, the air needs to be cleared. It can be cleared by a thorough inquiry and prompt, resolute government action. There is certainly a case for Australian regulatory authorities to be called to account.

PARA.TAB: I conclude by observing that the federal Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) only last week sounded an ominous note. Speaking on the Gold Coast he said that since 1991 the Japanese government has been trying to crack down on the Yakuza crime gangs. Mr Kerr is reported as citing intelligence reports to say that at least 28 Yakuza and associates from seven major gangs travelled to this country on at least 65 occasions between 1989 and 1993. How many have visited Australia during 1994 and 1995?.

Anybody who knows anything about Yakuza crime gangs knows they do not stop. They are in a class apart. Their connections go deep in Japanese society and Japanese business enterprise. Is the government expecting Australians to believe that none of the Yakuza had any association with Mr Takahashi or with his Australian operations? Huge amounts of money were flowing, who knows where. The whole record bristles with curious behaviour.

I have previously spoken about the Yakuza on the Gold Coast. On 26 November 1992, I spoke about it from the document prepared by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. I refer to page 3728 of the Hansard. The takeover of Bond University by the University of Queensland does not start with a clean slate. The takeover and the whole surround from whence it derives demand close government scrutiny from many perspectives. The government has the power to act. Where does it stand on these critical matters?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have given considerable thought about whether I should mention the matter which I intend to canvass today. Perhaps I should have let the matter rest in the hope that the occurrence, which I shall outline, does not occur again. Because the matter is an internationally sensitive one, I was tempted to remain silent. On balance, however, I do not believe that I can. I trust that the authorities in the Royal Thai Embassy in Canberra will understand why I have raised the matter and I trust that senior authorities in Thailand will similarly understand my reason for speaking today.

PARA.TAB: My main purpose in speaking is to make a plea to the media in Australia. That plea is for them to become more aware of the customs, traditions and general way of life of our Asian neighbours. The plea, however, goes further. Having become aware of our neighbours' customs, let us all—and my plea is principally to Australia's media—respect the way of life in those countries and not act in a way which is likely to offend. This should be a normal courtesy, but there is an overriding national concern: if we are to be accepted by Asian countries as a nation worthy of their respect, we must extend our respect to them. We should acknowledge that we have customs which are different from those which prevail in other countries and that many of our customs may be regarded as strange by our Asian neighbours. Just as we would hope that our way of life is respected so, too, do our neighbours expect that we will show respect to them.

Many honourable senators would be aware of my interest in the welfare of Australian citizens who are held in overseas prisons. My interest was aroused when I was approached by two Queensland constituents whose daughter was imprisoned in Thailand. Before I visited this lady in prison, I must admit that I was thinking of her welfare alone. Within minutes of entering the prison, I realised that the issue was far wider than I had thought. There were, at that time, four Australian women in that prison and I later became aware of Australian men who were imprisoned in the same city, two of whom I visited in two separate prisons. I have since had contact with other parents and friends whose loved ones are imprisoned in the same country and other countries.

Because Australia has not established a transfer scheme for international prisoners, the only way prisoners in Thailand can return to Australia is to complete their sentence or receive a royal pardon. Such a pardon is not royal in name only. It is very much a pardon which is granted by His Majesty the King of Thailand.

The negotiations to secure a royal pardon for my constituent's daughter—whom I shall refer to as Mary Smith from now on to respect her privacy—took a long time. This is understandable, because the King would have to be absolutely certain that a pardon is deserved before one is granted.

Towards the end of last year, negotiations in relation to Mary Smith were at a crucial and delicate stage. I was dismayed when an officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade told me that an offensive cartoon had appeared in the Age newspaper, accompanying the story about the release of two Australians who had received a royal pardon. The Tandberg cartoon may have been regarded as clever by Mr Tandberg and the Age, but it was, in fact, offensive to the Thais. It mocked the King of Thailand, something the Thais would never do. The King is held in great esteem in Thailand and any insult to the King is a very serious offence. I could understand the Thais' displeasure and I believe an officer from the Australian embassy in Bangkok was officially informed of this displeasure. I knew immediately that the publication of this cartoon would make the negotiations for Miss Smith's release more difficult.

In January of this year, I visited Bangkok once again to assess progress on Miss Smith's application for a royal pardon. I was granted a second audience at the Royal Palace with the King's principal private secretary. In the course of our conversation the Age cartoon was mentioned by the principal private secretary, and it was clear that the Thais had taken the matter quite seriously. I could well understand their deep concern.
I would like to read from parts of the records which I made after my visit to the palace. Again I refer to the Australian prisoner as Mary Smith, although that is not her real name:

SPEECH.PARA: The Principal Private Secretary raised the matter of the "Age" cartoon which the Thais regarded as offensive. I indicated that I, too, was disturbed, but outlined that we do not control the press and considered that nothing would be gained by speaking to the newspaper concerned. I stated that Mary Smith wanted no publicity and I would do what I could to see that nothing adverse would appear on her release. He said he appreciated that and would pass it on to the King.
The cable which was drafted and sent to Australia by the embassy officer who had accompanied me was perhaps a little more expansive. In part it read as follows:

The Principal Private Secretary raised his concern over a newspaper report about a recent Royal Pardon granted to an Australian prisoner jailed on drug trafficking charges. He said the media article had embarrassed the Thai authorities concerned. The Principal Private Secretary appeared to be signalling his concern about the possibility that such an embarrassing situation could happen again, should a Royal Pardon be granted to Smith, who was convicted on similar charges. Senator Colston indicated that he, too, had been embarrassed by the press coverage and had considered writing to the newspaper concerned. He had rejected this idea, however, fearing that such a letter could lead to an escalation of the matter. Senator Colston stated that the Australia press is not subject to direction by the government. He expressed his confidence that the Smiths would not provide any comment to the media, should Ms Smith be granted a Royal Pardon. ML Thawisan said that he would advise His Majesty the King accordingly.
When Miss Smith returned to Australia in July, there was so much media interest in her case that it was necessary to make a statement to the media. The statement issued by the Smiths read as follows:
We are extremely grateful to His Majesty King Bhumibol Adulyadej for granting a Royal Pardon and allowing us to resume a normal family life.
Other than that, we will be making no further comments to media representatives and we believe that at this time our privacy should be respected

The message which I wish to convey is that we should totally respect the cultural differences between ourselves and other countries. We can do this only if we make an effort to understand those differences. It is in this regard that I make a plea to the media to gain this understanding and be aware of the respect which should be afforded to our neighbours.

PARA.TAB: I had hoped that the offensive cartoon would eventually be regarded as an unfortunate incident in the past. But I was not counting on the abject insensitivity of the Courier-Mail. Running a story earlier this month about the Thais' refusal to grant visas to two Australian journalists, the Courier-Mail reproduced the offensive cartoon. I just do not know how insensitive some people in a responsible position can be and, if I were a prisoner in a Thai prison, especially if I had applied for a royal pardon, I would be extremely angry at the Courier-Mail's failure to understand the Thais' justifiable offence at the cartoon. I would realise that my application for a pardon would be considered against a background of the further offending reference to His Majesty the King. I sincerely express my embarrassment as an Australian to the Thai authorities over the Courier-Mail's actions. I hope that the Thais will understand that the press in this country is not subject to government direction.

It is obvious that some sections of our media need to devote more time to understand the way of life of our geographic neighbours. If they do that and, having understood, I would hope that they do not act as cultural philistines but, rather, respect our neighbours to the north. The Australian media has a powerful influence within our country. However, its influence extends beyond our shores and, properly used, it can cement good relations with other nations. If, in the future, any media representatives are tempted to show how clever they are by lampooning some aspect of another nation's culture, I would hope that they would think of the possible consequences and extend the same courtesy as we would expect from others.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is well known that this country is one of the great migrant countries of the world. People have come to this nation from far and wide to receive the benefits that Australia has to offer. They come here because they recognise that this country is better than the country which they have chosen to leave. Yet it alarms me that there are people who propose to change one of the fundamental strengths of this nation—to change its constitutional arrangements. In so doing, I believe that we run the risk of lessening one of the great democracies of this world. The problem is this: those who propose change, who wish to bring about a republic in this nation, arm themselves with arguments which are weak in comparison to the reasons why this nation has enjoyed so much stability and peace.

PARA.TAB: Let me run through for honourable senators the arguments which have been proposed by those who support a republic in these shores. The arguments can basically be boiled down to three. The first is that they believe that Australia should have an Australian head of state. The second reason they espouse is that we should become a republic to become more like our neighbours in Asia. The third reason which is advanced is that we should somehow become a republic because the current constitutional arrangements are irrelevant to a nation of increasingly ethnic diverse population.

Let me deal with each of those three points in order. The fact is that we do have an Australian head of state—an Australian head of state both in title and in effect. The constitution of this nation says very clearly that the Queen is the head of state as Queen of Australia. In fact, it is interesting that that title, the style of that title, was conferred on the Queen by an act of parliament under a Labor government. It was not under a coalition government but under a Labor government—in fact, under the Labor government of the Hon. Gough Whitlam.

The Queen is Queen of Australia and, as Queen of Australia, she is not queen of any other nation. We are not beholden to Westminster, to the UK, to whatever might happen in the House of Commons.
