The destiny of this nation is determined here, in this place, in this parliament. Those who say that our current constitutional arrangements show that we are not a truly sovereign and independent nation do an injustice to this parliament. They do an injustice to the institution of the Senate and to the institution of the House of Representatives, because it is here, within these walls, that the future of our nation is decided by Australians and for Australians, and no amount of saying otherwise will change that simple fact.

It is spurious indeed that those who propose a republic say that we have to have a republic to become a sovereign and independent nation. In fact, a leading republican proponent, Mr Barry Jones, said, in the House of Representatives in 1987 after the passage of the Australia Act, that, with the passage of the Australia Act, Australia was finally a sovereign and independent nation. This is a matter of fact; it is a matter of record. Yet, Mr Barry Jones and other republicans now seek to change their views on this issue. Of course, the fact is that Australia is independent under our current constitutional arrangements and will always remain so.

The titular head of Australia, the Governor-General, is an Australian by virtue of the constitution. People who have recently criticised the Governor-General for his trip to Turkey had to concede the fact that the Governor-General went to Turkey, to Gallipoli, as head of state—as the effective Australian head of state—and he is recognised as such around the world. For those same people to say that, for some reason, we are considered overseas to be something less than independent is to be less than honest with the facts. The facts are these: Australia is seen around the world as a nation beholden to nobody. It is the cringe of the republican movement which does damage to this nation's sovereignty and independence, not our current constitutional arrangements.

The republicans then trot out their next argument. They say that we have to be a republic so that we can be part of South-East Asia or part of Asia. This is a very interesting argument because it is not an argument that you hear republicans and the government espousing when they go to Japan and meet with the emperor. It is not an argument that you find republicans espousing when they go to Thailand and meet with the king. It is not an argument that you find republicans espousing in Malaysia or Brunei. In fact, earlier this year, I shared a very pleasant evening: a dinner with Senator Gareth Evans and the sister of the Sultan of Brunei. It would have been spurious for Senator Gareth Evans to say that Australia wanted to become a republic to be more like the people in Brunei, and I think he recognised this. The facts are that, in what we loosely call Asia, there are as many constitutional monarchies as there are republics.

The question is this: in which system would one prefer to live? I think that most Australians would recognise that they would much rather enjoy the freedom that we have under our constitutional monarchy than live in places such as North Korea, the People's Republic of China or that other great bastion of human rights and civil liberties, Indonesia. The facts are that, within our region, it is the republics which are the least tolerant of nations and which have the least respect for the rights of individuals.

Indeed, that is why my family came to this country from China. My grandfather, who was a republican in China and supported the KMT, suddenly found, having got his republic, that he did not get the republic he wanted. And this is one of the great dangers. So it was to Australia that our family fled, to enjoy the freedoms that this nation has to offer under the provisions of our constitution.

So when republicans espouse their third great argument for a republic—that this nation is increasingly more ethnically diverse—they miss the point as to why people choose to come to this country after all. In many cases, people come to this country from republics overseas because this constitutional monarchy offers better protections than they received in their former home, which was a republic.

Isn't it a wonderful thing that the constitution of our nation can be perceived around the world as a protector of freedom and as a protector of the rights of individuals? We should think of these things with our heads held high, remembering that this has been achieved through enormous sacrifice and has resulted in enormous tolerance, and that one of the great dangers of republics—at least republics in our region—has been that republics have failed to respect the rights of individuals. That is why I say that it is foolish indeed of the republican movement to assume that, because people come from different ethnic backgrounds, they are going to come to this country and want to change this country into a republic. In many instances they have come to this country from a republic because of the benefits that our constitutional monarchy offers.

There are two problems that republicans have to answer: how will the republic work; and, secondly, how can it make this democratic nation any more democratic than it is at the moment? Republicans will tell you that it is going to be very easy to appoint the president. The president, they say, is going to be appointed by two-thirds of the parliament sitting together. What a wonderful suggestion. It is wonderful until one remembers the fact that the House of Representatives and the Senate cannot even agree on mutual times for lunch, let alone who would be the head of state. What an absurd situation. At best, two-thirds of parliament would be in agreement between whoever happened to be Prime Minister and whoever happened to be the Leader of the Opposition. And 80 per cent of Australians who say that they would like a republic want a republic only if they get the chance to determine who will be the president.

Here is the delicious irony: the republican movement says to ordinary Australians, `We want your support. We want to have a mass movement to change the constitution'—and it does require a mass movement to change the constitution—`We want your support to make this country a republic, to have an elected head of state. We want you to vote in a referendum to achieve that change. But, having achieved that change, we don't trust you to choose who will be the president.' That is the delicious irony. The people who say, `We want your vote. We want your trust to change the constitution,' are also saying to those same people who support them, `But we don't trust you to elect the president.' That is why republicanism will fail in this country: it does not make the system more democratic.

Even if you could get two-thirds of both houses to elect a president, there are enormous problems that flow from the power of that parliament to sack a president. If a parliament can make, a parliament can unmake. Let us not forget that the Governor-General, as the Queen's representative, is the protector, not of the opposition from the government, but of the people from the parliament.

Suppose a situation arose in which both sides of parliament decided they were going to gag the media because they did not like the media running stories about politicians expenses, the bill duly passed parliament, it went to the president and the president refused to sign. What happens then? The same two-thirds that got together and voted the bill through parliament could get together and vote to sack the president to have their way. The president, of course, could always dissolve parliament. What happens? Who determines who has priority? Is it the president's writ of dissolution, or is it the vote of the same two-thirds of the parliament that appointed the president and want to close down the criticism by the media of the politicians? Which is it?

Republicanism, in this fashion, offers only one thing, and that is the constant threat of constitutional crisis. This is the grave failing of the republican case. They cannot make this system any more democratic than it is because, in truth, the only great power held by the Governor-General is the power, in the event of crisis, to dissolve the parliament and return the parliamentarians to answer to the people. Nothing could be more democratic than that. Anything else means that, at a time of crisis, the ultimate decision does not lie with the people but lies with some self-elected or self-appointed elite. In truth, the great challenge for our constitution in the future is to make the constitution more democratic, not to erode the fundamental strengths that make this nation a great democracy.

So I say to those in the republican movement that their contribution to discussion is welcome but they must, to have the support of the Australian people, offer an alternative which is truly democratic, and not merely an excuse to entrench the power of a self-elected oligopoly. This nation is one of the greatest nations in the world and we tamper with those freedoms at our risk. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today on the subject of Western Australian industrial relations legislation, in particular what is referred to as the first wave of industrial legislation introduced by the Court Liberal government. In doing so, I want to continue some remarks I commenced last night in the adjournment debate, which go to the detailing of workers' experiences in Western Australia under that legislation. I do so because I think the relevance is obvious. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr John Howard, is on the record as indicating his support for that legislation and saying that the policy applied in Western Australia would form the basis of federal policy. On 28 July 1995, Mr Howard said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to see throughout Australia an industrial relations system that is largely similar to what the coalition government has implemented in Western Australia.
He later said in parliament:
I said that I supported the laws that had already been enacted in Western Australia.

I make it clear here that Mr Howard was referring to the first wave of IR legislation, and that is also the subject of my discussion today. Last night, I detailed a comparison of the workplace agreement put in place at TAFE colleges in Western Australia for cleaners employed by Linfoot Cleaning Services, comparing that to their old award. For the subject of today's contribution, I will refer to that as workplace agreement A. I want to provide for the Senate today details of comparisons of further workplace agreements and the relevant award. I have sought leave of the opposition whip to incorporate these documents entitled `Workplace agreements B, C, D and E'. I seek leave to incorporate those documents.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: WORKPLACE AGREEMENT "B"EMPLOYER:

PARA.TAB: Avalon Cleaning Services Pty Ltd

SPEECH.PARA: AWARD:

PARA.TAB: Contract Cleaners Award 1990

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND:

PARA.TAB: The cleaning contract at SECWA Kwinana is currently carried out by Avalon Cleaning Services, employing approximately 15-20 workers.

On being awarded the contract in 1994, Avalon employed cleaners subject to the terms and conditions in this Workplace Agreement, despite the fact no Workplace Agreement had been signed or registered with the Workplace Agreement Commissioner.
Employment was only offered on the basis that the Workplace Agreement terms and conditions applied. The Award was not an option. There was no choice.

Subsequently, a Workplace Agreement in these terms was offered to and signed by workers. It merely formalised the arrangements under which they had been working, since the Commencement of the contract.
The employer failed to register these first Workplace Agreements within 21 days as required, and the Workplace Agreement lapsed.

A second identical agreement was offered during the Christmas period 1994, but again the employer failed to register the agreements within the specified time. It is alleged in one case, the employer changed the date on the Workplace Agreement in an attempt to overcome time problems.

By this time, some employees had sought advice from their union. One employee withdrew her consent to the second agreement, and refused to sign the third agreement which was now on offer. She was threatened with the sack by the employer and was in fact sacked approximately two weeks later.

The union successfully pursued an unfair dismissal application on the workers behalf and the worker was reinstated, only to be sacked again one month later. The worker accepted an out of court settlement for the second sacking and has not, nor will she return to her employment.

At no point did the employer give workers copies of any of the Workplace Agreements they signed. A copy was obtained by one worker only by approaching the Workplace Agreement Commissioner, who supplied the copy.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHLIGHTS:
CASUAL STATUS

PARA.TAB: As with the Linfoot's Workplace Agreement, this agreement classified employees as casual, removing all but minimum wage rate and unpaid bereavement leave protection under the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.

Workers who were previously part or full time forfeit all standard employment conditions such as paid sick and annual leave, and unpaid maternity leave. Casual workers under the Award are entitled to four week's unpaid annual leave.

SPEECH.PARA: RATES OF PAY

PARA.TAB: Under the Workplace Agreement all work, regardless of the hour of the day, or day of the week, is paid at a flat rate of $11.80 p.h.
Under the Award, the casual rate of $12.02 p.h. is supplemented by penalty rates applying to night, weekend and public holiday work.
So too is the Award rate of $10.02 p.h., for a part or full time worker supplemented by the standard award penalty rates.

SPEECH.PARA: Hours of work

PARA.TAB: The Workplace Agreement requires an employee to work at any time of the day, on any day of the week. Shifts can be of any length, at any time and are paid at the ordinary rate of $11.80 p.h. There is no overtime, nor is there provision for meal breaks during shifts.
Ordinary hours under the award are eight per day on any five days of the week. Overtime rates apply for hours in excess of these. Meal breaks are provided for.

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty Rates

PARA.TAB: Under the Workplace Agreement the ordinary rate of $11.80 p.h. applies to all work done, at any time, on any day of the year. There are no penalty rates for night, weekend or public holiday work as provided under the Award. This causes a significant reduction in a cleaner's take home pay.
