WAGE COMPARISON
Example 1

PARA.TAB: Roberta works an evening shift from 7pm—9pm from Monday to Friday. Under Award casual rates, she earned $138.20 p.w. After signing the Workplace Agreement her wage was reduced to $118.00 p.w., representing a 14.6% loss in her income.

SPEECH.PARA: Example 2

PARA.TAB: Nicolai was a part time worker enjoying all the standard benefits of employment (such as paid annual and sick leave) under the Award. For his 7pm to 10pm shift from Thursday to Sunday, he earned $174.33 p.w. After signing the Workplace Agreement, he earns only $141.60. This equates to nearly 1/5 reduction (19%) in his income. In addition, he has lost all the other standard conditions he previously enjoyed.

SPEECH.PARA: Overtime

PARA.TAB: Award overtime rates apply where more than eight hours is worked in a day, or where more than forty hours over five days of the week has been worked.
There is no overtime in the Workplace Agreement. Shifts can be of any length over any number of days at the employers discretion.

SPEECH.PARA: Public Holidays

PARA.TAB: Paid public holidays for part and full time staff is eliminated under the Workplace Agreement. So too are Award penalty rates applying to public holidays worked.

SPEECH.PARA: Allowances

PARA.TAB: Award allowances for such matters as toilet cleaning, meals during overtime, distant location and travel are completely excluded from the Workplace Agreement.
Under the Award allowances paid to a worker could range from $1.00 to $20.00 or more per week.

SPEECH.PARA: WAGE INCREASES

PARA.TAB: The Workplace Agreement applies for a period of one year during which there is no provision for a wage increase.
The Workplace Agreement provides that it will endure until another Workplace Agreement replaces it—wage rates are fixed for at least as long as this takes.

SPEECH.PARA: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT:

PARA.TAB: Under the Award, part and full time workers are entitled to one week's notice of termination of employment. Casual workers are entitled to one hour's notice.
The Workplace Agreement provides for one hour's notice for all employees.

SPEECH.PARA: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY ISSUES:

PARA.TAB: Restrictions on the height to which a cleaner can climb, and requirements that the employer pay for and provide protective clothing under the Award are removed by the Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: PAYMENT OF WAGES

PARA.TAB: Award wages must be paid weekly or fortnightly into a bank account or by cheque. The employer must meet any costs associated with payment of wages.
Under the Workplace Agreement payments are monthly by cheque.

SPEECH.PARA: DISPUTE RESOLUTION

PARA.TAB: If the employer and employee cannot agree on an Arbitrator in the event of a dispute under the Workplace Agreement, the agreement nominates a certified practising accountant, Mr A Terrebile, or his nominee. This effectively gives the employer veto in choosing an arbitrator.
Liability for the costs of arbitration is not mentioned.

SPEECH.PARA: STATUS:

PARA.TAB: All employees currently working on the Kwinana site are believed to be working subject to this agreement.
The union will be seeking an interim Federal Award to override Workplace Agreements in contract cleaning areas.

SPEECH.PARA: WORKPLACE AGREEMENT "C"
EMPLOYER:

PARA.TAB: Intercity Cleaning Services

SPEECH.PARA: AWARD:

PARA.TAB: Contract Cleaning Award 1990

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND:

PARA.TAB: Intercity employs approximately 10 cleaners under a cleaning contract for Delta West, a pharmaceutical firm, based at Technology Park.

Workplace Agreement "C" is the employer's second attempt to transfer workers from the award to a Workplace Agreement. Neither attempt has been successful, because the area is unionised and union intervention has caused the employer to re-think the matter.

This Workplace Agreement largely reflects the Example "A" and "B", in terms of casualisation, and reduction in income. However, it reduces conditions even further by requiring workers to perform "other duties" permits the employer to require workers to move from one site to another, without reimbursement of the extra cost associated with such movement.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHLIGHTS:
CASUAL STATUS

PARA.TAB: As with the Linfoot and Avalon Workplace Agreement, all employees are defined as casual, removing all but minimum wage and bereavement leave conditions under the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.
Workers who were previously full or part time forfeit all standard employment conditions they previously were entitled to under the Award.

SPEECH.PARA: RATES OF PAY

PARA.TAB: While the rate of pay does not appear in the Workplace Agreement, workers advise that they were offered $12.00 p.h., including the 15% casual rate.
Note that only 95% of this rate is paid for the first three months which is described in the Workplace Agreement as a probationary period.
This compares with the Award full/part time rate of $10.02 and casual rate of $12.02 p.h.
Again a substantial reduction in Workplace Agreement wages is achieved by the elimination of penalty and overtime rates, and allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: Hours of Work

PARA.TAB: Hours of work under the Workplace Agreement can be at any time, on any day, depending on which job a worker is assigned to. This means there is no overtime—all work is paid at the flat rate of $12.00 p.h.

SPEECH.PARA: Penalty Rates

PARA.TAB: There are no penalty rates under the Workplace Agreement. All work, regardless of the time of day, or the day of the year are paid at the ordinary rate of $12.00.
Penalty rates applying under the Award are outlined in the Avalon agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: Overtime

PARA.TAB: Award overtime rates apply after eight hours worked in a day, or more than forty hours worked over five days. Overtime is paid at time and one half for the first two hours, and double time thereafter.
There is no overtime in the Workplace Agreement. Ordinary rates apply regardless of length of shift, or number of days worked.

SPEECH.PARA: Public Holidays

PARA.TAB: Paid public holidays for staff previously employed as full or part time is eliminated, as are penalty rates applying to public holidays worked.

SPEECH.PARA: Allowances

PARA.TAB: All Award allowances are excluded. Under the Award allowance payments could range from $1.00 to $20.00 or more per week.

SPEECH.PARA: WAGE INCREASES

PARA.TAB: The Workplace Agreement applies for a period of three months, with no provision for wages review either during or at the expiry of the agreement. The Workplace Agreement provides it shall remain in force until replaced by another agreement. Wage rates are fixed for at least as long as this process takes.

SPEECH.PARA: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT

PARA.TAB: Curiously, the notice required under the Workplace Agreement is more favourable to employees than the Award. It appears the Workplace Agreement notice clause includes some aspects of standard redundancy provisions which would explain the difference.

SPEECH.PARA: OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY ISSUES

PARA.TAB: Protective provisions governing the height to which cleaners can climb, and provision of protective clothing by the employer are excluded by the Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: PAYMENT OF WAGES

PARA.TAB: Award wages must be paid weekly or fortnightly into a bank account or by cheque. The employer must meet any costs associated with the method of payment.
The Workplace Agreement does not provide for the method, nor the time of payment. This causes problems with enforcement.

SPEECH.PARA: DISPUTE RESOLUTION

PARA.TAB: Under the Workplace Agreement, if an arbitrator cannot be agreed upon, they will be nominated by a local Justice of the Peace. Costs are to be borne equally, unless either party was substantially incorrect. This exposes a worker to the full costs of arbitration, something which under the industrial system is free of charge to both parties.

SPEECH.PARA: STATUS:

PARA.TAB: It is understood that none of the workers at Delta West site have signed the Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: ATTACHMENTS:

PARA.TAB: Intercity Cleaning Services Individual Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: WORKPLACE AGREEMENT "D"
EMPLOYER:

PARA.TAB: J and P Pty Ltd trading as Bakers Delight

SPEECH.PARA: AWARD:

PARA.TAB: Bakers (Metropolitan) Award 1987

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND:

PARA.TAB: Bakers Delight operate at least 16 metropolitan baking and bread retail outlets in the Perth Metropolitan area and one in Mandurah. As it is a seven day operation, it is estimated each outlet would employ at least eight, and probably many more workers.

The Workplace Agreement was signed and registered in 1995. The worker concerned is a qualified baker and had previously been paid Award rates. He left his job because of dissatisfaction with the Workplace Agreement and his reduced wages.
The Workplace Agreement applied for a period of five years, with a further twelve months application should a new agreement not be finalised at that time.
It is believed that most Bakers Delight employees are employed on Workplace Agreements of a similar kind.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHLIGHTS:
RATES OF PAY:

PARA.TAB: The ordinary Award rate (full or part time) for a baker is $11.05 ph. The Workplace Agreement rate is $13.46 ph.

While the Workplace Agreement rate is considerably more than the ordinary Award rate, actual pay is less under the Workplace Agreement due to the exclusion of Award penalties and allowances and reduced rates and provision for overtime.
Hours of Work
The Award provides for 38 hours per week to be the norm. Any work in addition to 38 hours is overtime and paid as such. Ordinary hours are between 6pm on Sunday and midnight Friday.
The Workplace Agreement provides for a minimum of 50 hours per week, and a maximum of 70 hours per week.
Overtime is paid only where more than 70 hours is worked, at the rate of $15.00 ph. Ordinary hours are all hours of the day, every day of the week.

Under the Award, the 38 hours must be worked in no more than five shifts, of 10 hours maximum. Under the Workplace Agreement shifts can be spread over six days, with no restriction on the length of shift.
Meal breaks required under the Award after five hours work are eliminated under the Workplace Agreement.
Penalty Rates
The Workplace Agreement eliminates penalty rates. All work done (with the exception of overtime after 70 hours worked in a week) is paid at the ordinary rate of $13.46 ph.
The major Award penalty rates appear in the following Table. Industry requirements mean

SPEECH.PARA: workers qualify for significant penalty rates as a normal part of their wages.
Early Start Night Shift Sundays Public
3am-6am 6pm-3am After Holidays
6 pm Worked
Rate
WAGE COMPARISONS:

PARA.TAB: Example 1

A baker working under Award rates for 70 hours per week, in hours that attract no penalty rates earns $1116.15 pw. For the same work, the Workplace Agreement rate would be $942.20, representing an income reduction of 15.6%.
Example 2

A baker working 38 hours per week with three eight hour shifts attracting penalty rates of 1.36, 1.36 and double time respectively, earns $542.14 pw. Under the Workplace Agreement a baker would earn only $511.48 pw.
If overtime is regularly worked, as is the case in this industry, the gap between Award rates and the Workplace Agreement increases significantly.
Overtime

Overtime is paid under the Award for all hours in excess of 38 per week, or 10 hours per shift. It is paid at a rate of time and one half ($16.87) for the first two hours, and double time thereafter ($22.10). Where more than ten hours in a shift is worked, it is paid at double time.
Under the Workplace Agreement overtime is only paid after 70 hours in a week is worked. All overtime is paid at a rate of $15.00 ph.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC HOLIDAYS:

PARA.TAB: While the Workplace Agreement retains paid public holidays for full/part time workers, it eliminates any penalty rates for public holidays worked. Public holidays worked under the Award at a rate of double time and one half ($27.63 ph).
Under the Workplace Agreement, the public holiday rate is the ordinary rate of $13.84 ph.

SPEECH.PARA: WAGE INCREASES:

PARA.TAB: Wages are reviewed on the anniversary of the agreement. The basis for any wage increase is the Perth CPI figure. Productivity, skills and efficiency are not factors in wage determination.

SPEECH.PARA: TERMINATION OF AGREEMENT:

PARA.TAB: One weeks notice applies in both the Award and the Workplace Agreement. Under the Workplace Agreement an employee can be dismissed for "incompatible conduct".

SPEECH.PARA: PAYMENT OF WAGES:

PARA.TAB: Award wages are paid weekly or fortnightly by cash, cheque or into a bank account. The Workplace Agreement only provides for payment into a bank account on a weekly basis.

SPEECH.PARA: ANNUAL LEAVE:

PARA.TAB: Four weeks annual leave at the ordinary rate ($13.46 ph) is paid under the Workplace Agreement.
Under the Award, a worker receives the rate they would have at work, with a loading of between 17 1/2 and 36%.

SPEECH.PARA: SICK LEAVE:

PARA.TAB: Ten days paid sick leave is included in both the Award and the Workplace Agreement. Sick leave not taken accumulates from year to year under the Award, while under the Workplace Agreement it is forfeited every year.

Generally, medical certificates are not required under the Award for absences of two days or less. The Workplace Agreement requires medical certificates to be provided for any sick leave absence at all.

SPEECH.PARA: ALLOWANCES:

PARA.TAB: Disability, higher duties, in charge and travel allowances are eliminated under the Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: DISPUTE RESOLUTION:

PARA.TAB: If the worker and the employer are unable to agree on an arbitrator, the Workplace Agreement provides for a Commissioner of Industrial Relations to be appointed.

SPEECH.PARA: STATUS:

PARA.TAB: While the worker who signed this Workplace Agreement is no longer employed with Bakers Delight, it is believed most, if not all current employees are subject to this, or a similar agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: WORKPLACE AGREEMENT "E"
EMPLOYER:

PARA.TAB: JC Nominees trading as The Great Bake Hot Bread Shop, Collie

SPEECH.PARA: AWARD:

PARA.TAB: Bakers (Country) Award 1977

SPEECH.PARA: BACKGROUND:

PARA.TAB: In November 1993, a worker was employed as an probationary apprentice baker. Despite formal acknowledgment of the employer's satisfaction with the employee, the apprenticeship never materialised.

Instead, in May 1994, the employer indicated to the worker that business was not good, and he could not afford award wages. The employer proposed that the worker sign a Workplace Agreement. The worker was noncommittal.

The next month, the employer produced a Workplace Agreement already signed by the employer, employing the worker as a Full Time General Hand. The worker indicated he would not sign it, but would like to think about it and respond at a later date. He and his father then sought advice from his union.
A week later, the employer raised the issue of the Workplace Agreement again, and the worker indicated that he was unwilling to sign, and would prefer to stay with the Award.
The employer then dismissed the worker with a weeks notice, because he would not sign the Workplace Agreement.
Action for unfair dismissal was discontinued by the Union, after the worker found alternate employment.

In the meantime, the Union had requested the State Government to investigate breaches of the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act, arising from the Workplace Agreement, specifically the exclusion of minimum conditions such as paid sick and annual leave, bereavement leave and public holidays.

The Minister for Labour relations responded by stating the Workplace Agreement specifies it is a casual contract and as such is exempt from all minimum conditions, except pay rates and 2 days unpaid bereavement leave.

Despite the Minister's assertion, the Workplace Agreement does not specify the contract as casual. To the contrary it specifies the contract is for a Full Time General Hand position, working 40 hours per week. Neither is there an indication that the wage rate incorporates a 15% loading required for casual contracts under the minimum conditions applying.

Whatever the status of the contract, the Minister went on to advise that while the Workplace Agreement Commissioner would draw parties attention to the minimum conditions applicable, there was no requirement that an inadequate Workplace Agreement be amended to provide for minimums, in order for registration to occur.

This is because the minimum conditions are implied into the contract whether they appear there or not. This has serious implications for workers in terms of certainty, level of knowledge of minimum conditions and enforcement.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHLIGHTS:
RATE OF PAY:

PARA.TAB: The Workplace Agreement provides for an hourly rate of $7.00 per hour for any work done at any time.
The Workplace Agreement provides for an average of 40 hours work per week to be performed over any day of the week.
Penalty rates
There are no penalty rates under the Workplace Agreement. All work done is paid at the ordinary $7.00 per hour rate.
Overtime
Award overtime is paid for all hours worked in excess of 38 per week, or where work is performed on a sixth day. Rates are time and one half for the first two hours, and double time thereafter.
There is no overtime rate under the Workplace Agreement. All hours worked are paid at the ordinary rate of $7.00 ph.

SPEECH.PARA: PUBLIC HOLIDAYS:

PARA.TAB: Under the Award, full and part time workers are entitled to paid public holidays, and all workers to a penalty payment of double time and one half, if the public holiday is worked.
Neither of these standard employment benefits are included in the Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: WAGE INCREASES:

PARA.TAB: Wages are reviewed annually under the Workplace Agreement, and may be adjusted. The basis upon which a review is to be conducted is not detailed.

SPEECH.PARA: TERMINATION OF EMPLOYMENT:

PARA.TAB: One week's notice for full and part time workers, and one hour's notice for a casual worker is required under the Award.
The Workplace Agreement provides for a range of notice periods, dependent upon the length of service of a worker. The period ranges from 1 hour to 4 weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: PAYMENT OF WAGES:

PARA.TAB: The Award requires payment by cash, cheque or into a bank account on a weekly(?) basis.
The Workplace Agreement does not specify time or method of payment, giving rise to enforcement problems for the worker.

SPEECH.PARA: LEAVE:

PARA.TAB: There is no paid leave under the Workplace Agreement. Annual and sick leave may be taken, but is unpaid. There is no provision for bereavement leave.
The omission of these provisions breaches the Minimum Conditions of Employment Act.
Award leave includes paid sick, annual and compassionate leave of 10 days, 4 weeks (with a leave loading) and 2 days respectively.

SPEECH.PARA: ALLOWANCES:

PARA.TAB: All Award allowances for such matters as higher duties, travel, disability and duties in charge are eliminated by the Workplace Agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: DISPUTE RESOLUTION:

PARA.TAB: The Workplace Agreement provides for the Chamber of Commerce and Industry to nominate an arbitrator, with costs of arbitration to be borne equally unless the outcome substantially favours the worker.

SPEECH.PARA: STATUS:

PARA.TAB: While the worker who signed this Workplace Agreement has found alternate employment, it is believed that most, and probably all employees at the outlet are employed subject to similar Workplace Agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, and thank you, Senator O'Chee. These documents provide a comparison of the relevant workplace agreements and awards covering the workers described in the documents. They relate to people in Western Australia employed in a cleaning capacity and to people employed in the baking industry. I hope to table further such examples in coming weeks.

PARA.TAB: I have not at this stage tabled the actual workplace agreement because there are extreme secrecy provisions in the Western Australian legislation surrounding the disclosure of workplace agreements. There are also penalties involved with disclosing details of workplace agreements. The matter that most concerns me is that the individual workers who have provided those documents to the persons who have then forwarded them to me need to be protected. I will, at a later stage, seek leave to table those particular workplace agreements but I first have to make sure that there is no way of identifying the particular workers involved.

The workplace agreements that I have just incorporated highlight a number of things. The first is that, under the regime of industrial relations established by the Court Liberal government in Western Australia, workers have been forced into casual employment contracts. This has been done because the legislation provides that a worker employed on a casual contract is not protected by the minimum conditions of employment legislation. So no minimums apply to a worker employed on a contract that is defined as casual contract. To be defined as a casual contract all that is required is for a worker not to be entitled to paid annual leave.

It used to be the case when I was an industrial relations practitioner that casual employment was defined by the short-term nature of the employment. A casual was someone employed for less than a week or less than a month under a particular award. But, under the Western Australian industrial relations legislation, thousands of workers have been reclassified from being permanent full-time or permanent part-time to being casuals. Therefore, under the Western Australian industrial relations legislation, they are only entitled to protection for the payment of a minimum wage and for an entitlement to bereavement leave. They are not entitled to paid annual leave. They are not entitled to paid sick leave and they are not entitled to any of the other normal conditions that have been built up in awards in this country over the last hundred years.

These things mean that a worker, having served 10 or 15 years as an employee of a firm, and because they continue to be defined as casual, can be entitled to long service leave but not entitled to annual leave. They have no protection. The Liberal Party rhetoric about protecting people's minimums and protecting their conditions is a hollow claim. These agreements detail how workers are being classified as casual and therefore exposed to an individual contract with their employer that provides no minimums other than the minimum wage and an entitlement to bereavement leave.

The second aspect of these contracts, and the further ones that I shall introduce into the chamber in coming weeks, is that of wage rates. On first glance, the wage rates contained in the workplace agreements appear to be comparable with those in the award. They are designed, in my view, so as to look competitive in order to attract labour. They are also designed in this way, on the recommendation of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, to give some credibility to workplace agreements.

But what one must understand, and what these comparisons highlight, is that most of these workplace agreements do not provide for penalty payments or for overtime. Some of them provide that ordinary hours are up to 70 hours per week, without payment of any penalties. If a worker is taken sick, there is no entitlement for sick leave and there is no paid annual leave. The contracts provide that if a worker wants to take annual leave they need the permission of the employer and it has to be unpaid annual leave. This could be a worker who has been working for five, 10 or 15 years for that one employer.

In my view, in a lot of these industries, Third World employment conditions are being introduced into Australia, conditions that we legislated to prevent in the early part of this century, when we set up the conciliation and arbitration commissions and the award system in Australia. The total package that these workers are receiving is significantly less than the package they would have received under the award. Workers are significantly worse off not just in monetary terms at the end of the week by virtue of their pay packet but also in terms of their lack of entitlement to sick leave, annual leave and those other conditions that we, as Australian workers, have accepted as being basic minima, as basic to the standard of living and the social cohesion in this country.

Workers in WA receive no protection from the minimum conditions of employment act because, by merely defining a worker as casual, even if they are working 38 or 40 hours per week, working 52 weeks of the year and have been employed for five, 10 or 15 years, they have no protection as to minimum conditions, as I say, other than the minimum wage and an entitlement to bereavement leave. Clearly, the workers are worse off.

Another problem is that employers who employ under individual workplace agreements are at a comparative advantage to other employers. We are seeing the erosion of the award system and the safety net provided. For instance, a contract cleaner is paying under the award and a competitor is paying under an individual workplace agreement. The individual workplace agreement provides for significantly lower return to the worker and, therefore, significantly lower total cost to the employer, hence he has a comparative advantage. The competitor can gain the contract—for instance, a cleaning contract—because he can keep his costs lower. He would be rewarding and paying his employees considerably less, therefore, he can tender at a lower contract price. The award system is being eroded by these workplace agreements.

It is a nonsense to claim that the award system is a safety net, because the award system will eventually be totally eroded by the ability of employers to pay what they like. That is, effectively, the situation in Western Australia because there is no protection from the minimum conditions of employment act. There is no disadvantage test. There is no safety net in practice.

There is a third issue that I want to refer to, and this becomes clear from the examples that I have incorporated. Effectively, a worker has no choice in Western Australia about signing a workplace agreement. The union claim of sign or resign, or sign or refuse the job, has been proved by the experience in the last two years in Western Australia. Ian Viner QC provided a legal opinion to the Trades and Labour Council when the legislation was being debated in the WA parliament, which made it clear that, in his view, the legislation provided no protection for workers and no protection from the superior bargaining power of employers. His legal opinion has been vindicated by the experience of Western Australian workers. There is no choice and no protection. There is no choice when you are employed. For instance, recently, in the West Australian newspaper, an industrial commissioner, a former employers' industrial advocate, advertised for an associate to work with him in his position as an industrial commissioner with the WA industrial relations commission. He offered a workplace agreement. If people want a job working with the industrial commissioner, they have to sign a workplace agreement. If you were the best person for the job, there was no choice about whether you were going to be able to choose the award or the workplace agreement. You had to sign the workplace agreement.

Equally, the examples I have incorporated prove that workers are being dismissed if they refuse to sign workplace agreements. Workers are under enormous pressure to sign. They know it is a matter of sign or resign. We have instances of workers having been sacked for their refusal to sign or for their attempt to involve the protection of the award or the protection of their union. The only thing that is protecting some workers currently in Western Australia is the fact that their unions are seeking federal award coverage as protection from these workplace agreements.

The fourth issue arising from these examples that I want to address today is the role that the Chamber of Commerce and Industry is now playing in Western Australian industrial relations practice. We are aware that the minister has given himself the power to set the minimum wage, independent of any recommendation of the industrial relations commissioner. He has given himself the power to remove awards and to remove the right of unions to represent workers.

The minister has also given the Chamber of Commerce and Industry enormous powers. What is occurring is that the Chamber of Commerce and Industry is advising its members of the ability to employ people as casuals and therefore avoid the minimum conditions under the employment acts. They are advising and encouraging members to take out workplace agreements, to employ members as casuals and to set their own wage rates and conditions. Because there is no protection from the legislation, the chamber is able to advise employers what rates and conditions should apply. Employers can ignore that advice but most of them seem to be pursuing the chamber's advice and are using standard contracts drawn up by the chamber where all they have to do is write in the employer's name, the employee's name and a couple of other details.

As a result, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry is driving wage rates and conditions down to minimums that they consider to be appropriate to be paid. They have completely eroded the role of the industrial commission as the independent arbitrator of wages and conditions in Western Australia. Because individual contracts provide no protection for workers, the employer, with the advice of the Chamber of Commerce and Industry, sets the wages and conditions.

The other thing that has occurred is that they even have the gall, as shown in workplace agreement E, to nominate the Chamber of Commerce and Industry as the arbitrator of any dispute between the worker and the employer. Not only does the chamber advise and help draw up the contract that sets the wages and conditions but, if the worker is brave or stupid enough to dispute it, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry will appoint an independent arbitrator, not the industrial commissioner. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry says that not only will it set wages and conditions but, if people have any concern about that, they will nominate the arbiter to arbitrate any disputes under the workplace agreement.

Clearly, what the government has done is privatise the industrial commission's role and, in effect, has given it to the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia. It is another step in their privatisation process. It is clear that the rhetoric of the Liberal Party in Western Australia and the rhetoric of John Howard in the parliament do not match the reality of people's working lives in Western Australia and do not match the reality of what is occurring to people working under workplace agreements in Western Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take the time of the Senate in this matter of public interest debate to comment on two very specific and important issues affecting the Northern Territory. The first issue is that relating to the progress of the Northern Territory in constitutionally moving towards statehood. The Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, the parliament of the Northern Territory, quite incidentally had its 21st anniversary last Thursday, 19 October 1995. Also, incidentally, that day was the 21st anniversary of my entry to a parliament. I have since enjoyed participating in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, the House of Representatives and the Senate.

PARA.TAB: There is a very important bipartisan committee of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly which has released an exposure draft of a new constitution for the Northern Territory. It is based on the premise that the Northern Territory will be placed on an equal footing with existing states as a precondition to the grant of statehood and, of course, we will not accept a second-class grant under any circumstances.

The Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development of the Northern Territory has recently handed down its annual report. There is a very important point in that report which is that the committee is identifying and formulating long-term strategies such as the form, content and format of a draft constitution, reviewing the desired procedure for the adoption of a Northern Territory constitution and other issues relating to eventual statehood, including a possible timetable for the re-establishment of public awareness programs to Northern Territory urban centres, Aboriginal and remote communities. I commend the report to the Senate.

Secondly, the exposure draft of a new constitution for the Northern Territory is vitally important. I again commend to the Senate the tabling statement in the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly on 22 June 1995 by the Attorney-General, the Hon. Steve Hatton, who is also chairman of the Sessional Committee on Constitutional Development of the Northern Territory.
If I could highlight one point of Mr Hatton's tabling statement, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recognises there will be no major constitutional development in the Northern Territory without the support and recognition of the basic rights of Aboriginal people. However, there is a concern in Aboriginal society, which values its various indigenous cultural circumstances, particularly land rights, sacred sites and customary law, the concern being that these rights should be constitutionally protected, otherwise they could be at risk after statehood.

PARA.TAB: This exposure draft reflects the recommendations to satisfy these concerns, whilst presuming the transfer of the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 to become a law of the Northern Territory. Part of this proposal is to introduce the concept of organic laws into our new constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to table the annual report and the exposure draft of the new constitution. I did check it with Senator Schacht.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I mentioned, that work is the result of a bipartisan committee in the Northern Territory. This compares very favourably with the attitude to statehood by the Australian Labor Party in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: If I can refer to what Warren Snowdon, the Northern Territory's federal member, told Darwin radio on 9 June this year, he said that statehood was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . incidental to the process of getting to a republic and that's been made very clear.
Yet a news poll shows that two-thirds of territorians want both issues, statehood and the republic, resolved within the next four years.

PARA.TAB: Another of Mr Snowdon's colleagues, the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister, Mr Kim Beazley, stepped up Labor's anti-statehood campaign when he visited Darwin in August. He warned that the Northern Territory could suffer financially as a result of statehood. I disagree with him. But in comments reminiscent of Labor's scare tactics in the early 1970s—the pre-self government days—Mr Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: You could not sit down with the other states and justify the level of subsidy in per capita here if statehood had actually been achieved.

That was on a radio station in Darwin on 19 August 1995. The reality is that the Northern Territory receives a higher level of funding, not because of its constitutional status but because of factors such as distance, population dispersion and the pressing need of people in remote areas and Aboriginal communities. Clearly, Mr Beazley did not read his own departmental brief on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Labor's approach to statehood is in stark contrast to that of the Liberal and National parties in the federal coalition. John Howard, the opposition leader, gave a commitment in June this year to list Northern Territory statehood on the agenda of the people's convention in 1997. That convention will review the Australian constitution and consider new issues such as territory statehood. In other words, unlike Prime Minister Keating, John Howard has given territorians a firm commitment to address statehood in the context of discussions on the Australian constitution.

I think it is also important to note that, at the opening of the new Parliament House in Darwin on 31 August 1994, there were a number of very important statements made by the Governor-General, Bill Hayden, and of course others, including the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron. Let me quote from what Mr Perron said on that occasion:
In our sixteen year period of self-rule, the Territory has prospered despite the external constitutional constraints which have blocked many of our development options.

This former backwater, which the rest of Australia had forgotten, has been transformed into a modern, progressive state . . . and is acknowledged as a leader in making friends in the dynamic Asian region which starts just over our northern horizon.
The record shows that here, like elsewhere, self rule turned local vision into growth, and new endeavour.
The continued existence of this one-sixth of all Australia as a Territory constitutionally inferior to the States is an anachronism.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, it must be addressed and it must be addressed soon.

PARA.TAB: I note that today the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, in its annual report, has commented that an agreement was struck at the Council of Australian Governments in April 1995 for the establishment of a working group of Commonwealth and Northern Territory officials to consider the implications of a possible grant of statehood to the Northern Territory and that this working group is being chaired by the secretary to that department and is to report to the Prime Minister and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory by December 1995. The report goes on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has made no commitment as to any particular outcome of this process.

That is what disturbs me. There is an undercurrent by the Labor administration in Canberra that does not reflect the priorities of the Labor Party and certainly the Country-Liberal Party in the Northern Territory. I hope that it will now gather a lot more enthusiasm and support.

PARA.TAB: The second and quite discrete and separate issue that I want to address today relates to a proposal for the establishment of a cooperative research centre that will look very much at the issues of renewable energy and greenhouse gas abatement technologies. Research capabilities and market knowledge combine in this proposal as a world class centre for the development and commercialisation of renewable energy systems which will minimise greenhouse gas emissions.

The CRC proposal focuses on ecologically sustainable development in a practical way, especially in outback Australia, including Western Australia, the Northern Territory, outback New South Wales and Queensland. Thus it will benefit Aboriginal communities, pastoralists and remote off grid communities, remote mining communities and all Australians as the benefits will flow eventually to urban communities and export markets.

Without losing the export focus, the CRC includes the best and most innovative researches in renewable energy systems from other parts of Australia. It is proposed that there will be 26 participants, including nine from Perth and five from Darwin. Other national linkages come from Canberra, Broken Hill, Alice Springs, Sydney, Newcastle and Brisbane, and major utilities from Western Australia, the Northern Territory and New South Wales. A strong group of private sector innovators joins in this CRC to ensure research benefits flow through into the economy. It is Perth based, and this reflects the growing renewables research and development centre of excellence based at Murdoch University.

World class innovation and technology transfer to the Asia-Pacific markets are hallmarks of this proposal. Discussions have already begun with Asia-Pacific interests to develop an export culture for the CRC and to open up cooperation for demonstration projects and market opportunities.

The CRC is strongly supported by the Western Australian and Northern Territory governments, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and the private sector, and this reflects its remote area focus and the official recognition of the CRC's high quality research team and strong organisation and its commitment to demonstration and commercialisation of the products of research. This CRC shows that not everything new and exciting in Australia or in Australian science needs to be located on the east coast of Australia.

There is a gathering together of important groups from academia, whether it is from Murdoch University, the Australian National University, Curtin University, the CSIRO, the Northern Territory University—in particular, the centre for energy studies—the University of Queensland, the University of Newcastle and the University of Technology in Sydney. This is linked with a dozen or so companies from the private sector with major power energy areas and is supported, as I said before, by various other sectors, including the governments of Western Australia and the Northern Territory.

I know from discussions with my colleagues in the Northern Territory government that their agencies have been experimenting with renewables for remote community services since l978, when the first solar water pumping systems were commissioned in Aboriginal communities. Now over 150 solar water pumping systems have been installed to provide remote Aboriginal communities in the Territory with their water supplies.

Prior to l990 the use of renewables for electricity generation was not economic and the Northern Territory program for improving its electricity generation performance was based on the introduction of natural-gas fired plant and the latest technology at that time for combined cycle power generation plant. This led to the Power and Water Authority of the Northern Territory becoming the lowest contributor of CO2 of any state utilities that depend on fossil fuels for generation.

Over the last five years new and emerging technologies have changed the situation so that we now have a number of cost effective applications of renewable energy generation being demonstrated. However, the successes are still limited to niche applications, where care has been taken to design a system that accurately reflects the circumstances of the community being supplied.

A framework that provides for integrating emerging technologies for renewable energy generation systems with community circumstances so as to stimulate a market pull environment is lacking. The territory experience indicates that this component of the commercialisation process must be improved before the potential outback market, much less the enormous markets in developing countries, can be accessed.

For these reasons, a `systems' cooperative research centre is viewed by the Northern Territory government as being essential to the problem of providing equitable levels of service to remote outback communities and to the development of a competitive Australian renewable energy electricity generation industry.

The CRC structure provided by the Northern Territory-Western Australian bid is designed to focus Australian renewable energy research and development so that it meets contemporary needs for clean power as efficiently as possible, in the process helping to further reduce the amount of CO2 generated by the electricity supply industry. Involvement of the north Australian utilities, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Centre for Appropriate Technology and the United Nations Industrial Development Organisation Centre for Applications of Solar Energy provides this consortium from Western Australia and the Northern Territory with the tools needed to successfully enhance and commercialise Australia's impressive renewable energy research and development agenda. The international program as outlined in the bid is in itself an exciting prospect.

Members of the consortium behind the bid have been collaborating for several years and there is every reason to believe that the timely support for this process provided by the CRC will enhance the benefits of this collaboration for Australia.

I would certainly commend this proposal and believe it should enjoy the support of the federal government. I would link it to the first issue I addressed today, that of the progress constitutionally of the Northern Territory to statehood. It is as important and also demands active and positive support from the federal government and from this parliament.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 1.53 to 2.00 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before commencing question time, I mention that negotiations are continuing among the parties on the proportion of questions to be allocated to each party, which we hope will be resolved by tomorrow. In the meantime, I will apply the status quo ante.
—Does that mean that we don't get any questions until it is resolved?
—You do.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the dangerous increase in inflation in the September quarter, as measured by both the CPI and the underlying rate. Will the minister confirm that this is the sixth consecutive quarter in which the annual inflation rate has risen and that Australia is now firmly cemented in as having the second highest rate amongst industrialised OECD countries? Will he also confirm that the underlying inflation rate is now above the upper level of the range that the Reserve Bank considers tolerable and acceptable? Does he agree that we now face the worst of all possible worlds—rising inflation, falling economic growth, rising unemployment and inflationary pressure on interest rates? Will he reaffirm the Prime Minister's recent boast that, under this government, `This is as good as it gets'?
—It is a fact that inflation remains historically low and under control despite four years of strong economic growth. Underlying inflation has averaged only 2.1 per cent over the last three years.
—Who wrote this?

—Do you want to deny that? Underlying inflation remains consistent with the official target to average between two and three per cent over the economic cycle. Underlying CPI rose 1.2 per cent in the September quarter and by 3.1 per cent through the year to the September quarter.

PARA.TAB: The underlying inflation rate gives a better indication of inflationary pressures in the economy than the headline inflation rate. However, it is still influenced by one-off factors. The September quarter in part reflected one-off factors such as the increase in wholesale sales tax announced in the 1993-94 budget, which came into effect on 1 July, and the flow-on effects of the increase in the wholesale sales tax on cars in the June quarter.

Headline inflation also reflects the impact of these one-off factors. The measures of price movements in the national accounts confirm that inflation remains low and under control. The non-farm GDP deflator, a broader measure of inflation in the economy than the CPI, rose 2.1 per cent through the year to the June quarter. The annual increase in the non-farm GDP deflator has remained below 2 1/2 per cent for 15 quarters—that is, since the December quarter 1991.

I think the continuing prospect of inflation remaining low is good. As noted in the Reserve Bank's October bulletin, underlying inflation was expected to increase over the year to be a little greater than three per cent. The current growth in underlying inflation is consistent with the official target to average between two and three per cent over the economic cycle.

The Reserve Bank notes that the current monetary policy settings are consistent with the projected trends in growth and inflation. The budget forecast of underlying inflation is 3 1/4 per cent in 1995-96 and four per cent for headline inflation. This is consistent with the Reserve Bank's target for inflation. The expected increase in underlying inflation in 1995-96 is less than we have seen in this last stage of the economic cycle.

I remind the Senate that we have gone through 16 quarters of growth. The last time the mob opposite were in power they not only had a recession but also had inflation at 11.4 per cent in the middle of the recession. They try to lecture us on controlling inflation. They had no wages policy whatsoever. They had an inflation rate which was double digit. They had an unemployment rate which was double digit and they had no economic growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me seek a confirmation from the Acting Leader that the underlying inflation rate has in fact risen in the last quarter by no less than 60 per cent from 1.9 per cent to 3.1 per cent. Will he confirm that it is now above the highest level deemed acceptable and tolerable by the Reserve Bank? Will he also confirm that coming out of the worst recession in Australia in 60 years, which this government imposed on this country, and before any significant recovery in terms of living standards occurs, we now face the worst of all possible worlds of rising inflation, falling economic growth, rising unemployment and inflationary pressures on interest rates? Is that the performance you propose to defend at the next election? (Time expired)

—One thing I can confirm is the absolute distraught nature of Senator Short about the fact that we have had 16 quarters of economic growth. Another thing I can confirm, Senator Short, is that the last time you were in government you botched it entirely. Very few of your colleagues are left there. Those who are have political amnesia of those particular periods.

PARA.TAB: When you left office last time unemployment was beyond 10 per cent, inflation was beyond 11 per cent and interest rates were beyond 11 per cent. As for Senator Short trying to percentage the increase, you can always say if it goes from 0.1 per cent to 0.2 per cent it is a 100 per cent increase. But the way economists approach these matters is they look at the actual figures and describe how much they have risen in percentage points.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct, and you know it.
—You know that, Senator Short, being an ex-Treasury official. You have obviously forgotten anything you then knew.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of the Speaker of the Sindh Provincial Assembly in Pakistan, the Hon. Ghous Bux Khan Mahar. On behalf of honourable senators, I welcome you to the Senate and hope your visit will be enjoyable and productive.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. No doubt the minister is aware of the situation in the current wool market that demonstrates the need for more sophisticated commercial risk management tools. I ask: can the minister advise what action the government intends to take in this regard?

—I am pleased to advise the Senate that the government has accepted a recommendation from Wool International that it conduct a limited two-year program to develop and evaluate the forward marketing of wool. The proposed program builds on Wool International's efforts to stimulate the development of a broader range of risk management options for the sale of wool as required under its act. The wool industry has only limited commercial risk management options presently available to it, and of course the losers in that regard are the growers.

PARA.TAB: The recent volatility in the market demonstrates the need to utilise such instruments to better manage risk. The program does not presuppose any privatisation of Wool International. As I have said before, that will depend on the decisions taken by individual growers as to whether they wish to take equity in any privatisation of Wool International or, indeed, take cash.

I want to stress that this forward marketing operation will be completely independent of the stockpile sales, which will continue according to the fixed schedule. The program will be conducted through Wool International's subsidiary, Wool International Holdings. It will be conducted separately from the ongoing activities of Wool International whose prime responsibility is to manage the stockpile disposal and to discharge the industry debt.

The program will be conducted on strictly commercial terms. Wool International Holdings will only have access to the stockpile on the same commercial basis as any other industry participant. Wool International Holdings will be subject to all the requirements of Corporations Law and all forms of taxation.

Other key points regarding this program are: it will be a stand-alone commercial operation with a two year time frame commencing in 1996; it will be funded from revenue received from the management of non-wool assets as provided for in the existing legislation; no government guarantee is involved; and it will be subject to rigorous risk management requirements. Wool International Holdings will also have separate and transparent accounting. I have also asked the board of Wool International to provide me with quarterly progress reports on the program.

Current circumstances in the wool market highlight the need for better risk management tools for the industry. Wool International has been developing this proposal for some time in direct consultation with an industry contact group. It considered that the development of improved risk management techniques for the benefit of growers was running at a snail's [ace and it needed some impetus. We agreed. After considering the matter, and with the support, I might add, of the executive of the Wool Council, I have agreed to Wool International conducting a limited forward trading operation. I intend to introduce legislation into the current session of the parliament to give effect to this decision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, representing, I hope, everyday Australian families. Last week, Deputy Prime Minister Kim Beazley launched a hypocritical and deceitful advertisement in Perth which says in part:

QUESTION.PARA: The Court Liberal Government has set the minimum weekly wage at $317.10. A family can't live on that!

When Carmen Lawrence lost government in Western Australia the minimum weekly wage was $275.50 which in today's dollars is $17 less than the current Court minimum. How did a family live on that when Dr Lawrence was Premier? I further ask: is it not a fact that under your benchmark federal award the adult minimum for an unskilled employee in the metal trades industry is a mere $238.10 per week? That is a massive $80 a week less than the Western Australia minimum for any state award or agreement. Can the minister explain how a family can live on that? Given your party's recent affirmation supporting truth—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Minister for Family Services, but I am not sure whether it is completely in her area.

—The first thing that needs to be said is that the question is quite properly addressed to Senator Cook, the minister who has responsibility for industrial relations, rather than to me. If Senator Crane wanted to talk about awards, wages, payments and so on, it is properly the substance of a question to the Minister for Industrial Relations. However, if Senator Crane wants to talk about what this government has done for families, I am very happy to talk about it—as I often have. It is quite clear from any studies of this government's actions that the social wage is a supplement to any payment and is valued at about $200 a week.
—It is the position, and what my question is about.
—Senator Crane, it is impossible to talk and listen at the same time.

—It is true that Senator Crane, having asked the question, seems to be totally unconcerned about any answer. It is appropriate for me to comment on the benefits under the social wage which are a supplement to any dollars won under awards or arrangements under the Industrial Relations Act. Matters dealing with industrial relations properly belong to the Minister for Industrial Relations.

—I seek your ruling on this, Mr President, because that question was directed to a statement that is contained in paid ALP advertising—`A family can't live on that!' Are you going to allow Senator Crowley to say that she is entitled to waffle on about the social wage and other related matters, but that this question has nothing to do with family policy? It is quite clearly within her area of responsibility. If she wants to say that she is not prepared to answer it, or she has no answer, that is all right. I invite you, Mr President, to say that a question that asks about a statement that `a family can't live on that' is obviously within the ambit of responsibility of this minister.

—The only way that this question comes within the portfolio of the Minister for Family Services is: what is the government doing to assist families to be able to live on the wages that are set? That is exactly what Senator Crowley is doing. If it is put in any other way, it is a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. If it relates to what the government's family service policies do to assist low paid workers, it is something we are entitled to be proud of and Senator Crane deserves to hear about it. If it is actually about wage rates and awards, it should be directed to Senator Ray.

—I made the point when calling Senator Crowley, except that I was drowned out by the noise, that I did not think this was in her area of responsibility. I still don't think it is, and I think her answer in that sense is relevant.
—Thank you, Mr President. What is relevant is what this government is doing through the social wage, which has always been a critical part of the Accord.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have warned you once before about that, and I won't warn you again, Senator Alston.

—The most important part of the social wage is those family payments that particularly assist low income families. There is the basic family payment and the additional family payment of something like $35 a week tax free for families with children up to 13 years of age and in the $40 range for families with children between 13 and 16 years of age. Those additional family payments, which cost over $12 billion and are targeted to single income, low income families, are the sorts of benefits this government is concerned about in assisting families. This has been a critical part of our concern for families.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is that low income families are assisted through our Medicare arrangements in particular, because low income families do not have to pay the Medicare levy. As well as that, you know the benefits that we made—and if you don't, I will remind you again—for assisting families with educational opportunities for their children.

The social wage is a critical part of this government's assistance to families. To ignore it is to make the sort of case you make all along—you don't take any regard of it and it is the sort of thing you intend to cut if you ever get into government. We have Mr Howard's promises about that and we have your promises about it. Not only will you wreck the arrangements in the industrial relations sphere but you intend to cut additional assistance to families. The assistance we give to families is something we are mightily proud of, and we are not going to cut it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus. Last night you announced that the government would increase its humanitarian program for the financial year to a total of 15,000 places. What are the reasons behind this decision and how will Australia's response assist the international efforts to assist refugees from the conflict in the former Yugoslavia?

—Senator Murphy is right. We have increased our humanitarian program for this financial year. The driving factor for it, the reason for it, has been the situation in the former Yugoslavia—a situation which has led to a large increase in the number of refugees from that area and a situation which, I must say, has attracted the concern, I think, of all Australians, particularly as they see the plight of individuals from the former Yugoslavia night after night on TV news reports.

PARA.TAB: Since the outset of this conflict, Australia has been keen to assist the international community in a number of ways. We have done so in terms of aid and we have done so in offering people displaced by the conflict the chance to build new lives in a peaceful and secure environment. I was pleased last night to be able to announce a decision of cabinet that the government had decided to offer some 2,000 extra places in our humanitarian program this financial year for refugees and displaced persons from the former Yugoslavia. I think it was an extremely appropriate way also to mark UN Day.

The additional 2,000 places, which will be brought forward from the 1996-97 program, will mean that our humanitarian program will offer offshore resettlement to a total of 15,000 people from around the world this year and, together with that, close to 2,000 people will obtain refugee status onshore as well. It will bring the number of former Yugoslav nationals arriving here as humanitarian entrants this financial year from 5,650 to more than 7,600, which is just more than half of our total program.

Senator Murphy asked the reasons for this decision. They do go directly to the conflict in the former Yugoslavia. In July this year, for instance, the UNHCR launched an international appeal for countries to provide an extra 5,000 resettlement or temporary protection places. On 14 October, in response to new developments in the region gravely affecting a new group of refugees, the UNHCR had to revise its figures and appealed for a further 20,000 places in 1995 and another 25,000 places in 1996.

Australia has been responsive to the situation. We value our close relationship with the UNHCR. We have been keen to respond to this appeal without disadvantaging those in need from other parts of the world, particularly the Middle East and Africa, and our own region. All up, those who have come to Australia this financial year will join 14,000 people who arrived from the former Yugoslavia region as humanitarian entrants since 1992.

An important aspect, as I announced last night, is that people who have come here and who will be coming here will come under the three components of our multifaceted humanitarian program: the refugee program, the humanitarian program and the special assistance category. This comes on top of the $3 million of additional aid to this region, which the Prime Minister announced quite recently. Together, the responses amount to a major commitment on behalf of the Australian people.

I place on the record that the UNHCR has recognised Australia's position. I will table a letter in a few minutes. I indicate that they appreciate what Australia has been doing, particularly at a time when other governments were becoming more restrictive.

As I said, the Australian humanitarian program is an important part of our response to international distress situations. We have the highest per capita program in the world. It is flexible and can respond to situations like this only because of the commitment and support of so many people in the Australian community. Volunteers, church based organisations and the like assist people. Together with government, they provide the most comprehensive settlement program of any country in the world in respect of people in distress. I acknowledge that these people make a huge contribution when they get here. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. He will recall that in March 1995, during a debate on schools funding, he agreed there was a question about the legality of state schools charging voluntary fees, levies or, more accurately, taxes. The Sydney Morning Herald has reported that in New South Wales parents are being forced to pay $43 million for what are described as voluntary fees. These fees are administered inconsistently, with variation between subjects, schools and regions. Parents groups in other states tell me that their situation is also unfair. What has the minister done to clarify the legality of this situation? What is the government's position on this matter?

—I recollect that debate. First of all, decisions about levels of school fees for government schools are matters for state and territory governments. The key issue is not whether parents are prepared to pay such fees—recent press reports indicate that most appear to be prepared to do so—but whether the imposition of such fees creates hardship for disadvantaged students. There is also the question of what effect these fees might have on student decisions about choosing subjects and continuing on to year 12.

PARA.TAB: These issues have been raised recently by both Senator Bell and parent and student groups to Minister Crean and Minister Free. As the question of school fees has been a matter for the states, the Commonwealth has no detailed information about their application by schools. The Commonwealth ministers are seeking, and have sought, advice from the state and territory government ministers of education about these issues. When that information is available, they will make it available to Senator Bell and the Senate.

I understand that today a letter along those lines will be sent to Senator Bell in accordance with the letter he sent to me earlier this month. When the advice comes back from the states about their information and what they have on their own database about their arrangements and policy towards these fees, we will then be able to respond to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Is the minister aware of public concern over the drive by oil companies to push multi-site franchises on the petrol industry? What impact has this action had on small garage owners? What is the minister going to do about it?

—I thank Senator Carr for his question on what has been a complex issue of some controversy over the last year or so in this industry. First of all I should explain that a multi-site franchise, sometimes called a retail area franchise, is essentially a franchise where one dealer operates a number of sites. I am advised that the Mobil company has about five in what it would consider a multi-site and the Shell company has around 20.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the argument in the industry on this issue, you have the views of the petrol retailers and franchisees, particularly the Shell National Action Group, which is made up of retailers, and which argues that such moves to multi-site franchising arrangements will have a range of outcomes which they believe will be negative. They argue that a multi-site franchise is anti-competitive in that it allows a single dealer to effectively determine a retail price in that market area. They also claim that in many cases the multi-site franchise operator is financed by the franchisor and that the latter has a de facto control over the market.

The oil companies' view is quite different. The oil companies argue that moves towards MSF are a necessary part of restructuring in the industry which will lead to greater efficiencies, higher levels of training and service and greater profitability. The Trade Practices Commission has announced that they are currently investigating this issue and are likely to form a view in the near future. My view is that it is essential that the key players in this dispute in the industry have an opportunity to argue their case openly in the public interest. Accordingly, I have referred this matter to the House of Representatives industry committee for consideration and advice. I will meet with the chairman, Mr Griffiths, to arrange the terms of reference for such an inquiry. That will give both sides a chance to argue their case and the public can judge the merits of the issue.

I have also called on today the companies to have a moratorium on the further development of multi-site franchising at least until the Trade Practices Commission comes down with a considered view. The introduction of MSF at the moment has affected the completion of an agreement on a voluntary oil code between the franchisees and the petrol companies. That petrol code, substantially agreed upon, would be of major benefit to both sides of the industry and would enhance the building of trust within the industry, but unfortunately a number of the retailers' interests believe that MSF at the same time means that they are not quite certain exactly what is going to be the outcome of such a code. Therefore, I believe it would be in the interests of the industry overall if there were a moratorium, at least until the Trades Practices Commission comes down with its view. In the meantime I believe it is important that both sides of the industry, where there is considerable controversy on this issue, have a chance to put their views publicly, which they will be able to do before the House of Representatives industry committee.

I also on behalf of the government urge both sides of this industry to reach as soon as possible an agreement on a new voluntary petroleum code, which is much needed by this very important industry in the Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, on Monday you said that you were amongst those Cabinet ministers who believed it was appropriate to encourage the market to work efficiently when it comes to the investment of superannuation funds. Yesterday Mr Willis maintained his position that the government would not force or mandate superannuation funds for trustees to invest in particular areas. But today we learn that Mr Keating believes that because the Labor government has given $6 billion in tax concessions to the superannuation industry it has, to use his words, `heaps of prerogative over how the industry is run'. In fact, Mr Keating said: `Where are the greater prerogatives in this than in the hands of the Prime Minister' and further adds, `or in the hands of the trade unions?' What is the government's policy on mandating the development of superannuation funds and what form of intimidation will your encouragement take? Is Mr Keating making policy on the run again and, if so, do you support his new position on this vital issue?

—The answer to the first question is no. The answer to the second question is: there is no answer because the first question is inappropriate. The answer to the third question is no, and there is no answer to the fourth question because it is inappropriate. They are the answers to the questions.

PARA.TAB: For those who are listening to this broadcast, and there are probably very few of them, I might just say there is a very clear distinction between encouraging by doing things such as the government did just recently in requiring the funds to publish a five-year rolling average of their investment outcomes rather than having a short-term approach of only doing it on a one-year basis. I take that as an encouragement in regulatory legislation to look beyond the horizon of one year to the medium-term future. That is an encouragement device, as opposed to directing. You have confused both of those, and blurred the distinction quite unconscionably, I might say.

But the Prime Minister is on the record, the Treasurer is on the record, I am on the record and, as I have said, so is the Finance minister and, I believe, most of the cabinet. But, in any case, the government's position—which is also on the record—is that we are not going to direct superannuation funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator McMullan, has the government abandoned moves to gaol journalists, editors or media proprietors for publishing information on Australia's security intelligence matters? Will the minister confirm that representatives of the Defence Intelligence Organisation, the Department of Defence, the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet have met with editors of print and electronic media to discuss an industry code for the publication of stories relating to national security? If so, can you outline what negotiations have taken place and what is the proposal that has been put to the media outlets about the clearance of stories on national security issues? Does this proposal include a requirement that no reporting is to occur of the negotiations themselves between the government and media outlets about such stories?

—I think most senators would agree that the disclosure of sensitive national security information by any Australian is a serious matter. The government is committed to taking whatever steps are necessary, including legislation if that is necessary, to ensure that our security interests are fully protected. It is important, I think, and appropriate to remind the Senate—although most senators would be aware—that there are already secondary disclosure provisions in the Commonwealth Crimes Act. They are not recent initiatives. But both the Gibbs and Samuels inquiries recommended changes to make these provisions more workable, so it was an issue we had to address on the basis of those two recommendations.

PARA.TAB: It is true that senior officials have conducted an extensive series of high level consultations with the media on the future of a voluntary D-notice system. I do not think you got all the details of who was involved in that negotiation quite right, but the fact that they have been happening is true.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not DIO.

—The Minister for Defence, who would know these things, says that DIO was not involved, so I am sure that is correct. They are not included in the list that I have seen. I do not have a comprehensive list, but I accept obviously the minister's indication. But of course there have been discussions. You would be stunned if there were not; it would be entirely inappropriate if there were not. The government has been pleased with the constructive approach taken by media representatives.

PARA.TAB: The results of these consultations are now under consideration. There has not even been a report to ministers yet, so there is certainly no government proposal. There has not been a report put to ministers; we expect that next month. We hope that the media will continue to engage in constructive discussion on these and related matters. Consultation has included the editors of the major national dailies and television stations, the Press Council and the Media, Arts and Entertainment Alliance.

It certainly has not been a secret set of consultations. It would be pretty hard to have secret consultations with all of those people—in fact with any one of them. But the emphasis the government has put on these discussions has been on a consultative process and on a voluntary and cooperative D-notice system. All the issues, I think, are on the table for discussion, and ministers are expecting a report early next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and clarification. Is it true that if, under this proposal, media outlets agree to be involved in the negotiation process, the government will agree not to take out injunctions against them?

—I am not aware of any such proposal. It certainly has not been drawn to my attention, but I will check whether that is the case. If there is some information I can add, I will provide it, but I am not aware of any such proposal. I think if there was such a proposal I would have been aware of it, but I cannot say that absolutely so I will confirm it if I can.

—My question is addressed to Senator Collins. I ask: two years ago, when the government introduced a one-third reduction of AQIS staff, why did you let all plant quarantine officers take redundancy? Do you think this was responsible management at a time when imports were increasing by 40 per cent? Did not the absence of plant technologists coincide with the introduction of serious diseases like thrip and white fly into Australia? How many plant technologists are presently in AQIS?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Here is another chance to get it right.
—It certainly is, Senator Hill. I am delighted to get this question from Senator Boswell about AQIS resources.
—It might be a better answer than we have had recently.

—It will be a good answer, Mr President. Senator Boswell misled this Senate last week. That is all right; I will give you the quote. He is continuing to mislead the Queensland media, which are continuing to run this garbage, and I had to respond to some of it this morning. On this question of AQIS resources, this is what he told the Senate last week:
