That is right. I am glad you are nodding your head, Senator Boswell.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can hear it.

—You can hear it. Good. The two pieces of absolute garbage that you are feeding out on this issue are, one, that we changed it from a no risk policy to an acceptable risk policy. So back in the good old days of the coalition government, we had—
—When was that?
—A long time ago—a no risk policy—
—And you have five other diseases.

—And quarantine officers running out of our ears in the Torres Strait. The two pieces of nonsense that are being pushed again here today are that we changed the policy from no risk to acceptable risk in 1988, and we have reduced the resources available in the quarantine area from the good old days of the coalition government.

PARA.TAB: I did a little bit of homework and I came up with this. This is a Senate report, Senator Boswell, from 1978. This is 16 years old, this report, back in the good old days of the Fraser government, with a coalition majority. It is titled, interestingly enough—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you forgotten this, Ron?
—He has forgotten it all right—The adequacy of quarantine. I will just refer you two sections. The chapter on the Torres Strait, back in the good old days of a coalition government—
—Give me an answer to my question. I did not ask about that!
—Order! Senator Boswell, you will do yourself some harm.

—Yes, I can understand your being a bit distressed about this being delivered. I hope that the media that are reporting your nonsense in Queensland listen to this as well, Senator Boswell. It was chaired by a Liberal from Western Australia. On the question—have a listen—of no risk to acceptable risk, the good old days of no risk in the coalition, the report states:

ANSWER.PARA: The shorthand term `no risk' is widely applied to Australia's quarantine policy. The use of this term is misleading and is not accepted by the quarantine authorities as an accurate—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I asked a question about 1995, not 1979. I do not think the Senate or anyone else is interested in what happened in 1979.
—Order! The answer is perfectly relevant because it is referring specifically to the no risk policy.
—I will continue:

ANSWER.PARA: In practice—
Listen, Senator Boswell—

any international trade or travel contains an element of quarantine risk. The function of the quarantine service is to assess the likely risk a disease or pest poses to this country, to consider probable means of entry and, in the light of these factors, to produce policies aimed at their exclusion.
The final sentence is—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order.
—You don't want to hear it.

—No, no. There is an appropriate time for that, but this is not it. The question was: what happened two years ago when you cut the staff of AQIS and the relationship between cutting the staff of AQIS under a Labor administration and, apparently, the introduction of these particular pests. There is no way what occurred in a Senate report years and years ago can be relevant to this particular question, as asked in this form today, Mr President. I therefore respectfully request that you ask him to have a go at answering the question that was asked, rather than debating a Senate report of some decade and a half ago.
—The minister is entitled to refer to reports to define issues. That is what he is trying to do.
—To conclude on what the coalition do not want to hear, the final sentence is:

ANSWER.PARA: A more accurate description of quarantine policy would be the scientific evaluation of `acceptable risk'.
On the chapter dealing with the Torres Strait, I will quote this paragraph:
The present situation—
This is resources—

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not ask about the Torres Strait.

—Mr President, on a point of order: when Senator Boswell first raised the point of order, you said that the minister's answer was in order on the basis that he was addressing the issue of zero risk. I have just re-read Senator Boswell's question and the words `zero risk' do not appear in the question. So, quite clearly, in your own judgment, Mr President, this answer has to be totally and utterly irrelevant, as is the minister. I would put it to you that he should be directed to answer the substantive question, which is about what he has done to the resources of AQIS and why he has allowed plant quarantine officers to take redundancy. It is about his mismanagement—not about something that happened when I was in secondary school.
—Notwithstanding your overexcitement, I have ruled twice on that.
—I will talk about downgrading resources from the good old days of the coalition when we had quarantine officers to burn—and I will read the paragraph:

PARA.TAB: The present situation with a single quarantine officer located at Thursday Island is insufficient and unsatisfactory.

ANSWER.PARA: As I told the Senate yesterday, we now have 12 quarantine officers located in the Torres Strait and a further five at Cairns who also work in the Torres Strait.

PARA.TAB: So the only way that we would be able to downgrade quarantine resources in the Torres Strait to below the position they were in when the coalition ran AQIS would be to take them down to zero—zero! One quarantine officer, Senator Boswell, in the Torres Strait, under your administration!(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think even you would have to agree that is the most inane, stupid answer to any question that has ever been given in this place. But let me just ask one, simple supplementary question, which should not be difficult for even the minister to answer: how many plant technologists are presently employed at AQIS—one, two, none or what?

—The relevant answer to this question I in fact gave the Senate yesterday—and Senator Boswell does not like it because it contradicts the nonsense that I have just exposed that he is continuing to push in Queensland—that under this administration AQIS has significantly increased the quarantine resources in the Torres Strait from one under the coalition to 12.
—My question is directed to the minister representing the minister for—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Take your seat, Senator Reynolds, until things are quiet.

—My question is directed to the minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Can the minister inform the Senate of the government's progress in implementing the national rural health strategy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senator for this question because it allows me to tell the Senate about the recent initiatives in the national rural health strategy which was initiated by this government in 1994.

PARA.TAB: The government has now established the Office of Rural Health within the Department of Human Services and Health in response to the concerns of many rural health stakeholders, including the Rural Health Alliance.

Rural health policy involves all areas within the department and the Office of Rural Health will provide an appropriate contact point for a lot of questions about rural health that did not have any particular point of focus before.

It is a very important part of this ongoing rural health strategy which addresses the health needs of people living in rural areas of Australia and the challenges facing rural health providers. Although it is a Commonwealth-state program, its initiative is very much a Commonwealth one.

It strengthens the rural health programs—for example: the GP rural incentive program; and the rural health support education and training program. Many of the reforms are to encourage medical schools to attract more country students to their courses because, on the evidence we have to this point, students from the country, once finishing their medical studies, are turning out to be more likely to be the people who would return to country practice.

We have a challenge from the opposition here, because last Wednesday we got from Senator Herron, in between a pretty reasonable speech about this, a remarkable slip—I have to say, Senator—about what the opposition's view is on this area. In explaining why there are not enough doctors in the country, Senator Herron said:

ANSWER.PARA: More than half the number of medical students now are female and, inevitably, they get married. They usually marry non-medical people and they stay in the cities. In bulk-billing clinics female doctors can earn an income and raise their families at the same time, and this, in turn, has had a compounding effect—
not all in the one room, I hope—

There is a dramatic shortage of doctors in the country areas because half the graduates are now female and they marry and stay in the cities. Female doctors do not want to go to the country, understandably, because of their family situation.
Senator, I have seen women blamed for lots of things but to blame them for the lack of doctors in the country area is very strange indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise to a point of order: Senator Crowley used the word `blame'. There was no blame. I was stating a matter of fact. She has imputed blame and she has imputed incorrect motives to me. It is incorrect to state it.
—Order! It is not a point of order. But you are awfully sensitive too, I must say, Senator.

—On the point of order: Mr President, on two occasions you have cast aspersions on the motives of members of the opposition here—gratuitously. It is not your place to cast aspersions on any motives of anybody on this side. I would ask you, Mr President, to regard your own position.

—On the point of order, Mr President: I will leave you to deal directly with Senator Herron's point, but it still raises a secondary matter of Senator Herron raising what he knows is not a point of order. There are other forms of the house in which he can make that point. He is also interrupting question time. Really, that was not a point of order. I will leave it to you to comment on the other matter.

—I think there is a difference between a facetious comment and a reflection on somebody. However, by comparison with the very rude and offensive reflections that are frequently made on me, it pales into insignificance.

—Sensitive indeed is the opposition on this point. It is important to have the opportunity to put the record straight. I think this would be of interest to you, Senator Herron, in particular. Women do practice country medicine. Under the rural—

—On the point of order: I am sorry, Mr President, I thought Senator Crowley wanted to contribute to the debate on the point of order. I would just invite you to consider your response to Senator Herron and perhaps come back at another time, when you are not so offended by what he said—perhaps you are a little thin-skinned yourself, some might think—and give an indication as to whether you are saying that you think it is appropriate for the President of this chamber to make what you describe yourself as `facetious' remarks about senators, at your whim.
—I have already commented. I will be making no further comment.

—What I want to say is very important: women do practice in rural Australia. Under our GP rural incentive scheme, 67 women have been relocated from the city to the country compared with 163 men. So already the program is clearly successful in encouraging general practitioners into rural Australia. That is so very important in terms of our rural health program. The Labor government is implementing this strategy to meet the health needs in non-metropolitan areas.
—That was my point.

—No, it wasn't, Senator. Your point was ridiculous; your point was silly—and you know that. You would like to have it again and make the same kind of sensible other points that you were making in the same speech. But you lost the plot on that quote. Women are going into country practice; so are men. That is one of the most important things. It has been a regular complaint. There have been questions asked by some of our National Party colleagues in the Senate. We are addressing it under our national rural health strategy. There are more doctors now returning to general practice in rural Australia, and that is the intention of our program. It is the request from rural communities. This government is absolutely committed to seeing that it happens.

—My question is to Senator Cook, the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, I refer to the ALP's tax policy for the next election. Will this policy rule out increasing existing taxes and the introduction of new taxes?
—To the best of my knowledge, we have not formulated our tax policy for the next election but, when we do, we will announce it. However, what you can be sure of—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please take your seat, Senator, and let us have a bit of quiet before you start again.
—What you can be sure of is that our policy will continue the tradition we have installed in government of this country; that is, to minimise the tax burden on ordinary Australians.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, take your seat again, and we will wait for some more silence.
—To minimise the tax burden on ordinary Australians, senators will know—

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I have asked, even for Senator Cook, a very straightforward question. The question is: will the ALP's tax policy rule out increasing existing taxes and the introduction of new taxes? It is a central part of a tax policy. What we want to hear is a straightforward answer, a yes or no answer, from Senator Cook.
—There is no point of order, and you know it.

—What our policies will obviously do—and the opposition do not want to hear this—is continue the fine record of achievement of this government in lowering the level of taxation. We have reduced the level of taxation borne by ordinary Australians to well below the level they had to put up with when the coalition were in government and when the Treasurer of Australia was Mr Howard, who is now the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Our tax policies will be aimed at continuing to achieve that goal and to maintain our ranking among developed countries of the world, which is the second lowest taxing economy in the whole of the OECD. That is what we have achieved, and our objectives will be to maintain that structure. I am sure that our election policy will focus directly on that.

However, it is an odd thing that this question should come from Senator Rod Kemp, because yesterday I had a question from Senator Amanda Vanstone on tax as well. I also had a question from one of my own backbenchers, Senator Jones, about the secret deals that the Liberal Party is engaged in with state Premiers in the states of Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. We had this game yesterday.
—You are sucked in again.

—You will concede that I have a right to request that he be kept to relevant answers. The question related to the government's tax policy. What was interesting was that yesterday the minister said, `Our tax policy is on the table.' Today he said, `We haven't developed it.' If he wants to expand that point and explain it, he can.
—Come to your point of order.
—He has no right within the terms of that question to debate opposition policy. I ask you to require him to answer in accordance with the standing orders.

—Mr President, on the point of order: Senator Cook has been asked about the government's intention to introduce new taxes. That was the substance and the effect of Senator Kemp's question. In canvassing any new tax that Senator Kemp may be contemplating, I think it is quite within order for Senator Cook to go to any new taxes that might have been mooted in recent days, particularly state based consumption taxes and state based income taxes—all matters that were raised by the opposition shadow Treasurer in an article in the Business Review Weekly—and to give the government's position in respect of those. Senator Kemp asked about new taxes. It is obvious that the new taxes the opposition would be thinking about are the ones that their shadow Treasurer has mentioned. It is quite pertinent for Senator Cook to address those taxes.
—Order! I would ask Senator Cook to address the—

—Mr President, on the point of order: you will note the question was very specific. There were no embellishments. It was a straightforward question: what is the ALP's tax policy? A simple yes or no answer would solve the problem. It had nothing to do with any other taxes; it had to do with your tax policy.
—Order! I would ask the minister to address the question directly and not to debate the issue.

—I was saying that I was asked a question on taxes yesterday by Senator Vanstone and by Senator Jones. The question from Senator Jones referred to the article about the Liberals radical new tax plan that appeared in the Business Review Weekly—

—Mr President, I take a point of order. It is very clear that the minister is deliberately flouting your ruling. He is now, by his own admission, referring to yesterday's question and not this question, the most simple of questions that he could have been asked by Senator Kemp. Clearly he should be directed to be relevant.
—On the point of order, Senator Kemp asked Senator Cook to speculate on what Labor Party tax policy would be at the next election.
—No, he didn't.
—Yes, he did. What Senator Cook is doing right now is saying what it won't be.
—I have already asked Senator Cook not to debate the issue; and I think he is starting to do that. I ask him to get back to the answer.
—Senator Jones's question is, `Would we do what was proposed in this article?' This question is, `What is our policy at the next election?'
—Order! You make things very difficult for me, I must say.

—Senator Jones has asked me whether we would do what is proposed in this Liberals radical new tax plan? Senator Kemp's question is about what we might do at the next election. Therefore, I take this new Liberals radical secret tax plan as being part of the things that might be at the back of the mind of Senator Kemp when he asked the question.

—On a point of order, this minister has had about four opportunities to comply with your very clear and specific ruling. You have the power to tell him that he should be no longer heard; and I invite you to say that enough is enough.

—On the same point of order, the only way that any tax plan mooted by the opposition is not relevant for Senator Cook to address is if the tax measures that the opposition has been contemplating are irrelevant to the Australian public. If the opposition maintains they are relevant, then they are relevant in Senator Cook's answer. If the opposition maintains that the measures are not relevant to Senator Cook's answer, these tax plans are as irrelevant as the opposition. It is quite appropriate for Senator Cook to canvass them in terms of what taxes—
—Order! You have made your point of order. I think you can answer this question very directly and I am asking Senator Cook to do so.
—One of the things that we will not include at the next election is a proposal for a state income tax or a state consumption tax.
—I take a point of order.
—Order! That is what he was asked to answer.
—That is precisely what you have told him he cannot do. If I asked you what you are going to do—
—Take a seat. I know what you have said; and you are wrong.

—It is one of the things we will not do, as the Prime Minister made clear overnight when he referred to the possibility of a referendum in Australia to ensure that the income tax provisions that are now conducted by the Commonwealth are not devolved to the states. Yesterday I said that under the vertical fiscal imbalance proposal that the shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, is so keen on—
—Order! Senator Cook, you are now debating the issue again. I have asked you not to do that.
—Mr President, I will keep to order. It would mean a state income tax of $25 billion being raised by the states—a new tax at that.
—Order! Senator Cook, I ask you to take your seat. I call Senator Spindler.
—I am in order.
—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question.
—I have just ruled that answer out of order. Is there any point in the supplementary?

—I think the Australian community and those who are watching these TV broadcasts would have been fascinated by the ducking and weaving that Senator Cook indulged in, in trying to avoid giving a very straightforward answer to a straightforward question. Senator Cook, the question that we want you to address—and you have a minute to do it—is, `Will your tax policy rule out increasing existing taxes and the introduction of new taxes?' That is the question I put to you. You have urged the coalition to bring forward its policies. Bring forward yours and give us the answer to that question. The Australian people want an answer now.

—Thank you for the heroics. What I have said is that we will continue our policy of reducing the burden of income tax where we can. We have a fine record of achievement on that subject and where we can we will continue to do that. We certainly will not be stampeded by excitable and dramatic pronouncements from the opposition about our policy. We are the low tax party and you are the high tax party.
—You are a hypocrite, Elmer.
—The other thing we will not do is devolve income tax to the states, as you are considering doing under a proposal secretly being hashed out between the coalition—

—I take a point of order. Mr President, I think you clearly heard Senator Faulkner's interjection when he called Senator Kemp a hypocrite. This is from a minister who has actually reduced sports funding for next year by $34 million and has refused to make an announcement about it.
—Order! You have made your point of order. I ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw that.
—I withdraw.
—This secret plan would mean a new income tax for the states of $25 billion.
—A point of order!
—Order! Senator Cook take your seat.

—I heard you ask Senator Faulkner to withdraw. He has not risen in his seat. He has not said in an audible voice that anyone can hear, let alone Hansard, that he withdraws. I think that if you are going to maintain decorum you must insist that this minister comply with your orders.
—I really despair of this chamber.
—On the point of order: if that is going to be the case—
—We are always asked to stand to withdraw.

—It is often not the case. If you want to rule in future that when someone withdraws they must get to their feet and say, `I withdraw unreservedly,' and limit their comments to that, this chamber would be better off.
—In the interests of Senate harmony, Senator Faulkner, would you stand and withdraw that statement unconditionally.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—We will continue to be the low taxing party and you will continue to be high taxing party. We will not adopt your secret plan being worked out with state Liberal premiers to impose a state based income tax. We will not cop your secret deal about a state—

—I take a point of order. This is really getting too much. We have asked Senator Cook twice a very straightforward question about the ALP's tax policy. Why does he keep ducking and weaving? Can you not tell us in clear terms whether the ALP policy will rule out increasing existing taxes and the introduction of new taxes?
—Order! That is not a point of order. You have made your statement.
—Mr President—
—Order! Your time has expired. I call Senator Spindler.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I have called Senator Spindler.

—I take a point of order. You had a point of order put to you by Senator Kemp and you have not ruled on it. I want to address you on that point of order. Senator Kemp is out of order in pretending that that was a point of order. He has got up and used the device in the standing orders of a point of order to make a speech and to reiterate his loony, stupid and idiotic ideas about tax. He is out of order. The device of a point of order has been misused by him and by other members on the other side several times during question time. If you do not mind, I would ask you in the future when they start to lurch into making speeches that you sit them down.

—On the point of order: if you are going to rule on that, you might also rule on the ministers' abusing question time every day by giving four minute diatribes, never answering the questions and simply making political statements. You are going to make those sorts of rulings—
—On your motion, Bonehead!

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Take your seats! I ask you to look at yourselves and look at what a rabble you are being in front of everybody. I have said this before, but it is honestly true. What do people in the gallery think of this behaviour, for God's sake? You could have saved your breath earlier because I had already ruled that that was not a point of order. It clearly was not, as most points of order are not. People know that.
—I take a point of order: is the use of the words `for God's sake', which you used a moment ago, unparliamentary?
—I call Senator Spindler.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade, and I am confident that the minister can answer these questions. Can the minister advise when the report by the tripartite working party on labour conditions will be available for tabling in parliament? Is the topic of labour conditions and, in particular, child labour on the agenda for the forthcoming meeting of APEC in Osaka? Will the Australian government press for the inclusion of social clauses and the establishment of an APEC subcommittee at the Osaka meeting to ensure that labour conditions, environmental safeguards and social consequences of any APEC agreement are properly addressed?

—It makes a pleasant change to get other than from our own side a question that actually raises some issues of public policy. The working party is scheduled to report in about December. It has been working to its own timetable, not one that we have specified. It is weighing up over 20 major submissions from a range of union and industry groups and government and non-government organisations. I expect the report in December.

PARA.TAB: At this stage I do not expect the issue of trade and labour standards to be on the agenda for Osaka. You referred to social clauses, Senator Spindler. This is an idea that arose from a misapprehension. We have something which you could call social clauses—it is not a title I would give it—in NAFTA. There is debate about one in the WTO. These are formal agreements of treaty or similar type into which people enter. This is not what we are talking about.

In APEC there is no such proposal for a formal binding agreement into which people enter and where everybody signs a treaty or type of agreement. It is really an indication of shared commitment and coordinated voluntary actions by governments. So we will not have clauses in that sense because it is not that sort of agreement.

Nevertheless, your other point, with regard to the subcommittee, is important because it raises issues to do with labour standards and environment being considered in APEC. Yes, they are being considered but not by one separate compartmentalised committee. There are a number of committees looking at issues to do with human resources and strategies to improve workers' conditions, training, education of workers, et cetera, in the various APEC working groups, particularly the human resources development working group.

There are also APEC bodies, such as the energy working group and the tourism working group both of which I am advised are looking at environmental aspects of APEC. Of course, the APEC environment ministers meet regularly to discuss environment issues within the region. I do not think we should compartmentalise it off into one separate committee that only looks at those issues. But they are matters that are being considered by some of the existing working groups, and I imagine that will continue to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer. Can he tell us whether he is confident that these discussions will be reflected in whatever agreement is made at APEC? I know he cannot do it in the space of this time so perhaps he can take it on notice, but would he be able to outline the position that Australia is taking on these matters in the negotiations at APEC?

—While there are really no negotiations on these issues in APEC, I am very happy to outline the government's position on this. I will send Senator Spindler a copy of the very good speech I made about it last week.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen The Hon R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Campbell asked about youth suicide funding. The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following information:

ANSWER.PARA: The government established a youth suicide prevention initiative to which $12.9 million was allocated over a four year period. This initiative commenced at the beginning of the current financial year.

PARA.TAB: In August 1995, the government released a strategy and plan of action for the initiative. The youth suicide initiative is aimed at the overall reduction of youth suicide in the longer term, and the development of best practice policy and service delivery models of national significance in the shorter term. Given the complexity of the issue being addressed, a variety of national demonstration projects are being set up. These will be thoroughly evaluated prior to dissemination throughout Australia.
A former subcommittee of the National Health and Medical Research Council had been considering the problem of youth suicide for some time. The NHMRC dissolved this subcommittee.

As part of the implementation of the government's program, a Youth Suicide Advisory Group including expert, consumer, youth and indigenous membership has been established and met first on 6 October 1995. Projects under the initiative to be commenced this financial year include:

ANSWER.PARA: Support for general practitioners and community health personnel in identifying, referring and treating young people with mental illness and young people at high risk of suicide. This project is currently proceeding to tender and is expected to be advertised in early November;
An initiative in rural areas to prevent and respond to suicide. The tender for this will be advertised in December of this year;

Development and demonstration of hospital and health service protocols. This project is already established under the auspices of a working group and tenders for implementation will be advertised in early April 1996;and
Intervention programs for young people who have attempted suicide or have suicidal tendencies. This project will be advertised for tender in February, 1996.

The budget for this financial year is $1.3 million and it is envisaged that this money will be spent initiating several projects. The remainder of the $12.9 million will be spent over the next three financial years.

PARA.TAB: In summary, the nature of the youth suicide initiative is such that it dovetails with many other initiatives including the national mental health strategy. Projects are being carefully planned and established in keeping with the seriousness and complexity of the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Thursday, Senator Chamarette asked me a question regarding my decision to grant a new permit allowing Pasminco Metals EZ to continue to dump jarosite at sea until the end of 1997. In her question Senator Chamarette asked if it was true that my predecessor, Mrs Kelly, had written to Pasminco informing it that no future extensions of the licence would occur. In a supplementary question Senator Chamarette asked me to table all correspondence between Minister Kelly and Pasminco regarding the dumping licence.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the letter that Senator Chamarette was referring to is Mrs Kelly's letter advising Pasminco of the granting of a sea-dumping permit for the period from 1 November 1991 to 31 October 1995. I table that letter. This letter makes it quite clear that the government was seeking to end sea dumping as soon as possible. The letter also expresses Mrs Kelly's wish to set an agreed date for the cessation of sea dumping. It does not state that no further licences would be issued, as I think was suggested by Senator Chamarette in her question.

The government has closely followed Pasminco's efforts to develop an alternative to sea dumping. As I said last week, I am convinced that the extra time is necessary for the implementation of the co-treatment process and that this process will provide the best long-term results for the environment. I hope that tabling this letter will satisfy Senator Chamarette's request and that it will not be necessary to look back at all the other correspondence over the period when Mrs Kelly was minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On 31 August, in question time, I asked Senator Cook a question about the Reserve Bank which he took on notice. I wish to ask Senator Cook why he has still not answered that question 55 days later and when he will answer it.

—I was asked a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. The routine attention is that these questions then go to the Treasury or the Treasurer's office and are returned to me, and I answer them on the Treasurer's behalf. I understand that on this occasion there has been some delay. I will see what the delay is and, indeed, answer the question as soon as possible.

—Thank you, Minister. As you know, on 31 August I did ask you that question in your capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. I find it astounding that it has taken 55 days to confirm an issue which is of paramount importance to all Australians—that is, to confirm that the Reserve Bank still has an unequivocal policy and resolve of acting as lender of last resort to all Australian trading and savings banks.
—Senator Watson, you actually need leave to speak again on this issue. Are you seeking leave to do so?
—I seek leave.
—Is leave granted?
—Why? This is just a stunt!
—Yes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far from it being a stunt, this issue was not only raised at question time, it was subsequently raised by me in this parliament during a debate on the adjournment. There has been plenty of toing and froing by the Treasury and by the Reserve Bank. People are starting to get a little bit nervous because it is a simple matter of confirmation of a situation which has existed for a very long time.

PARA.TAB: There is a lot of doubt in the community about the extent now of this underwriting or being lender of last resort. It is a matter of priority, and I seek from you, Minister, that you will give it greater priority than it has been given at the present time, given the urgency of the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to industrial relations in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In that question I addressed four fundamental points. The first point was the deceitful advertising that has occurred in Western Australia, particularly relevant being the comments in the adverts that `the Court Liberal government has set the minimum weekly wage at $317.10 a week. A family can't live on that!' I addressed my question to Senator Crowley because I thought that, with that situation in that ad, and the reference to families she would be in a position to answer it, but she couldn't.

PARA.TAB: The second point of my question relates to the situation which existed with Carmen Lawrence and the position then. The third point I wanted her to address was the fact that, under the current metal trades industry award—clause 9 of the award, if you want to know—the current unskilled minimum weekly wage rate is $238.10, which is $79 less than the WA minimum. It is well worth mentioning the fact that under Queensland law they have a minimum rate of $250 a week, which is some $67 less than the situation which exists in Western Australia.

This, as I have said before, is one of the most deceitful efforts ever by this government in misleading the Australian public as to what a situation is. In putting these ads together, they have obviously not even bothered to look at the history of just Western Australia. If we look at Western Australia, we find very clearly that since 1987, when Brian Burke was Premier of Western Australia, the minimum wage has been coming down consistently.

In fact, if we go back to 4 January 1980, when Sir Charles Court was Premier, we find that that particular minimum wage was at its highest then. It was not until the Liberal Court government was elected in Western Australia on 20 August 1994 that we saw the minimum wage in Western Australia start to reverse in terms of its position. And we had the increase last week of $16 per week placed on that, which is double what the Accord will deliver next March, some five months before that particular situation.

I want to put on the public record the situation which exists in the metal trades industry. An amount of $238.10 per week is the Labor Party's benchmark award in terms of minimum standards. Senator Murphy knows that very well. I have already discovered in Western Australia 16 other minimum rates between $238.10 and $280 operating under federal awards. The article of 17 October says that the ALP is to support honest political advertising laws. It mentions ALP national secretary Gary Gray. He says that the ALP could also outlaw controversial campaign tactics.

What we have seen perpetrated following the blockade in WA is this action on advertising. We had industrial civil war declared on Western Australia by the trade union movement. I believe that it was supported by this Labor government. When you start examining the facts, you find that the Labor Party's performance in terms of minimum standards has been very poor when it is compared with what exists in Western Australia. Compare it with the present state government or the government prior to Richard Court getting into power.

The Labor Party's federal performance is also very poor. Even the state Labor government in Western Australia did better than this federal Labor government has in terms of that situation. Mr Gary Gray is trying to mislead the Australian public with regard to truth in advertising. I find absolutely disgraceful and unacceptable what they are doing now. Firstly, you have been exposed for what you are. Secondly, if you are going to uphold this principle, those ads in Western Australia should be withdrawn immediately and you should apologise to Western Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is—
—This will be a really good one!
—It is going to be very good. Senator Crane mentioned—I am not quite sure about the figure—$238.

—I am not going to claim that I can get it totally right. But I think you have it totally wrong. I recently checked the award. According to my information, the minimum adult rate of pay under the metal trades industry award is $341.40. Let me explain what that is made up of. It is made up of a base component of $284.80, a supplementary payment of $40.60 and a safety net adjustment of $16. That is a lot more than $317.10. The lowest adult rate of pay is $341.40. Probably not a lot of people are getting that.

PARA.TAB: More importantly, look at the history of the wage increases during the life of this government and those who have actually got up to $341.40. All of the wage increases, bar one, have been opposed by the opposition. What is so fundamentally important is that if there were a coalition government tomorrow, with its current industrial relations policy, the people on $341.40 would automatically be $40.60 worse off.

There is an indication that you may have some safety net. Senator Abetz says that that is wrong. Let me put it to you that, in Victoria, Jeff Kennett made application to the state industrial relations commission for a minimum hourly rate of around $8.23. If you were in power now, those people would lose their supplementary payment of $40.60. That would take them back to less than $300 per week. It would then be in line with what Senator Crane is talking about.

What is even more important is what the social wage is now in terms of family supplements, et cetera and how it decreased under you people. I would like to outline a few facts with regard to the social wage. The social wage, as I said before for the information of those opposite, includes expenditure on health, education, housing and child care. Under Mr Howard the social wage went backwards to the tune of nearly 18 per cent. That is what is important to the people in this country today. They do not know what you are going to do with respect to the social wage because you will not tell anybody.

I will tell you what has happened to the social wage under Labor. The social wage under Labor has increased by 73.1 per cent. That is a massive increase. It decreased under you. If you people on that side of the chamber think this is all lies and myths and schemes and plots, then there is a simple solution for you: come out and spell out clearly what your policies are, where you stand on the social wage and on the industrial relations system with regard to hourly rates of pay. You have given only four commitments: a minimum wage, four weeks annual leave and 10 days non-cumulative sick leave—a very poor position—and we do not even know whether we will get long service leave under you lot. The workers have a right to know. I am sure that at some time—I do not know when, but I do not think it will be until after the election—we will see the introduction of the type of position that exists in Western Australia, because that is Mr Howard's model.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—You laugh about it. You think it is a joke, do you, Senator Panizza? The Western Australian legislation is a joke. I am pleased, Senator Panizza, that you think that because it is a joke and it should not be followed. (Time expired)
—Madam Acting Deputy president, I take a point of order. I never said that the Western Australian position is a joke.
—That is not a point of order.
—No, it might not be a point of order but it is a good explanation for your mate behind you.

—Senator Murphy needs to realise that Senator Panizza was laughing at Senator Murphy, not at what he was saying. Indeed, Senator Murphy is a classic example of why hundreds and thousands of people are leaving the trade union movement right around this country.
—You wish!

—Senator Neal says, `You wish.' That is why you got rid of Martin Ferguson and are now hoping that Jennie George might somehow alter the trend in the trade union members. You know very well that there is a huge decrease in support for the trade union movement right around this country. The reason is that people such as Senator Murphy have simply used the trade union movement to advance their own political career and to advance the ALP without being genuinely concerned about the plight of workers.

PARA.TAB: We saw that with the Labor Party trade union orchestrated blockade of Western Australia. They had Jennie George over; flew her all the way from Melbourne for this mass rally. It attracted all of 200 people. We have already had answers given in this place that the 200 people who came to hear this new messiah for the trade union movement came from Senator Cook's office, from Dr Lawrence's office, chances are from Labor headquarters, from the Trades and Labor Council in Western Australia and all the other MPs in Western Australia. Chances are that would have made up the 200. Chances are there was not a single true rank and file worker at that rally. That indicates the lack of support that the Labor Party has in the area of industrial relations. So what are they doing? As Senator Crane put in his question, they are embarking upon a deliberate scare campaign around this country to try to win back votes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Senator Abetz, as other senators have done, says that we are embarking upon a scare campaign.
—That is not a point of order.
—My point of order is that there is one simple solution to that: tell the people what your policy is.
—There is no point of order.

—When Senator Cook gets out his tax policy we might oblige with our industrial relations policy—the full details. When the trade union movement, such as the CFMEU, has to deal with questions of industrial relations, just ask people like Tony Benson. Do you know that name, Senator Murphy? That is the way the trade union movement deals with its own employees—a fellow who got threatened and harassed and who had to go to the Industrial Commission to get himself reinstated. Or have a look at the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca). Guess who was the first parliamentarian to run foul of Labor's unfair dismissal laws? It was none other than Mr Sciacca, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, a Labor minister. That is the Labor Party record and the record Labor has to defend.

PARA.TAB: They cannot defend it, so what is their tactic? It is to suggest that we on this side of the House are going to embark upon all sorts of policy changes which would adversely affect the people of this country. The most important industrial relations initiative that any party could create is to give the people of Australia a job.

Let us look at Labor's record on unemployment, a horrid record, a shameful record, and one which I am sure the people of Australia will judge the Labor Party on at the next election. Senator Murphy says: `Judge us on our own credibility.' They told the workers of this country that they would get a tax cut, that it was written in law—`L-A-W law'. Where are they? They are not to be seen until the next millennium or later. That is what we are talking about—a complete breach of promise.

Labor said there would be no increase required in the Medicare levy for the workers of this country. Dr Lawrence said: `There will be no increase.' But she forgot that she made that promise, like so many other things she forgets. They have ratted on the workers of this country yet again. We had the former Prime Minister Bob Hawke talking about the poor in this community: `There will be no child living in poverty by 1990.' We are now five years from that threshold date, and nobody believes that promise. Labor is running scared. It is now deliberately manufacturing stories about us which are completely untrue. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to a national rural health strategy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Crowley made the very point that I made the other day when she said that the number of female doctors is half the number of male doctors who have been relocated by the rural incentive program. What interested me so much was the narrow feminist ideology that came through—that somehow I was reflecting on women because I made the point that women tended to marry. They marry, Senator Crowley. They stay happily married. They worry about their husbands. It is those points that she picked on.

PARA.TAB: Amongst the other things I said which she did not comment on was that there was a loss of tax deductibility of education expenses, there was an absence of locums, retraining was needed, there was a maintenance of skills required, re-accreditation was needed, they were constantly on call and could not get people to take their calls and, in addition to that, they could not take holidays. What does Senator Crowley pick on?—the narrow feminist ideology that somehow I was casting aspersions on females. With seven daughters, and with one wife who is happily married to me, I would not be game! I have eight women around me.

The narrow feminist ideology is the thing that got me—why you picked on that out of about 10 points I made about the shortage of rural doctors. The other thing, Senator Crowley, that you are not aware of, because you were not able to produce the figures, is that the rural incentive program is replacing one or two GPs a week after three years, when your own department says that there is a shortage of 400 to 500 in rural and remote areas. You are replacing one to two a week, but six a week are leaving. So you tell me how that rural incentive program is working.

If you do not believe me, I draw your attention to the latest addition of Australian Medicine where it says there is `a country crisis'. There is a crisis, Senator Crowley, in obstetrics and in anaesthesia. As you know from the speech I gave last week, I have just toured western Queensland. Senator Crowley, when did you yourself last drive through those rural areas? When have you done 4,000 kilometres, as I did, through western Queensland?

I have the figures in front of me. There is a shortage of between 400 or 500 doctors; there is a country crisis in obstetrics, and there is a growing shortage of rural obstetricians, both specialists and GPs. This week's Wodonga paper says that there is a desperate crisis in western New South Wales. It says, `Medical service a major worry. As it is with many small centres, the lack of adequate medical facilities is a major concern.' You are telling me this rural incentive program is working but, Senator Crowley, it is not working. It has not worked; there need to be a lot more incentives. An article in the Victorian AMA's rural newsletter states that there need to be further incentives in relation to the rural incentive program. You are just not giving enough incentives.

Another big thing which you are not covering is the blow-out in indemnity insurance. We have been waiting for your report for how long—six or nine months? The editor of the report has gone off on long service leave or study leave or something. We still have not seen that report on medical indemnity insurance.

You come in here and try to pick on me for giving a truthful answer. Your own figures show that, of those needing to be replaced, there is only half the number going out there. You will come back at me, I suppose, and say, `Well, it is only in recent years that the number of females in medical schools has increased.' But the reality is, if you went around these areas, if you spent more time there, you would be a bit more knowledgeable about it, Senator Crowley. Coming in and picking on that very narrow feminist point I think speaks more of your answer than of anything that I have said. When I gave you another 11 reasons, you picked on that one narrow, feminist point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, I wish to speak on the same matter. Senator Herron, if you were faithfully reflecting me, you would note that I said `out of a reasonable speech that you made, where many of the points were well taken, you had this further to say.' So I acknowledged the other points, absolutely, but you did not say that a minute ago. You seemed to suggest that I ignored the other points, although I did not.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, the fact that 67 women and 123 men are going into rural Australia is no indication of your case at all; in fact, it is very strong evidence that, although the number of women coming through universities in medical schools now is about 50 per cent, that is a very recent phenomenon. Indeed, it has been happening at a period of time when general practitioners have been asking for a different emphasis in their training to prepare them to have the confidence and the assurance that, if they practice in rural Australia remote from hospitals, they will have the appropriate backup.

As to the numbers of women graduating in medicine, although there have been one or two over the years, it is only very recently that we have seen large numbers of women graduating. If it is all right for very few men after 100 years of medical training to be going out into rural Australia, what about giving us the same amount of time?

I was right to pick on your point, Senator. I said we agreed with your reasonable points about the lack of locums, about insufficient training and a request for preferred training—and that training, of course, should apply for men and women. You referred to those things, and you said that the problem was education. I said that we agreed with those points.

But you did not stick with those points. You actually wandered off on the point that women get married. For heaven's sake, do men not get married? What if a man gets married? It does not stop him from going into a country practice. The point is that you raised the question of women getting married, not me. It is you, Senator, who have a view about that being a negative for women but not for men.

This government is very concerned that there be sufficient medical practitioners in rural Australia. That is why we have this rural program. If it is not working and if there are more reasons for us to look even further, then you can be absolutely sure that the government is committed to making sure that happens.

The point you mentioned of obstetric indemnity is a matter of real concern, particularly in my own state of South Australia. It is fascinating that any time there is any problem of this sort, people no longer even think of turning to state governments. They have to turn to the Commonwealth because state governments—particularly in South Australia which now has a Liberal government—are not the place to go while they are taking money out of the health system to assist them in rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have a short memory, Rosemary.

—You boys can yell at me—but that is because you don't like what is being said. The concern about sufficient numbers of rural doctors is a major one. Senator Herron, you and I know that we largely agree on this matter. The concern is how best to assist doctors to go to rural areas and how, indeed, to assist them to stay there.
—A change of government.

—You had all those years and that is when the whole system got run down! It is us who have a program. It is us who are putting doctors back out there. It is us who are actually serious about providing assistance to rural areas in Australia. It is not us who say, `It is difficult because women get married.' Senator Herron, that is not your usual line, it is not your usual point. It is a mistake in what you usually argue, which is much more reasonable than that—to take the words out of your own mouth, `Women get married.' One way I could refute this argument would be to find a woman doctor who is not yet married. That would probably give lie to that claim by Senator Herron. I do happen to know some women doctors who do not get married. Do you suggest they all get married?

PARA.TAB: The first problem is adequate training and adequate supports to assist doctors to have the confidence to actually feel that they can cope. The second problem is getting locums to back them up. The problems of locums are very important, because a rural GP can often expect no break, seven days a week, 52 weeks a year. Those are the sorts of concerns at which this government is looking.

We have very considerable financial incentives to get doctors into rural practice. Apparently, that is not a sufficient reason for many of them to go into rural practice. Another reason that is not strictly related to doctors only is the question of education, particularly secondary education for children of families of professionals in rural areas. It applies just as much to school teachers, police persons, bankers and anybody else. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Jones this day, relating to risk management in the wool industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the statement by Senator Collins that for two years Wool International has been investigating and implementing a system of risk management. As a sideline to that, at least there will be a direct link between the woolgrower and wool processor. Also, importantly, on the risk management side, at certain times of the year when growers do not have the wool from the sheep, they can make arrangements to take advantage of certain market conditions.

PARA.TAB: Equally, I welcome the statement that it will be stand alone and be self-funding—that funding will not come out of the general assets of the stockpile. Furthermore, I welcome the statement—and I hope it never changes—that when Wool International is privatised in 1998, or whenever, there will be a choice for growers to take shares or equity.

I hope that that never changes, whether under this government or under our government. I do not think the choice is one of being given shares in return for your equity and then on-selling. It has simply got to be that if you do not want to be in the system then you get your cash back. At this stage of two years away from privatisation, I do not know that we really need, as Senator Sandy Macdonald said to me before, another friendly stockbroker. I can remember various so-called friendly stockbrokers, such as Western Livestock, coming in—

TALK.START.PARA: —All your mates.

—What do you mean, my mates? What is he talking about? I can remember various ones coming in and, after a while, not being so friendly. If there is to be another player in the field, if the situation demands it that much, I believe that private enterprise will provide that if someone is minded to go that way. I certainly would not like any force to be applied to growers in respect of their equity.

PARA.TAB: No-one has told me whether there will be any equity at the end because, at the present moment, the debt about equals the assets of the wool stockpile. That should leave $200 million to $300 million in fixed assets that are still there at present. But the way that the price of wool has been dropping in the last couple of months—

TALK.START.PARA: —It has gone back up.
—I hope you are right that it is going back up.
—I know it has.

—Well, I have not read today's newspapers but I hope it is going back up. If it were to go down any further, I think you would have to throw in that $200 million or $300 million—or whatever it is—of fixed assets as well to square it up.

PARA.TAB: All in all, I do welcome the minister's statements, especially the one on growers having a choice. But that has to stay in concrete. When we do see the end of the stockpile, there is one thing that is certain: there will never be another one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the course of taking note of answers, there was some dispute with regard to what the award rate was in the Metal Trades Industry Award. I seek leave to table a copy of the Metal Trades Industry Award, which clearly identifies exactly what the rates of pay are.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:
