INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The government's failure to implement policies which would deliver Australians the high living standards which flow from sustainable economic growth accompanied by low inflation, low interest rates and low unemployment.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that informal arrangements have been made to allocate specific times to each of the speakers in today's debate. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Australian Bureau of Statistics announced that Australia's inflation rate, as measured by the consumer price index, increased by 1.2 per cent in the three months of the September quarter alone to a level 5.1 per cent above that of a year ago. That is a dangerous increase which will set red lights flashing across all business, consumer and wage earner groups in Australia. It is the sixth consecutive quarter in which our annual inflation rate has risen.

PARA.TAB: Inflation in Australia is at a rate that puts us firmly in second place—second only to Italy—amongst the high inflation nations of the Western world. In Australia, inflation is measured in more than one way. The consumer price index is the most common, but the government also likes to use what it calls the `underlying inflation rate'. It likes this form of measurement because the figure is generally below the consumer price index figure. It excludes such things as meat, fruit and vegetables, clothing, housing interest rates, petrol, fuel and power, local government charges, tobacco and alcohol, health services, pharmaceuticals, education, child care and several other very important items. In other words, it fiddles the inflation that people actually experience, basically to suit its own political ends, although I do accept that there are valid reasons for some of the exclusions.

But even this heavily adjusted fiddled inflation figure shows the same dangerously increasing trend as does the consumer price index. In the September quarter, this so-called underlying rate was 3.1 per cent higher than a year earlier. On the government's own reckoning—no-one else's—this is a dangerously high figure, because the Reserve Bank of Australia says that the range of acceptable underlying inflation in Australia is two to three per cent; that is, three per cent is the upper level of acceptability. Anything above that is unacceptable and requires policy action to bring the inflation rate back down to within an acceptable range. That policy action involves a range of things. It certainly involves monetary policy and it involves budgetary policy. Monetary policy, of course, means one thing; that is, higher interest rates.

So what today's inflation figures mean, if they continue in the months ahead—and there are no grounds for thinking that they will not—is that interest rates will be on the rise again before too long. They are already amongst the highest in the Western world. It is a figure that is often glossed over by the government in its attempts to conceal the real level of interest rates in this country, but when you look at the real level of interest rates in Australia, they are at all levels, short-term and long-term, amongst the highest in the world. That, of course, increases the competitive difficulties that we face on an international basis.

The government, of course, will be doing everything in its power to keep rates from rising before the forthcoming election. They will cajole Reserve Bank Governor, Bernie Fraser, and his team—and bear in mind that Mr Fraser has already warned the government about rising wage pressures and higher than acceptable inflation; and the implications for interest rates and other economic policy measures that that brings out.

This government will do anything to avoid a rate increase before the election. But they cannot deny one inescapable fact; that is, that under this Keating government's policies, rates will soon be on the rise again. That inflation figure that we had today is like a time bomb. It is like the foreign debt time bomb we have: tick, tick, tick; away it goes and sooner or later that bomb will explode and interest rates will go up—and the government knows that full well.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wish.

—I know, as do you. That situation, of course, is one that our Prime Minister thinks is okay. Indeed, he thinks the present situation is much better than okay. He thinks that things today are `as good as it gets'. Let me tell the Prime Minister something.
—You can't tell him anything.

—No, you are right. You cannot tell the Prime Minister anything. You are absolutely right. He does not listen to you. He has taken your innovation statement away and he has taken the industry policy statement; he will not listen to you. He does not listen to anyone. He is the most arrogant Prime Minister; he is the most arrogant man this country has ever known. He does think things are as good as they get.

PARA.TAB: Let me tell him something. No-one else in Australia thinks that things are as good today as they could get. The 760,000 unemployed Australians do not think so; the 750,000 small businesses that are the lifeblood of this country do not think so; the millions of middle and low income families desperately struggling to make ends meet, desperately struggling to keep themselves together to avoid sinking, do not think so. The only person in Australia who thinks that things are as good as they get is this tired, divisive, arrogant, absolutely out of touch with the real world Prime Minister. He does not actually care what happens to the rest of Australia's 18 million people, so long as he can hold on to the trappings of autocratic power.

The Prime Minister has long had a quite unreal view of his government's success in producing a long-term, low inflation, sustainable growth economy. He must shudder today—if he was not so thick-skinned he would—to read and recall some of the things he has said in recent times about the inflation rate in Australia. Let must just quote a few of these comments, one as recent as 27 April this year. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the underlying rate . . . gives you the steady view of inflation. And the steady view on inflation is very steady . . .

Let me say that since he said that, some six months ago, the underlying rate of inflation in this country has risen by something like 60 per cent. Going back almost exactly a year ago today, to 26 October 1994, he said:

. . . Australia has changed its form . . . it has broken the back of inflation and it is capable of a low inflationary performance . . . What we have here is what a lot of other countries don't have and that is relative price stability and strong employment growth.

I have news for the Prime Minister: he was absolutely wrong on both those points. There are still 100,000 people less in full-time employment today than there were at the peak, five years ago. He said:
. . . the trick is to get both—
that is, price stability and strong employment growth—
and by the mix of policy we have, I am happy to say, that Australia has both.
Another broken promise; another l-i-e from this Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Madam Deputy President. Surely that is unparliamentary. Just because you spell the word, it does not make it parliamentary. Senator Short knows it is unparliamentary. It should be withdrawn.
—I did not understand him to call the Prime Minister an unparliamentary name; I thought he was referring to policy.
—I do recall Senator Short—and Hansard will reveal this, I believe—as saying that from the Prime Minister it is just another l-i-e—
—I said it is another l-i-e from this Prime Minister. I did not call him a liar; I said he told a lie.
—That surely is an unparliamentary reflection upon the Prime Minister.

—I withdraw that and substitute deliberate untruth. We could go on with other statements that the Prime Minister has made in recent times. Three years ago he claimed that under Labor inflation had been conquered. He also stated:

SPEECH.PARA: I think (there is) a clear view that we have broken the inflation stick. That is, inflation is down to stay down.
That is absolute nonsense. That never was the case and never will be the case. That is the track record of this Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: The real facts are that the Labor Party has been unable after 12 1/2 years in government to make the necessary reforms to enable Australia, on any sustainable basis, to grow at a rate that absorbs the additions to the available work force and reduces the massive and horrendous pool of unemployment that Labor's policies have produced. What we are seeing now is more of the same old treadmill cycle of boom and bust, higher unemployment, higher inflation and lower economic growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a couple of things that Senator Short said that probably need to be corrected. First of all, he attacked the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I will not go into a great defence because it is not necessary. In the Melbourne Age there was an article about Australia and France being at war over nuclear testing. The headline in heavy black print stated: `War: Chirac v. Keating'. I think the Australian people will be pleased it is Paul Keating. No-one could imagine Chirac versus Howard as any sort of contest in which Australia would stand up with any dignity in the international fora.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short said that the underlying rate of inflation is a fiddled figure. He also said that it is produced for political ends. Neither of those comments are true. For a long time Treasury has produced a figure showing what the underlying rate of inflation is. The underlying rate removes items which are particularly volatile, seasonal or subject to government charges in the CPI in order to make that rate a truer measure of inflation. To accuse anyone of fiddling the books or to say that this is a politically produced figure is to call into question the authority and impartiality of the Treasury in the political process, something that Senator Short is not game to do to its face.

It is not an attack on the government, it is an attack on the Treasury and the Reserve Bank of Australia which refers to the underlying rate of inflation when it says that the inflation level in Australia should remain between two and three per cent. It is not an attack on the government, it is an attack on both those institutions. Senator Short knows better and he should withdraw those remarks at a future time. To use them in this debate as a sickening attempt to undermine the government is pathetic.

This MPI should not succeed and I do not believe it will. We have in Australia sustainable economic growth. We have high and rising living standards. We have low inflation and we have increasing employment. I will go to the first of the trinity of descriptions of the economy which is that growth at present is at 3.75 per cent. We are on track for the budget figure to be realised. This represents 16 successive quarters of growth—in other words, four years of successive growth. The December quarter this year will record a further quarter of growth, putting us at 17 successive quarters of growth—one of the longest periods of sustained economic growth in the economic history of this country.

If we look at the economic growth performance of this government versus the opposition when it was in government and when the current Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, was Treasurer of Australia, we find that the average rate of real economic growth for Australia was 2.6 per cent. Under our period of office it is 3.5 per cent. The record for which party can deliver the best economic growth goes to us.

Economic growth is important in this debate because it is directed at families. It is growth in the economy that creates opportunities for families and creates opportunities for employment. We have managed to have a high level of economic growth in this country with quite distinctively and importantly a low level of inflation. That is a vital consideration. To get economic growth is one thing but to get it with low inflation is the most important thing. We have delivered that.

This country is enjoying high and rising living standards. I will go to household disposable incomes. Real household disposable income in percentage terms has, under our government, grown by 41.8 per cent. Real household disposable income per capita has grown by 20.9 per cent. The approximate increase in real annual household disposable income per capita from June 1983 to June 1995, expressed in June 1995 dollars, was $3,500. That is a real dollar increase in per capita household disposable income. That is a record not matched by the opposition.

We recall the opposition's infamous trinity of double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and negative economic growth when they were cast from office by the Australian electorate. Under us, living standards have risen. They have also risen in terms of company profits and because of retained income in national savings through superannuation. That is an initiative introduced by this government.

Prior to our ascension to office, superannuation was the privilege of the upper executive in corporations or public servants. Blue-collar workers and others in the private sector typically did not have access to superannuation. Now all workers do. The lowest to highest paid have access to superannuation and can look forward to a dignified retirement. We are building a national pool of savings for investment in the Australian economy which will grow the economy and return a retirement wage to ordinary Australians.

Today's debate has been sparked by the September quarter CPI figures released by the Statistician at 11.30 this morning. These figures show that the underlying rate of inflation in Australia for the year is 3.1 per cent. I believe it is important to put those figures in context. That is exactly what the Treasurer (Mr Willis) did today. In a press release he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: While today's result indicates that through the year underlying inflation rate has risen above 3 per cent for the first time since December 1991, this outcome is not inconsistent with the commitment of the government and the Reserve Bank of Australia to keep underlying inflation between 2 to 3 per cent on average over the course of the economic cycle.
To put this figure in context, the Treasurer stated:

While the Treasury underlying measure of inflation attempts to measure generalised inflationary pressures by removing items that are particularly volatile, seasonal or subject to government influence, it can still be affected by one-off changes. For example, the September quarter increase in the underlying rate has been influenced by the increase in third party insurance premiums and by the changes to the wholesale sales tax rate (WST).

-New motor vehicle prices, reflecting increases in WST, and motor vehicle insurance contributed 0.36 percentage points to the quarterly increase in the underlying rate. In the absence of these increases the underlying rate would have risen by around 0.8 per cent in the quarter, and 2.7 per cent through the year.

That is why we are working within the parameters. That is why the scaremongering motion ought not be entertained for one minute. It is fair to say that we are operating within the parameters set out by the budget. The economy is not in panic mode as the opposition would like it to be. The economy has a strong level of growth which is underpinned by some inflationary pressures which are in a manageable area and within the scope of what we believe is manageable. They are within the budget settings, as I have said.

PARA.TAB: The significant thing about inflation, and one cannot leave a debate on the subject of inflation without making this point, is that we have an accord with the union movement of Australia. One of the areas through which inflation can be pushed quickest is excessive wage settlements. Under that accord, we have entered into an agreement which ensures that wage settlements will not push the underlying rate of inflation beyond the two per cent to three per cent area. That is what the Reserve Bank of Australia says is the manageable area. That is what the accord says. We do expect that that will be delivered.

The opposition has an industrial relations track record which makes it impossible to have any agreement with the trade union movement of Australia. We are able to reach a situation by having an agreement with them in which there is wage moderation for tax trade-offs and improvements in the social wage so the living standards rise—that is, all those things affected by the level of income in wages, the level of tax paid out of those wages and the social wage delivered by the government to the individual household. We have a situation where we can trade that off because of a cooperative relationship with the union movement in order to ensure living standards rise, profits remain high and investment can occur in the Australian economy.

I do not think anyone can leave this debate without referring to taxation. We had a little encounter, one might say, during question time on the subject of taxation. I think this motion, which gets it lamentably wrong but politically wrong on purpose in order to make a case that does not exist, a fictional case against the government, was moved by the opposition in order to hide the fact that the opposition has not declared to the Australian people its own economic policies. It is criticised in the media by economic commentators for not doing so. The coalition intends to ambush the Australian electorate on the eve of an election with a mass of detail that the electorate will not be able to consume. In doing so, the coalition will confuse the public as to the intent of that policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the point of view of truth and relevance, this is an astonishing statement by Senator Cook. We asked him today at question time to reveal a central element of his tax policy and he refused to do it. You refused to reveal a central element of your tax policy. That is absolute hypocrisy.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—Order! There is no point of order, Senator Kemp. I think you realise that.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is another attempt by the opposition to cover its lack of policy by going on the attack and using up my speaking time by calling a point of order. The people of Australia are entitled to know what would be the economic policy of a coalition government in Australia. The fact that Mr Howard and his cohorts refuse to tell them and duck, dive, weave and hide is an indication that they are in fact intending to ambush the electorate on the eve of an election with a mass of detail which cannot be synthesised, consumed or understood. They will try to blind and confuse them and, hopefully for them, skate through their strategy to victory while confusing the people as to the real intent of their economic policy.

PARA.TAB: If they do not want that accusation to be levelled, they have one easy way out—that is, to declare their policy now, open it for inspection and enable people to judge it for themselves. They do not do that and because they run away from that challenge they are exposed. Last Friday the reputable magazine the Business Review Weekly, which is a business magazine circulated in Australia, had an article on page 22 headed `Libs' radical new tax plan'. This tax plan proposed that the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance be corrected, which is code for saying that you devolve the level of income tax as now gathered by the Commonwealth to the states and give the states an income tax of their own. That is what the plan is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Point of order: I do not like ministers of the crown telling deliberate untruths. The statement that you are alleging has been categorically denied by the shadow Treasurer and the coalition. If you are going to attack the coalition, attack it on fact and not on assertions that have been categorically denied.

—Order! Senator Short, you are debating the issue. There is no point of order. There was some other unparliamentary language across the chamber, so I would like Senator Cook to continue without interruption.

—Again, my time has been eaten up by a non-point of order in order to stifle the debate in this chamber. That is a terrible reflection on proper conduct, respect and politeness in this chamber, which has now been reduced to a new low.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the shadow Treasurer denied that it was his intent to enact what this article reported in quotations from him and other Liberals in Australia—that is, the secret tax plan of Australia. But when you look at the words of the denial you have to ask: is this genuinely a true denial or not? The shadow Treasurer said:

SPEECH.PARA: There will be no separate income tax. The coalition will not in any way change the current arrangements as to the method of collecting income tax.

Is that a denial? Is that a categorical denial? No, it is not. The plan suggests that the Australian tax office will be maintained to collect a state income tax nationally. So when he says `There will be no change in the current arrangements as to the method of collecting income tax' that is not a denial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, what is it?
—It is an attempt to see income collected at the national level. (Time expired)

—I must say that to have the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) come into this chamber on this debate and accuse the coalition of not having its economic policies in front of the Australian people is an act of gross hypocrisy, absolute gross hypocrisy. This is the who has been described in the paper as not being able to get his innovation statement before the Australian people because people like Wayne Swan and Stephen Smith, the member for Lilley and the member for Perth respectively, have described it as a bronze medal strategy.

PARA.TAB: He has been trying to write a policy for some months now, probably six or seven months. We are told we may see it before Christmas. This is supposed to be a detailed visionary sort of policy. We in the Senate and the Australian people know the fact is that Minister Cook, the bronze medal man, will not be capable of writing this policy or getting any visionary policy up so Don Russell has been called back from Washington to write it. I would not be surprised if the poor old scungy, mangy draft of this policy that must be gathering dust by this stage, the paper must be turning brown, has indeed been faxed to Washington so Mr Russell can work on it when he sits on his 747 on his way home next week.

This minister talks about the coalition not having policy before the people. Quite frankly, we have more policy in relation to industrial relations on the table in front of the Australian people now than the government had before the last election. As we speak today, we have more of the fundamental tenets of our economic policy before the Australian people than this government had on the table before the last election and has on the table now.

This very day my colleague Senator Kemp asked the minister to describe one scintilla of your tax policy for the next election. Very simply put he asked: will you raise existing taxes? In other words, will you introduce new taxes or raise existing taxes? Senator Cook went on and did one of the most disgraceful and pitiful performances in question time.

TALK.START.PARA: —And was sat down by the President.

—He was sat down by the President on two occasions in what was one of the most pitiful performances by a minister that I have witnessed in my five short years in this place. George Bush was able to say, `Read my lips.'
—And he lied.

—He was rolled by Senator Cook's Democrat friends in the Congress. Mr Keating did not want to say, `Read my lips,' because former President Bush had trumped him on that one so he said, `L-a-w. It is in law.' We passed it through the House of Representatives, we passed it through the Senate and he said, `It is l-a-w'. What did he do, Senator Cook? Interject! What did he do? George Bush lied, he delivered it.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to the main point of this contribution, Senator Cook. You get up in this chamber day by day and say—and you have said it again today—how wonderful things are in this economy, how the Australian people are doing so well under you. I get angry when I hear you say that. You are in politics. You have got to use the statistics you can find to support your case, and you do that day in, day out, telling Australians how lowly they are taxed, telling everyone how their taxes are going down under you.

I get angry about that, when I think about those people who actually listen to these broadcasts—I will not say God help them, but I just did—and those people who see your propaganda when you write letters to constituents or get reported in the paper. Those very people read it and they probably say to themselves, `Hang on. This government is reducing taxes, but I went to the supermarket last week and all my groceries that have got a sales tax on them have gone up: detergent, soft drinks, biscuits, toothpaste, toothbrushes, all of those items.'

You just admitted in your speech that inflation has gone up because sales taxes have gone up—as if some fairy godmother had introduced all these new tax taxes. Are you blaming the tax department, are you blaming Mr Carmody for inflation now? It was your government that promised the people that we would not have any increases in taxes. You made it quite clear to the Australian people that the reason not to vote for Dr Hewson last time was that he was going to put up the price of your groceries. What did you do? Within months of coming to power, you put them up. I think it was Access Economics which reported only recently that the taxes on the necessities of life have actually gone up more under your government than they would have if there had been a GST. So you are blaming Mr Carmody for putting inflation up.

I would love to see what the inflation figure would have been if the Senate, in its great wisdom, had not knocked back your building tax. We will have all of these scare campaigns at the next election and if something remarkable happens and you are re-elected, I will respect the decision of the Australian people, as I always do, as I did the last time. But I tell you what: there would be nothing surer than that you tax building items. I guess people keep voting for Liberal and National Party senators because they rely on us to take off the most offending bits of your legislation, such as when we knocked out the building tax.

This government not only put up sales tax; they put up income tax. They said there would be l-a-w tax cuts. Then they put income tax back up. They put company tax down before the last election, put it back up, increased fuel tax, increased wine tax. These guys are just big taxing government. That is why inflation is going up.

You have actually done nothing to institutionalise low inflation. You say the great achievement of your government is to have low inflation and high growth. You keep repeating the mistruth, the palpable lie that this is a low inflation government, that you have delivered low inflation. I think I have got up in the Senate virtually every week for the last 12 months and reminded the Australian people—and I think they will be reminded today loud and clear on the news when they see your record inflation this quarter—that this is not a low inflation government. You are the second highest inflation government in the OECD. The only country that beat us is Italy. Can we get the minister's approval to have incorporated in the Hansard the table from the 14 October Economist magazine that shows that Australia has the highest inflation for that quarter, the three months; the second highest inflation for the year; and the third highest inflation forecast for 1996. Can I have your agreement to incorporate that in my speech?

TALK.START.PARA: —Not until you do the right and proper thing.
—I only have a minute left.

—I raise a point of order. There are forms to proceed with incorporation, and Senator Campbell knows it full well. If he would do us the favour of observing them, he might get agreement from us, but if he wants to trump them and do this unilaterally, he will not.

—That is okay. We gave it; we will take a bit of it. The government goes back to the record of the Howard treasurership and says that that was a high inflation government. You have to look at it in world comparative terms. I have done that since question time. The reality is that we had average inflation rates, even in 1982 and 1983, and for five of the years of the Fraser-Howard government we had below average world inflation rates. Under your government, you have had above average inflation rates for virtually every year, and you are way above whatever it is now. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take up a couple of issues that have been raised in this debate. First of all, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, has very adequately refuted claims made in this matter of public importance. It is surprising that these claims should come from Senator Short, a Victorian. Senator Short should know what Premier Kennett is doing to living standards in Victoria. I am surprised that Senator Short would come into this chamber and make the claims that he has made in this matter of public importance.
—Bring back Joan Kirner.
—No one wants Joan, Margaret.

—Obviously Senator Kemp is unhappy when anyone speaks of Mr Kennett's policies. When we come to the election next year the Australian people will only have to look at the record of the Kennett government and the Court government on a range of policies because we are not going to hear very much from Mr Howard. All we can do is look at the record in Victoria and Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Campbell mentioned industrial relations policy. Industrial relations is a major issue. It is a very important issue for all Australians. Look at the models that we have in Victoria and Western Australia.

I want to return to Senator Short because he referred particularly to living standards. He claims that living standards under the federal government are not what they should be. Let us look at what they are under a Liberal state government.

If we want to analyse what has happened in industrial relations, Premier Kennett's new employee relations commission has changed the set of powers and that means that equal pay is no longer protected. Equal pay is something that women in Australia still do not receive. Premier Kennett is prepared to undermine the equal pay that is available to many women. For example, women are disadvantaged under enforced individual contracts. That matter was debated very vociferously in Western Australia last week.

Premier Kennett has weakened the Equal Opportunity Commission. He has cut back on material health care with no follow up support for new mothers. We are all aware of the risk of child abuse. Parents are not supported in the early months. Women are being released too early from hospital. We have seen cut backs in kindergarten services. We now have a new $100 tax on all property owners. There is no elected local government in Victoria because commissioners have been appointed.

I find it very strange that Senator Short, of all people, would come into this chamber and talk about living standards when right on his own doorstep we have a premier who is undermining the living standards of Victorians. That is the only indication we have at the moment of coalition policy.

We know something about the Liberal Party's tax policies because if we read the current issue of Business Review Weekly we see that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and shadow Treasurer, Peter Costello, described the Commonwealth-state financial relations as an important issue that has to be addressed. SPEECH.PARA: State reliance on Commonwealth grants—the so-called vertical fiscal imbalance—is something we will be dealing with in our first term of government.

That sounds very ominous. It is particularly ominous for Queensland because it has been estimated that under Mr Costello's proposals the revenue cuts in Queensland could amount to a great deal. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing the government's performance this afternoon I have to say that time has really run out for this government. We had the very uneventful launch of the blue book called Shaping the Nation. I notice that speakers on the other side of the chamber have not brought that book into the chamber. That publication was meant to document line by line the performance of this government over the past 13 years. Within a week of the government trumpeting its performances in government we find that it is now in tatters.

PARA.TAB: First of all, we had the failure of the Working Nation statement last week with the publication of the unemployment figures. The figures are trending up. We have had a desperate attempt to rework Working Nation. We have also had the collapse of the superannuation policy. We are told that it is in the revamp state, too. In the publication Shaping the Nation the government lauded its low inflation policy around which the whole budget strategy is centred.

Today we had the announcement of Australia's annual headline inflation rate and we find that it has climbed to 5.1 per cent. That absolutely snuffs out any chance of a fall in interest rates, other than those that are politically motivated. The fear is that interest rates will now rise.

Last month we had the announcement that Australia's foreign debt is at a record level. One would have to say that the government's whole economic strategy is on the verge of collapse. We must remember that in July this year the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, when referring to inflation, said this at an ALP dinner:

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at what economic significance will give us a guide to our economic performance as a country over the next three or four years, the key piece of economic news is the two to three per cent inflation target in the wages Accord.
He went on:

Agreeing on a wages system which endorses the government's and the Reserve Bank's two to three per cent inflation target is an event of seminal economic significance: significance to competitiveness, significance to investments and savings; and to a lower CAD.

The inflation rate that the Prime Minister was talking about was the headline rate. That rate is five per cent, not two to three. Today's inflation announcement does more to undermine the credibility of the government than any other single economic statistic or trend that we have had of late. That is why the government has placed great store in holding down the inflation rate. It has underpinned the government's whole fragile and shonky economic strategy. The government has tried every deceptive policy available to show that it has broken the inflation stick.

PARA.TAB: We have had false budget surpluses, artificially high interest rates, superficial wages Accords and even slick salesmanship from the Prime Minister in an attempt to convince the marketplace of the government's anti-inflation policies. Today we have arrived at a point where the bond yields are on the rise again, as they were in 1994, in expectation of entrenched inflation in the future. As this effect cascades through the economy and high inflation takes hold and interest rates remain high, the losers will be the people battling to pay off their mortgage home loans with no expected relief; the people battling to stay afloat in small business with no expected relief; and the worst affected will be the unemployed. The cost to business to further employ has gone up. We have the threat and fear of a wages spiral.

Even worse news today was the increase in the underlying rate of inflation. This was a figure that was trumped up by the government and the Reserve Bank as being something that was far more important than the headline inflation rate. It is supposed to be the rate at which the Reserve Bank and the government will set policy. The Australian public would rather look at a rise in the cost of living. The Reserve Bank's annual report defined the underlying rate as the consumer price index less fruit and vegetables, fuel, mortgage interest charges, consumer credit charges, public dwelling rent, local government rates and charges, household fuel and light, postal and telephone services, motoring charges, health services, pharmaceuticals, education, child care et cetera et cetera.

After all those exclusions you would have to ask yourself: what exactly is it measuring? This measure is absolutely no comfort to the real people who are feeling these inflationary effects on their real standards of living and their real incomes. As they see it, the real inflation rate is the headline rate. That is what affects them.

It is also the headline rate that underpins the wages accord with the government—not the underlying rate. It is true to say that the previous ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, and the present ACTU President, Jennie George, have made it quite clear that it is the headline rate of inflation which affects their members. Today's inflation rate announcement has all the hallmarks of yet another government policy starting to fray at the edges with a real fear of a return to the wage-price spiral of the 1980s.

In the short time I have left, I have to say that today's inflation rate really does send shudders and fear throughout the economy for the average Australian and for the battlers, for now they face a spiralling inflation rate and further danger to their standard of living.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short today brought into this chamber a matter of public importance which says:

PARA.TAB: The government's failure to implement policies which would deliver Australians the high living standards which flow from sustainable economic growth accompanied by low inflation, low interest rates and low unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: With regard to sustained economic growth accompanied by low inflation, our record is, I think, that we have had the longest period of economic growth, certainly in recent history. TALK.START.PARA: —You are the second highest in the Western world.

Page 2 of the 20 October edition has an article entitled `Economy better than ever, says bank chief', and that is attributed to Mr Bernie Fraser.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't Mr Murdoch. What did he say?
—Mr Fraser happened to actually disagree with Mr Murdoch. He said, very briefly:

PARA.TAB: "I have been around the economic scene here for quite a long time and in terms of the fundamentals, in terms of the capacity of this economy to cope with the global environment, I think we're in better shape than we have ever been," he said.

SPEECH.PARA: If we go back and look at your record, Senator Kemp and Senator Campbell, we see that productivity during your last term of office went backwards—not forwards; backwards. PARA.TAB: So you should not come in here with matters that are really like, I could say, a bird crapping in its own nest. They are the sorts of actions you take from time to time. TALK.START.PARA: —Sustainable economic growth is a nonsense. We can have sustainable societies or we can have economic growth until things collapse. Sustainable growth is an oxymoron, but as Professor John Young said, `"Sustainable" is a good, unambiguous term. Like pregnancy, you can't be a little bit sustainable.'

PARA.TAB: A sustainable society must first be materially—that is, ecologically—sustainable. If you cannot sustain the ecological base of society, you cannot sustain its continued material existence. There is no escape from that for societies, although individuals might survive an ecological disaster. A society must also be socially sustainable in the sense that it cannot be so unjust and skewed or oppressive that it sooner or later provokes unrest and uprising.

Senator Short talks about high living standards flowing from sustainability. If he were talking about ecologically sustainable societies, he might have a point. I will just detail an implication. We talk about the need for a minimum level of ecological sustainability just to assure material survival. If we intend to increase real living standards, the quality of life, we must go further. It would imply maintaining or increasing the diversity and integration of an ecology. It means access to that essential element of nature—abundance. But abundance and economic growth are opposite terms.

Economic growth continues to be based on natural wealth and a large supply of essentially free goods. But as economic growth proceeds, things become scarcer and, after a while, the nature of growth changes. It is based on increased cost of scarce resources. Paying a higher price certainly has the effect of adding to GDP, generating economic growth, but in practical terms, it means we have less per person. Increased use of free goods means ultimately they are no longer free. The economy grows but we all get poorer.

Look at Japan, that economic powerhouse. How many Australians would prefer to live in Japan? Sure, you would get more for your house, but your house would likely be a tiny box in the middle of a vast, dirty, noisy city. You would get more wages on an international basis, but milk is several dollars a litre, there is no space, there is no beach to head down to and islands are built out of the garbage people dispose of. This is economic wealth, but natural living becomes inaccessible. Are living standards higher?

I have seen these MPIs pour from the opposition benches lately. Somewhere you will need to sit down and work out some of the contradictions in them—not just the coalition, since the government makes the same demands that reality adjust itself to policy. You want people to have higher living standards but not higher wages, because increased wages will increase inflation. You want labour market reform because this will decrease labour costs.

There will be fewer workers, or they will be paid less, and they will work harder for the same money. This will give us higher living standards. We are told that the profits companies make will be reinvested to create more jobs. If these jobs continue to be low paid, how will people be better off and have higher standards of living? You want higher house prices because this increases the value of the family investment, but you want prices, interest rates and wages to stay down. Every time that house prices go up, not only do those who sell houses make money but those who buy will need to borrow more money. If that is the case, either they will be worse off or they will be pushing for higher wages so that they can afford a house. The more people borrow to spend on a house, the fewer savings there are, the less money is available for productive investment and the more pressure there is to raise interest rates. Do not you see some contradictions here?

The growth is good mentality does not work. Growth does not solve our problems. Growth in resource demand increases marginal costs, and technological input is needed as resources decline in quantity and quality. Economic growth is based on increased activity and increased profits, which are based on decreased costs of input, including labour.

There have been a number of motions relating to the growing gap between the rich and the poor. This growing gap is a feature of growth everywhere in the developed world. It is a direct outcome of growth. The Greens would like to see stable prices and low stable interest rates. This includes stable house prices. We would like to see a stable population and a stable, steady state economy.

From there, we would like to see society address the real barriers to higher living standards. These include the pointless waste of resources in our current modes of consumption. They include the lack of distribution of employment. If we established a more equitable sharing of jobs, we would get effective full employment. We should also address the central issue of the maldistribution of profits, which reinforces the maldistribution of wealth and power. We might then start seeing something worthy of the term `rising standards of living'.

On a number of occasions in this place in recent times we have mentioned the fact that, in the end, if we want to see distributive equity in Australia and small business able to survive, we have to start thinking radically. We have to start thinking about regional and local based economies. We have to start thinking about the amazingly radical concept of paying people more per hour to work less, and distributing the work available. It might seem, in the short term, that you are increasing your costs. But, in reality, if you are only using labour as a cost of production, you are missing the point in terms of standards of living and the ability of our economy to survive. Basically, the standard of living depends on people's ability to enjoy their life, leisure and families and to be able to participate—(Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Reynolds)—In accordance with the provisions of the Public Service Act 1922, I present the annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for 1994-95.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an interesting document because it touches on part of the services in the building that are used by all senators, which is the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Research Service. Some of us use the Library to lesser or greater degrees. I am currently reading a book which the Library was kind enough to borrow on my behalf from the National Library of Australia. It is a great privilege that we have, and we should always be grateful for it. At other times, I use, as honourable senators would, the Parliamentary Research Service and the Parliamentary Library Information Service. They are also very important. So we have to pay attention to what happens in the Library and how the resources are used to maximise its efficiency.

PARA.TAB: I have always said that the Library is probably more important for the opposition than it is for the government. I will explain why. In government, one has all the resources of a department to provide information to ministers. Whichever group of parties is in government has easier access to material from those departments. That is not a complaint; it is just a fact of life.

To balance it up and for the benefit of a good democratic system, there has to be a mechanism by which those who are in opposition, or those who are in the minor parties—heaven knows, sometimes I think some of the minor parties need all the help they can get—can get access to information. That, of course, for us often means the Parliamentary Library and the research service there, in particular, in producing research and discussion papers.

So it is interesting to note some of the statistics that were pulled out by the Parliamentary Library Research Service on requests for information. Ten per cent of senators and members, which on my reckoning is about 25 people, made 30.6 per cent of the requests; and a quarter of senators and members made 52.6 per cent of requests.

TALK.START.PARA: —What page is this?

—This is page 18. A quarter of all requests were made by just 16 senators and members. I might be wrong but it sounds very much like most of the requests came from the shadow ministry or the shadow cabinet, and that is not a bad thing. I know that when Senator Walsh was in the place, he made enormous use of the library, as well as other resources, when he was no longer in the ministry. He was stunningly effective in what he did as a result of the flow of information. But it stresses the importance of the library to those of us who are in opposition at the moment and it stresses the importance of the library to those who may be in opposition after the next election. I think everybody has a vested interest in making sure that the system works well.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that a couple of years ago when the Parliamentary Library came within the purview of Estimates Committee A—and you will remember it, Madam Acting Deputy President—there was enormous consternation over the mismanagement of the library. The matters no longer come before an estimates committee on which I take an active interest; but it was decided at that point in time that some temporary measures be taken to rectify the parlous situation into which the library had fallen. As a consequence of that, you will well recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that it was decided that Mr John Templeton should take over as acting librarian, although he was not a librarian himself. That was done for administrative reasons to try to rectify some of the problems.

That is several years ago and Mr Templeton seems to have done a fairly reasonable job. But it is interesting to note that nowhere in the document is there mention of the future of the library under a librarian. Mr Templeton signs the report as `Acting Parliamentary Librarian'. If matters that caused the concern in the first place have been resolved, then maybe it is time that we have a parliamentary librarian, a person who is skilled in librarianship, to deal with the library and also the flow of information.

Obviously, it is a difficult matter because the Parliamentary Library is not like any other library in this country. It is as much a research service as a library. But, certainly, there are issues there that have to be dealt with and, certainly, we are talking about multimedia and so on. The principles of good librarianship are as applicable to CD-ROMs as they are applicable to books. So there is no reason why it should not happen now if the problems have been resolved.

It is interesting to see on page 17 the table of requests completed and the time taken to complete those requests. There is quite a degree of variation which is attributable in part to the sitting periods. It seems like there are more requests for information when parliament sits than when parliament is not sitting. In the accounts at the end of the report, it is made very clear that it is very difficult to predict the flow of work, the amount of time required and the resources needed because it varies according to external factors over which the library has no control. But I think Senator Kemp would agree it is a good thing that nobody can ration our access to the library. That would be an horrendous situation.

I am very pleased that the library has done such a good job. I wish we could have had more opportunity to scrutinise this in further detail. I note that Senator Kemp is keen to make a contribution to the debate on the report. I only hope that, if there are no honourable senators who wish to follow Senator Kemp in his comments, he will seek leave to continue his remarks so that we can keep the debate open.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to comment on the report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library. PARA.TAB: I find the Parliamentary Library a most effective and responsive organisation.I would like to put on record my appreciation for the assistance that I have received from the many people in the library who have been able to provide me with useful briefing notes and research on often quite obscure topics and to provide it in a very efficient and effective way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes four measures announced in the 1995-96 Budget.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Rebatable and frankable dividends

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will give effect to the 1995-96 Budget announcement that dividends paid out of share capital funds and asset revaluation reserves will not be rebatable or frankable.

This is an anti-avoidance measure which will apply to dividends paid after 7.30pm Eastern Standard Time on 9 May 1995, unless declared before that time or paid under certain transitional arrangements.
The measure is expected to prevent a significant loss to the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Infrastructure borrowings

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will give effect to the 1995-96 Budget announcement to increase the infrastructure borrowings tax rebate from 33 per cent to 36 per cent. The increase in the rebate corresponds to the change in the company tax rate and will have effect from a taxpayer's 1995-96 income year.
The estimated cost to the revenue of the increase in the rebate is $2 million in 1995-96, $8 million in 1996-97 and $10 million in 1997-98.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reduction of PAYE early remitter threshold

SPEECH.PARA: The bill amends the law to lower, from $5 million to $1 million, the threshold at which a group employer is treated as an early remitter. As a result, the twice monthly remittance arrangements will apply to group employers who have annual PAYE remittances in excess of $1 million per year.
The amendment will bring forward $275 million into the 1995-96 year of income.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Depreciation on trading ships

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1995-96 Budget the Government announced an extension of the operation of the provision allowing for accelerated depreciation of trading ships. The concession will phase out on 30 June 2002 instead of 30 June 1997. This extension parallels the extension of the Ships (Capital Grants) Act 1987. That act provides a grant against the capital cost of purchasing an eligible Australian ship.
This measure will cost the revenue $11 million in 1997-98 and $16 million in 1998-99.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Superannuation guarantee charge—excess benefits

SPEECH.PARA: Employers who do not provide the minimum level of superannuation support for their employees are liable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge. Currently, this charge applies even if an employee has already accumulated superannuation entitlements in excess of the reasonable benefits limit or RBL. Superannuation benefits which are in excess of the RBL are taxed at the highest marginal rate in the hands of the recipient.

This bill will allow employees with accumulated superannuation entitlements in excess of the pension RBL to make an election not to receive superannuation support from their employers. When an employee makes the election, the employer will be exempted from the superannuation guarantee charge in respect of that employee.
Employees who make this election will, however, be denied income tax deductions for personal superannuation contributions.
The measure will have minimal impact on the revenue.
Superannuation guarantee charge—notional earnings base
The bill will amend the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992 to extend the use of pre 21 August 1991 employee earnings bases if employers restructure their superannuation funds.

Under the existing earnings base regime, as soon as an employer transfers members to another fund or amalgamates funds, the employer loses the right to contribute under a pre 21 August 1991 earnings base. A new employer acquiring a business loses the right to contribute to the existing superannuation fund on the pre 21 August 1991 base available to the former employer.

The bill proposes to extend the right to contribute under the same earnings base if members transfer to another of their employer's superannuation funds or a reorganisation of superannuation funds occurs in a business acquisition.

The measure is consistent with the Government's general approach to superannuation policy, which is to encourage appropriate restructuring of superannuation arrangements to ensure that benefits are provided with the lowest possible administrative costs.
The amendments will take effect from 1 July 1995, for reorganisations which took place on or after the Treasurer's announcement of the measure on 28 June 1994.
The amendments do not have any impact on the revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Bankruptcy and losses

SPEECH.PARA: The bill will give effect to the Treasurer's announcement on 26 February 1995 of the Government's intention to strengthen and extend the provisions of the law that deny deductions for losses where debts are released under bankruptcy law.

The amendment will ensure that, where an annulment of bankruptcy occurs in connection with arrangements under which debts are or may be released, revenue losses will be denied as if the bankruptcy had not been annulled.
In addition, the bill amends the capital gains tax provisions to ensure that net capital losses are also denied where a taxpayer has become a bankrupt or is released from debts under bankruptcy law.
The revenue gain will be less than $1 million per year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Group certificates and other PAYE provisions

SPEECH.PARA: The bill amends the income tax law to require group employers to provide original group certificates to the Australian Taxation Office rather than to employees. The changes will facilitate the introduction of optical character recognition equipment by the Australian Taxation Office. The new equipment will be able to more efficiently and accurately capture employment income data and assist in identifying areas of potential non-compliance.

The amendments have provided an opportunity to generally modernise the group tax provisions of the law. For example, a new system of tax vouchers is being introduced to partially replace the outmoded tax stamp system, and the Commissioner will be able to apply excess PAYE credits against other debts owing to the Commissioner, in line with more recently enacted collection systems. The amendments also use a clearer drafting style and structure than the provisions they replace.
The amendments are expected to result in an unquantifiable revenue savings through increased integrity of the income matching system and some public debt interest savings.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Foreign income

SPEECH.PARA: Australia now has a comprehensive system for taxing foreign source income. The first two parts of the system were the foreign tax credit system and the controlled foreign company measures. The foreign investment fund measures constitute the third and final part of the system.

The bill contains an amendment to the controlled foreign company measures that will reduce compliance costs and facilitate corporate restructures involving foreign companies. The amendment will have the effect that only capital gains and losses which accrue after a company becomes a controlled foreign company will give rise to attributable income.
This amendment will result in an unquantifiable loss to revenue.
The bill also contains three amendments that close potential tax avoidance loopholes in the foreign source income provisions.

First, the rules for obtaining a foreign tax credit will be tightened to ensure that a credit is not available for tax which is effectively refunded to the payer or to another person. A credit will also be denied where a benefit is provided as a direct result of the payment of foreign tax.

Secondly, the amendments will clarify that adjustments reflecting arm's length values can be made to amounts used in determining whether a controlled foreign company has passed the active income test.

Thirdly, rules will be introduced to ensure that the controlled foreign company measures are not avoided by the liquidation of a controlled foreign company prior to the end of the period for which its attributable income is calculated.
The closure of these loopholes will result in an unquantifiable gain to revenue.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Minor amendment

SPEECH.PARA: The bill also makes a minor technical amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment (Drought Relief Measures) Act 1995.
Full details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable senators.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995 and move:

PARA.TAB: That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES BILL 1995
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES CHARGES BILL 1995
PRIMARY INDUSTRIES LEVIES AND CHARGES (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

The purpose of this package of bills is to rationalise into a single framework the 59 separate levies and charges acts currently imposing levies on primary industry products. It complements the significant rationalisation of the levies and charges collection legislation that took place in 1991 and is consistent with Blewett report that sought to reduce the parliamentary legislative program.

It is designed to overcome past problems caused by the volume of Primary Industries and Energy portfolio legislation and the logjam the levies and charges legislation created by requiring constant amendment in the parliament.

We have analysed the problem, consulted extensively with industry and concluded that amalgamating all the levies and charges into two framework acts will make more effective use of parliamentary time dealing with levy legislation. It will also assist industry to have changes to levies put in place more rapidly than on some occasions in the past.

The levies and charges in question are not unilaterally imposed by the government, but rather are sought by representative industry bodies, on behalf of the industry. Their purpose is to fund activities such as marketing and research and development that would be beyond the scope of individual farmers on their own. I would expect that more levies will be requested by industry in the future, particularly in new and emerging industries and most probably for R&D.

The levies bill and the charges bill set up a framework for imposing levies on primary industry products by regulation. They will allow new industries or new products to be included quickly on the request of the industry concerned, while, at the same time, protecting parliament's powers to decide on these matters.

It is important to recognise that this streamlining process will not change the practical impact of the current legislation but only the way levies are established or amended. There will be no discernible difference from the industry point of view in the way that the levies and charges processes operate other than that any changes they wish to make to maximum levy or charge rates will be able to be completed in a much shorter time frame.

Previously maximum rates for levies and charges were included in each individual levy or charge act to give parliament control over any arbitrary imposition of taxation. Because of the wide variety of bases for the calculation of the levy and charge rates it was not possible to find a suitable formula covering all industries to include in the framework legislation.

The bills therefore require the maximum rates of each levy or charge to be set out in special regulations. Normal regulations come into effect on gazettal before they are tabled in parliament. These special regulations will not come into effect until after the parliamentary disallowance period is completed. This still gives the parliament the ultimate role in determining maximum rates.

Impositions of levy or changes to levy matters such as maximum and operative rates can only be made on the recommendation of the designated body and after the required consultation with the relevant industry.

The bills also require any increases in maximum rates to be published in a daily newspaper in the states and territories to ensure that individuals in an industry are aware of them. Initially, the maximum rates to be included in the special regulations are likely to be the same as those currently applying in each industry, unless the industry has specifically sought a different rate.

The bills allow the minister to declare a designated body or bodies for each industry to make recommendations regarding the setting of levy or charge rates. Where there is more than one designated body for a particular industry these bodies will be required to agree on any recommendations they make to the minister.

Designated bodies are also required to consult with other representative bodies. For example, if the designated body for a particular industry is a peak grower body, it is required by reference to section 22 of the Primary Industries Levies Bill 1995 to consult with any other eligible industry bodies set out in the relevant statutory marketing authority act before making recommendations to the minister.
The relevant industry or product regulations will contain

PARA.TAB: the detail of the particular levies or charges,
who is liable to pay them,
how and when they will be collected, and
what they will be used for.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulations for each industry will be very similar to the regulations currently in force, but will include some provisions from the old levy or charge acts that do not appear in the new bills because they were too specific for the framework nature of the new bills. We will be circulating draft copies of the regulations to industry organisations for comment when they are drafted. This continues the consultative approach we have adopted with industry through the development of this streamlined levy package.

A third bill is included in this package—the Primary Industries Levies and Charges (Consequential Amendments) Bill 1995. This bill includes the repeal of the old levies and charges acts and a number of amendments to other acts that make reference to the old levy and charges acts. These amendments are necessary to ensure that levies and charges can still be collected and the correct amounts can be paid to the correct organisations.

The commencement date for this legislative package is 1 July 1996 to allow time for the regulations for all the relevant industries to be made and tabled in the parliament. However, certain sections of the legislation will commence on royal assent to allow designated bodies to be declared and maximum rates, to be set in time for the commencement of operation of the levies and charges acts. Regulations relating to operative rates of levies and charges will also be able to be made and tabled for disallowance following royal assent but these regulations will not come into force until the remainder of the act commences on 1 July 1996.

A wide range of representative bodies in all the primary industries covered by the current levy and charge arrangements have given broad support to the approach being taken. Draft copies of these bills have been made available for comment to these bodies.
Let me remind honourable senators that this legislation was inspired by two things
industry's need for a streamlined and more responsive process; and
a need to make better use of parliamentary time.
There are advantages on both sides by making this process work.
I commend the bills to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum.

DEBATE.TITLE: HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE CORPORATION (TRANSFER OF ASSETS AND ABOLITION) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Transfer of Assets and Abolition) Bill 1995 will provide legislative authority for measures that will assist in giving effect to the Government's decision to restructure the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation.
It will also provide for the abolition of related legislation, namely the Housing Loans Insurance Act 1965 and the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Act 1990.

The restructuring, or corporatisation, of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was announced in the 1995-96 Budget. It is designed to provide the Corporation with greater freedom to operate on a strict commercial basis and, as such, to put it on a more comparable footing vis-a-vis its competitors.

The decision to follow this approach reflects the same considerations that had earlier influenced the Government to attempt to sell the Corporation, namely that the prevailing conditions in the mortgage insurance and finance industries now differ considerably compared with when the Corporation was set up.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation was established as a statutory authority thirty years ago to meet a structural deficiency in the highly-regulated financial environment which existed at that time. Its primary charter was to help low income earners with small deposits to obtain housing finance; financial institutions tended to allocate their then scarce housing funds on a least-risk basis.

Since those days, a competitive private sector mortgage insurance industry has emerged in Australia. Together with the finance industry reforms introduced by this Government, this has removed the old structural deficiency in the housing finance market.

With these improvements in access to housing finance, the objective of the Government has been to maintain and enhance these achievements by ensuring that there is an efficient, diverse and competitive mortgage insurance market. The decision a number of years ago to attempt to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation reflected the view that the continued involvement of a statutory authority in the industry was not consistent with this objective.
However, efforts to sell the Corporation have not proceeded since it has become clear that the sale was not going to produce a satisfactory result.

As a consequence, the Government has considered alternative approaches. It commissioned the Task Force on Asset Sales' financial advisers, Baring Bros Burrows and Co Limited, to undertake a complete review of the sale process and the Corporation's position in the market. They concluded, among other things, that the Corporation enjoyed a number of advantages over its private sector competitors arising from its statutory authority status, including the guarantee of its liabilities, and from the fact that it is not subject to the supervision of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC).

As these benefits, which put the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation on a different basis to its competitors, would not be available to any potential purchasers, it was difficult for them to establish the nature and size of the business that would exist post-sale and, so, to put a value on the Corporation.

The corporatisation arrangements that the Government now proposes represent a significant move in addressing these concerns. A new company will be established under the Corporations Law which will be subject to the regulatory requirements of ISC, as well as those of the States and Territories. The new company will be fully capitalised in line with the requirements of the ISC, drawing on part of the present capital and reserves of the Corporation.

The existing Commonwealth guarantee will be removed as far as borrowings by the Corporation is concerned. However, the Commonwealth guarantee for non-borrowing liabilities has been retained, at least for the moment, to minimise any uncertainty in the mortgage insurance industry that might arise as a consequence of the restructuring of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, given its prominent position in the market. Furthermore, to enable the company to attain the minimum credit rating required for mortgage insurers by state legislation without retaining that guarantee, it would be necessary for the Commonwealth to commit significant additional capital resources to the Corporation, over and above what is already proposed.
However, in setting a target rate of return for the company, account will be taken of any advantage the retention of the guarantee may accord it.

With the removal of the guarantee on borrowing, there is no longer a need for a specific legislative provision as the Treasurer has the powers under the Constitution to guarantee liabilities of a non-borrowing nature.

The Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will cease writing business on the day before the new company comes into operation. The insurance policies of the Corporation entered into prior to and including that date, which we might refer to as the `old book', will become the direct responsibility of the Commonwealth. In exchange for accepting these liabilities, the Commonwealth will receive the balance of the Corporation's capital and reserves. On the Budget estimates, the level of funds likely to be transferred to consolidated revenue is expected to be in excess of $100 million.

The new Housing Loans Insurance Corporation will be contracted by the Commonwealth to administer the unexpired portion of all insurance obligations contained in the `old book'. Funds will be set aside by the Commonwealth in a special account to be established by this new company and will be replenished as and when necessary to meet claims against these insurance contracts.

The transfer of the `old book' to the Commonwealth along these lines is consistent with the arrangements that would have been put in place had the sale of the Corporation proceeded in 1991. Separation of the `old book' will, in particular, enable the new company's performance to be judged independently of the Corporation's previous operations.
The bill currently before the Senate is designed to assist in giving effect to the arrangements that I have just outlined. It includes the following:
provision to the Treasurer of the necessary powers to direct the transfer of assets and liabilities in whatever way is considered appropriate to give effect to the abovementioned objectives;

authority for the Treasurer to enter into an agreement with the new Company which would cover the terms under which existing insurance contracts would be managed, as well as the means by which payments for claims arising from these contracts could be made. The latter includes a standing appropriation for the required funding;

the transfer of staff of the Corporation to the new company, as well as the transfer of all current rights enjoyed by those staff with respect to such matters as long service leave, superannuation, maternity leave and Comcare. It is not intended that the interests of the staff should in any way be adversely affected by this corporatisation exercise;
provision to exempt from taxation transactions involving such matters as the transfer of assets that would not have arisen apart from the corporatisation exercise; and

finally, the winding up of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and the repeal of all relevant legislation relating to the Corporation. As part of the winding up exercise, a final report and detailed financial statements as at the date of cessation of the Corporation's activities will be prepared by the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. After being audited by the Audit office, they will be tabled in the Parliament in due course.

I conclude by pointing out to the Senate that the restructuring of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation that is proposed is seen by the Government as an important step in its efforts to maintain an efficient and competitive mortgage insurance market.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
