SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Employment Services Act 1994 established the case management system and established the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) as an independent statutory authority responsible for regulating the case management system.

The bill would make machinery changes consequential to the implementation of changed case management arrangements for certain part-time and seasonal workers. It would also streamline certain administrative procedures relating to CES notification requirements and allow the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA) to obtain goods and services by using a credit card.

The bill would provide for consequential amendments arising from proposed changes to the Social Security Act 1991 that would amalgamate job search allowance and newstart allowance. It would also amend the Social Security Act to provide for the National Convenor of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal to delegate his or her powers under the Employment Services Act.

In particular, the bill would allow for inclusion in determinations made under the act provisions relating to resetting unemployment registration to zero of particular clients who decline to continue to participate in the case management system. This is in line with announcements made in the 1995-96 Budget and already implemented. The new arrangements were introduced for part-time and seasonal workers because they have substantial and recent workforce experience and may not require, or in some instances want, the level of assistance provided under case management. The bill would seek to make consequential amendments to that part of the act that defines Job Compact eligibility for the purposes of a Case Management Activity Agreement.

The bill would streamline requirements on the CES to notify and interview a person after they become a participant in the case management system. The existing provisions of the Employment Services Act 1994 require two separate contacts to be made; the first being when a person becomes a participant in the case management system and the second when the person is to be referred to a case manager. The bill would require the CES to make a single contact with the jobseeker for the purpose of notifying participant status and for requesting the jobseeker to attend or take part in an interview. Under the bill notification that a person is a participant in the case management system will be made when the CES calls the jobseeker in for an interview and considers that a referral can be made to a case manager within 24 days of a referral interview taking place.

At present, ESRA is unable to use Government credit card facilities because the act does not provide for it to borrow money. To overcome the administrative inconvenience this causes, the bill would provide for ESRA to obtain goods and services on credit by the use of a credit card.

Consequential amendments are also required to the act following changes to the Social Security Act 1991 to allow for the amalgamation of Jobsearch and Newstart Allowance with effect from 20 September 1996. The bill would provide for these consequential amendments.
I commend the bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [No. 2]FAMILY LAW REFORM (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1995

PROCTEXT.PARA: FAMILY LAW REFORM BILL 1994 [No. 2]

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Watson)—The committee is considering the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone to the Family Law Reform Bill 1994 [No. 2].

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to this amendment, I think it is worth while to refer back to the report of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee dated March 1995. Recommendation 3 of that report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Family Court of Australia monitor parenting plans when filed in the Registry. The Court should make rules specifying the information required in the plan.

That is precisely what this amendment seeks to do. As I recall it, in the course of the hearings in relation to this bill, the Law Council of Australia put to the committee the assertion that in property matters the court inquires into deeds of agreement reached between the parties to see that they are just and equitable. When you come to children, I think it was Senator Spindler who said that they should not be treated just like chattels. When you look at the requirements made of the Family Court in relation to real property and personal property, I would say that the requirements should be more onerous when looking at the welfare of children. Mr Watt, who is Deputy Chairman of the family law section of the Law Council of Australia, said:

We are talking about people being able to enter into parenting plans or obtain consent orders simply by filing with the courts an agreement that has been signed around the kitchen table . . . That is exactly what is happening under this proposal.
He went on to say:

. . . When parties separate, or even just upon disagreement arising within the marriage before they separate, they can say this is what is going to happen to the children and, under the bill as it presently stands, they can write it down on a piece of paper and, provided they sign it, one of the parties can then take that off to the court and register it as a parenting plan.

Mr Watt went on to say, and this was echoed by Senator Vanstone earlier, that this then has effect as if it were an order of the court. Of course, other consequential matters flow from that. The scrap of paper is no longer a scrap of paper. It has the full effect and force of a Family Court order.

PARA.TAB: I would submit to the Senate that what we have is a situation where, if the plan is to have that effect, then the court should have the ability to inquire into the best interests of the children. When one looks at the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone, proposed section 63D firstly provides for independent legal advice, which I think is a very good idea. Senator Vanstone has more than adequately set out as to how one party may be in a more subordinate role to the other and therefore in need of separate advice, particularly in a relationship where one party exercises some degree of emotional control over the other. That is important to start with.

Secondly, the court has to be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child. That is imperative. Subsection (2) goes on to say that, in looking at what is likely to promote the best interests of the child, the court may have regard to the matters set out in subsection 68F(2). It sets out a whole raft of criteria that deal with what the court might hold to be in the best interests of the child. The age of the child, the health of the child and other aspects are dealt with there. If needs be, the court can inquire into the plan that has been put before it and, in doing so, can have regard to this whole range of criteria set out in 68F(2). That gives the court some important flexibility.

I am not saying that every parenting plan that is presented to the court will require this. It won't. It may be that in 10 per cent or even in five per cent of cases the court will have to inquire further and address these issues. Even if it is in a minority of cases of the order I mentioned—such low percentages as five or 10—it is still important that the court have that ability to inquire further. That is absolutely essential when one looks at this.

We have that requirement for property. The court has to make sure that any deed of agreement in relation to property is fair and equitable. Since the inception of the Family Law Act the court is placed in a position where it inquires behind the agreement that is placed before it. In a situation dealing with children, the matter becomes even more important. The best interests of the children must be taken into consideration and the court, in some cases, has to undertake an affirmative role in this regard.
Paragraph (3) of the amendment states:
The Rules of Court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court.

SPEECH.PARA: That is self-evident. Therefore, I submit that this amendment moved by Senator Vanstone incorporates the concerns mentioned by Senator Spindler on behalf of the Democrats in relation to the best interests of the children. It is an important aspect. That concern was raised before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee and is one which certainly had the strong support of the family law section of the Australian Law Council. For the variety of grounds I have put to the chamber, I commend this amendment and implore the government to once again assess its position in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little concerned. I have great respect for the opinions of Senator Vanstone, Senator Spindler and Senator Ellison. We have discussed this backwards and forwards in the committee.
—Poor old Senator Abetz got left out.
—And Senator Abetz, but he has not spoken on this yet. Have you spoken on this?
—Not yet.
—He has not spoken yet. I will be very impressed when he does speak. I give a preview of my position.

PARA.TAB: When we are talking about children it is a little different to when we are talking about property. Property is disposed of once and for all. You say, `You have the house, you have the car, you have the farm,' and so on. The property is distributed among the two parties, and that is the end of it. To compare children to property is the wrong concept. To say we have to deal with the property in the correct way and, therefore, we have to deal with the children in an even more correct way misses the point, because children are not property.

Under this new legislation, children will be subject to both parents while their parents live. You have to try to work out a scheme that can accommodate both parents and the children. The children are, as they ought to be, the main matter of concern for any legislature. If the parents work out a plan which both feel happy with for the children's sake and for their own sakes and if the plan they have worked out is correct and the children will be looked after properly, why should not that position remain until some problem arises?

The problem I have with the amendment moved by Senator Vanstone is that it is very much the same as the amendment moved by Senator Spindler. It is introducing the court at the wrong point in time. The court ought to be introduced when the problem arises. With property, the problem arises when it is to be distributed. Once it is distributed, that is it. With children, the problem arises when something goes wrong with the arrangements that the parents have made. It is at that point in time that the court ought to look at what is happening. That is the point I want to make.

That would be in the interests of the court. If you are going to have this situation, there will be a need for a lot more judges than you presently have and for a lot more court space. Senator Vanstone's amendment states:
A parenting plan may be registered in a court having jurisdiction under this Part if:
(a) it is signed by the parties . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is fair enough; and if the parties have been provided with independent legal advice. That situation could lead to a lot of clumsiness as to how an agreement can be brought into operation. Each party has to get together the funds to see separate lawyers to get a considerable amount of advice. If the lawyer charges a moderate fee, it is going to be an expensive exercise.

PARA.TAB: There would be a demand for more legal aid, which is proper. There is such a demand for legal aid now that to introduce a demand where I say there is no need for it could be a little unwise.

Even more importantly, it introduces into an agreement that the parties might want to reach the need for legal advice, which is not always likely to be a good thing. The amendment refers to the court having to be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child.

Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, I say to Senator Vanstone: that would seem to require the court going through a full-scale hearing. If the court has to satisfy itself that the plans are likely to promote the best interests of the child, I would have thought that required a fairly long and extensive investigation by the court. You would have a hearing. The very need for a plan would hardly continue to exist.

People might come to a parenting plan and not register it. Wouldn't that be sensible? If you are going to set out a regime which makes things quite difficult, why would you register it? Why wouldn't you come to a parenting plan and go ahead on that basis? If you go ahead on that basis, why penalise the parents, who might want to register a plan, by making things much more difficult than would be the case if they did not register it?

I think there should be a monitoring process—say the registrar monitors it or somebody goes through the plan and looks at it and says, `This seems to be reasonable,' and that is it. To require the court to satisfy itself seems to be a terribly involved process. Why don't we just monitor the plans? The registrar or a judge could read through the plan and see whether it is right on the face of it and lets it go. To require this process to be gone through seems to be pretty complicated.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Watson)—Senator Cooney, are you moving an amendment or are you seeking an explanation from Senator Vanstone?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just asking Senator Vanstone, Senator Ellison and Senator Spindler what they think of it.

—I would like to contribute again to the debate on this amendment I moved. I would like to add to something that Senator Spindler raised earlier when we were debating this matter prior the matters of public interest discussion. The point he raised was that the government might be happy with this arrangement for parenting plans and to have no scrutiny at all, not even the monitoring at a very low level that I think Senator Cooney is suggesting—and I will come to whether I agree with that or not. But the government would say, `Well, when one party fails to stick to the agreement, that is when the problem arises and that is when the court needs to come in.' Senator Cooney you were, in fact, emphasising that point yourself. You did not respond to a number of matters that were raised earlier in the debate—and I do not think you were here at that point, Senator Cooney; you were probably in your room listening—namely, if you have two parties of unequal strength and there are any consequences at all that hang on the agreement, then surely you want to ensure that the weaker party has some advice before entering into that agreement.

PARA.TAB: There is nobody who is of the view that parties are always equal in matrimonial proceedings. It is pretty well a 100 per cent view that one party is weaker than the other; and if there are consequences that hang on the agreement being registered, then those parties should be independently advised. I do not assume that you would, generally speaking, disagree with that. If parties are going to register something in a court and consequences flow from it, they should have advice prior to doing that.

Senator Cooney says, as I say, that when the problem arises the court will concern itself with what is in the best interests of the child. There are two points to make. Firstly, it is not only the interests of the child that are being looked at here. While they are paramount, it is the interests of the weaker party as well. We need to ensure that they are protected in terms of their access to the child. There are a whole range of things they might want some advice on. It is better to do that than have them realise, having signed an agreement, that they would have been better to have the advice on it.

Secondly, let us not just focus on whether, if one party breaks the agreement, you are then going to the court to try to get enforcement proceedings—and we are satisfying ourselves that at least the court will then look at what is in the best interests of the child. Let us look at where the parties decide they want to easily change the agreement and they do not agree as to how it ought to be changed. That is the only time at which you say the court can come into it.

Let us say that it is the weaker party who has made the agreement and wants to change it. I am talking about a couple here who, we will assume for the purposes of this debate, have the best interests of their child or children at heart and there has been some change in circumstances. She might have got a job full time as opposed to part time; his income might have changed; he might want to move interstate—or whatever. A whole range of matters—I am sure you can list hundreds of them, Senator Cooney—can happen that mean the parties want to change the agreement, and one party may want to change it in a different way from that in which the other party wants to change it.

Senator Cooney, I would be interested in hearing how easily you think that is done once this is registered as an order of the court. Let us assume for the sake of the argument that it is the weaker party—because that is always the one the law would be looking to protect—who wants to change the agreement because of changed circumstances and the stronger party does not. It may well be that that is at much more expense to the weaker party—and I understand the point you made about the expense of getting legal advice. And, if I say so myself, Senator Cooney, I thought you came very close to making some slightly disparaging remarks about the legal profession. I certainly hope I did not hear a glimmer of insult towards the profession in your remarks. You were certainly very limited in your praise as to what benefit might be available to parties if they did seek legal advice at an earlier stage.

In the situation that I am raising, some circumstances have changed, the weaker party may want to change the agreement and the stronger party does not agree. I do not think you can assure us, Senator Cooney, that the weaker party would not in those circumstances have benefited from legal advice in the first place. The weaker party will be up for much greater costs than the initial advice in getting the agreement changed.

I suppose it is similar to why I would advise someone to get legal advice before they make a will, instead of trotting down to their local stationery shop and filling in predetermined paragraph headings. The reason would be that it is only with some skill in a particular area that you can look to the future. Plenty of people make the mistake of making a will and listing such assets that they have now and not putting appropriate remarks in to cover other assets that they acquire and what will happen with the rest of them. They do not adequately cater for what will happen if one of the parties to whom they were leaving something dies before they do. I am sure you understand what I am saying, Senator Cooney. Someone trained in an area understands how circumstances might change. They have seen it day after day, with client after client.

Therefore, I would say that they are in a far better position to advise someone at the commencement of making an agreement: `what are you going to do if you want the kids to change school or he wants to move interstate?' They need to try to sort some of these things out at the beginning. The consequences of not doing that are that, when you want to change the agreement, the stronger party is going to use all the force that he or she can, and the weaker party is going to have much greater expense in trying to get that agreement changed.

So I just put it to you that the only reason for wanting advice is not the paramount interests of the child. They are paramount, but it is also the interests of the weaker party, because there are consequences for both parties of registering. If you say, Senator Cooney, `Well, no, there is not. There is really nothing to it; it is just a pretty stamp that is put on it by the court,' then why are we bothering to make the change? I do not think you were suggesting that it is nothing more than a stamp. It has the imprimatur of a federal court on the agreement. It becomes a court order. Rights and duties and obligations are affected.

I would have thought, Senator Cooney, that in all those circumstances you would have agreed that the parties should be independently advised. I thought you would have agreed to that because you know, as just about everyone else does, that there is always a weaker party in these types of negotiations. So I would be interested if Senator Cooney or the minister might like to advise as to what the anticipated costs and procedures would be for changing an agreement when one party does not want to change it. That may cast some light on the whole discussion.

As to the last point you raised, Senator Cooney, my advice is that if you take what we are proposing in 63D(1)(c) and combine it with 63D(2), you, in effect, end up with the same sort of attention given to the matter as the court would give to consent orders. That, to me, seems appropriate. If you somehow believe that that is not correct, that we have been ill advised, I am sure we would be happy to listen. Senator Spindler has shifted his position a bit, and I have shifted mine a bit in order to come to some agreement here, partly through different understandings of what it was that we each wanted to achieve. If you are so convinced, then perhaps you could either offer an alternative or explain why the combination of those two does not end up the same as consent orders.

Last but not least, you make the point that if you do this people will simply come to agreements on their own. What on earth is the matter with that? If people do happily come to agreements about what to do with their children, what is the problem?

TALK.START.PARA: —Hallelujah—that's what we are saying—without lawyers. What have you been on about?

—Yes, but the point you are wanting to push, Minister, is that there is some benefit for those people in registering the plan. What I am saying is that, if people are perfectly happy amongst themselves, let them remain so. If you are going to shift it above that—a flexible agreement between two parties who have the best interests of their child at heart—and make it a court order, then you have to have some sort of advice, especially for the weaker party, and, understandably, for the best interests of the child.

PARA.TAB: That seems to me to be the appropriate arrangement. Do not try to implement a system where everybody who separates and divorces somehow comes to the conclusion that they must register their parenting plan. Why should they? If they do not have a problem with it, if they are happy that as time goes by they can resolve the disagreements they may have about changed circumstances, let them remain unregistered. We are talking about a different category—a category of people who have come, presumably, with some difficulty to this plan and want some confidence that the other party is going to stick to it. It can otherwise be described as wanting some consequences hanging on the agreement—that means rights and duties are affected. That means, Senator Cooney, you ought to be interested in the rights, duties and obligations of the weaker party.

TALK.START.PARA: —In dealing with this particular amendment—and as I said before, Senator Vanstone's is really based on the one that I have put forward—I have always been very conscious of the fact that we are making a decision on balance. I am not after creating a bonanza for lawyers or increasing the costs to people who want to go through a divorce. I am not at all reticent in saying that if we can keep the lawyers out, let's do it. But there is, I think, a genuine concern here about the power imbalance that could obtain where people are influenced unduly by the other party; where they are overshadowed by the knowledge of the personality of the other party; or where they have not got requisite knowledge, expertise and facility in negotiation. Even where they do have these things, I think it is important that the court does not renege on its obligation to give priority to the welfare of the child.

PARA.TAB: There are two other options or changes that I will float at this stage to see whether they find any favour with other people in the chamber—with Senator Vanstone or with the government. The first is in (b) where the amendment currently asks for `independent legal advice'. I wonder whether we could consider `independent advice by a court counsellor' as an alternative to `independent advice by the legal practitioner'. That would certainly address the cost question to a large extent. One would imagine that if a court counsellor is prepared to append her or his signature to the statement, they would have carefully considered the position that is being adopted by the party in becoming a signatory to the agreement. That may be one alteration that goes some way towards minimising the cost factor.

The second amendment that I would like to suggest is in (3) which currently reads, `The Rules of Court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court.'. I wonder whether we can change that to, `The plan may be assessed by the court.' That means that the court could have the option of not going to a full hearing, but making a rule that the registrar of the court peruses the agreement on a range of however many checkpoints you want to establish to test it.

So that option would be open to the court. It does not exclude the court's capacity to have the case before it. I guess the rules could provide that if the registrar is unhappy or uncomfortable, the parenting agreement could be referred to the court for a full hearing. I would imagine that would be necessary in only very few cases. Just to formalise what I am saying, I propose an amendment to (b) to the effect that `legal' in line three be removed so that it reads, `with independent advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the legal practitioner or court counsellor who provided that advice.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to make a contribution to this debate until Senator Cooney said that I would undoubtedly make a very valid contribution. He must have known what was going on in my head. I thought there was a lot of merit in what Senator Cooney said. So far today, anyway, we have been dealing with this bill on a very bipartisan basis. Whilst I do not have any intention of doing anything radical and voting against the approach of my party on this issue, I do want to float some of my concerns about this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I believe there is one fundamental principle; that is, anybody ought to have access to the justice system should they wish, without engaging a solicitor. I say that as a solicitor, and I would say to the people who do so that they are foolish and stupid, but they ought to have that fundamental right. Those of us who have been engaged in Family Court trials where people are self-represented know how very tedious it can become. Nevertheless, that ought be a fundamental right. I stand by that.

It is a question, I suppose, as to how much the government and legislation are to spoon-feed people. I know that my shadow Attorney-General talked about forms for wills that you can buy from a newsagent. I would agree with her. It is very foolish to make a will that way; and, at a later time, I have had to try to fix some of those wills in my office. But I would not be in favour of making those forms illegal and saying that you can only ever have a will if it is prepared for you by a legal practitioner. There is a fairly fundamental point in that and it is, I suppose, the basis on which I make my comments.

It seems to me to be somewhat incongruous that, if mum and dad are married or together, they can determine what is good for the children but if they then decide no longer to remain together, they can somehow, even if they want to, be no longer capable of determining what is in the best interests of their children. The reality is that the vast majority of parents do not use the facilities of the Family Court to determine issues of custody and other matters. They sort those things out for themselves.

I understand the argument about the weaker party. But how far can we go to protect the weaker party? Chances are, if somebody is very dominant they will bully a person not to even go to court with a parenting plan. So those who are the real bullies will ensure it never gets to the court in the first place for the court to look at it.

If it can be shown that an order was made under duress then there are the provisions in the Family Law Act to undo that at a later stage. The plan that is being proposed in this bill is basically a plan on the basis of agreement between the parties. If agreement can be achieved, I would have thought that a clause, in a standard plan which says that there was no fraud or duress applied, might be an appropriate way of dealing with that. The rules of court may possibly determine the particular form that the registration ought to have.

I am quite attracted to Senator Spindler's suggestion. Before any matter comes before the Family Court these days, the parties have to have a counselling session before the first mention date of the matter in the court. Therefore, a counsellor is already involved. It should not be beyond the wit of an independent counsellor to determine whether or not there is some power imbalance between the parties and whether somebody has been bulldozed into signing the parenting plan. As a result, Senator Spindler's amendment does have some merit. I would accept that as a compromise.

My starting point would still be that, if mum and dad while they are together can come to an agreement on how their children ought to be looked after, if they separate and can still come to such an agreement why on earth would we not allow them to simply register that with a court?

I understand the argument of the shadow Attorney-General (Senator Vanstone), that we are asking for the imprimatur of the court and, therefore, it would be appropriate for the court to satisfy itself that it is an appropriate plan. But, having said that, I would hope and wish that the court would not involve itself in any detailed analysis. The logical flowthrough would be that, if, just because they are separated, you are going to check up on parents who voluntarily come to the court with an agreement, why on earth do we not involve the courts when the parents are together? Why don't we worry about the weaker party within the family unit while it is still together?

That argument, if you work it backwards, has some very concerning aspects to it in relation to the family unit. As bad as families may be, I believe that they usually are the best place to bring up kids. Much as counsellors, lawyers, et cetera, may be well meaning, mum and dad usually know best. At the end of the day, if mum and dad can agree about the way the kids ought to be brought up, I would say that 99.9 per cent of the time that is the best way for it to go, especially for the children. If the kids know that mum and dad worked out this agreement together, and mum and dad are both happy with it, then I am sure their lives will be so much easier when they have contact with the parent with whom they do not reside on a full-time basis.

I turn to the suggestion made by Senator Spindler for proposed section 63D.(3): `The Rules of Court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court.' I think you have suggested the deletion of the word `registered' and to replace it with `assessed.' I wonder whether, possibly, we ought to have both, because the rules of the court possibly ought to deal with the way that it is registered. I agree that, possibly, the rules of court ought to determine the way that it is assessed as well.

If Senator Spindler would be agreeable, my suggestion would be that we insert the words `assessed and' before the word `registered' in subparagraph (3). I hope then that the rules of the court would not make it too difficult for the way the court may register a plan. That is the only contribution that I wish to make on that. I trust that we may be able to get some agreement on that. I see that the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and the shadow Attorney-General are in deep discussion. I hope that some compromise on a bipartisan basis can be achieved. I have run out of wind, but I do not know if we have actually reached an agreement which might satisfy most people in the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to what Senator Abetz said, I think the difference should be very obvious. When a family is intact and not going through the traumatic stage of separation, of course there is no reason to intervene or get the court to take any interest in it unless, of course, the children are, for instance, abused. That difference is accepted. We should not forget that there are well in excess of 20,000 cases of child abuse that have occurred in any one year within a family setting; but that is another story.

PARA.TAB: What we are dealing with is not an intact family. It is a family that has split up, where the partners have separated and the future wellbeing of the children is very much more at risk because they are now unlikely to have both parents caring for them continuously. I know that these amendments, in total, seek to maintain an involvement of both parties; the Democrats welcome that. Nevertheless, it is a traumatic period. Another situation is where the adults involved are concerned with setting themselves up and looking after their own interests in the post-separation period. We need to make sure that whatever arrangements they make in an effort to set themselves up do not disadvantage the children.

At the risk of causing further work for the clerk, I should state that I am happy to accept the suggestion by Senator Abetz; I think it is a good one. My amendment would therefore read `how the plan may be assessed and registered by a court'.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That one really throws me, because what you are now doing is getting the court in the process of assessing every plan.
—That has always been there.
—Not under the registration system we are talking about here, under section 86. We are not talking about that being there.
—I mean the amendment.

—I am prepared to put to you a counter-offer, which is a better one. I think it is one that probably fits more within your approach to this area. What I am prepared to suggest is that, where you have in part (b) of your amendment `that is to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice', we broaden that to include advice from family and child counsellors and family and child mediators, the definition of which is on page 3 of the Family Law Reform Act.
—Minister, are you aware that it was suggested that the word `legal' be deleted so it would be just `independent advice'?
—That is right—`independent advice'.
—It has been agreed on this side that the word `legal' would come out.

—We can handle that. I had not seen the latest amendment. That covers the field. I place on the record that when we say `independent advice' we mean a definition of adviser that covers family and child counsellor and family and child mediator.
—I would not accept `mediator'.
—What have you got against mediators?
—Mediator is quite a different function.
—They are the people who are up-front in the process.
—No, that is not their function.

—It may not be the lawyer's function to provide child counselling, for instance. If you are happy with the word `advice', then the meaning I would anticipate it having is broad enough to encompass those areas.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Watson)—As a point of clarification, what amendments are you accepting?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am accepting the amendment moved by Senator Spindler to Senator Vanstone's amendment. On that basis, I can live with Senator Vanstone's amendment as amended by Senator Spindler.
—Without clarification?

—Yes, but I do have problems with `assessed by a court'. I presume my advisers have the same problem with respect to that part of the amendment. We are moving from a system where an agreement is registered in a court to a system where, under Senator Spindler's amendment to Senator Vanstone's amendment—and you have argued for the last hour or so that the best way to provide protection is to provide it up-front, to get the advice and make sure that the advisers are registered—you are saying, as well as that, that we need to have the final agreement assessed by the court. That really burdens the process enormously. Unless someone has a point of view that that is not what you are doing and unless someone can tell me that the words `assessed by a court' do not mean assessed by a court then I think you ought to delete the second part of the amendment.

—I am happy to set the minister's mind at ease. Subsection (c) says that the court must be satisfied that the arrangements set out are likely to promote the best interests of the child. Subsection (c) addresses the mechanics by saying that the rules of the court may deal with how the plan may be assessed. I interpret that as meaning that the court, through its rules, may determine the manner of satisfying subsection 63D(1)(c). That is certainly the intention.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —We still have a problem that you are imparting a process of assessment by the court as opposed to a process of registration by the court. That is the problem that we have with 63D(1)(c). In the spirit of compromise, what I am suggesting is that you stick with the advice at the time of registration, which is what has been pushed by those on the other side, and not encumber the process with a further assessment process by the court in each individual case. That will impose a burden not only on the process but also on the people involved who will have to go through the court process with each individual case. I think Senator Abetz is picking up on this point and I hope others are as well.

—With the word `registered' does the minister envisage the court making rules as to the format of the parenting plan and the information that would be required to be included in the plan in order for the plan to be registered, much like the section 86 maintenance agreement where you simply went to the counter and filed the agreement? In the preamble to those agreements certain things have to be set out such as the date of the marriage, the age of the parties and the age of the children. Basically, the history of the matter is set out in the preamble. The agreement goes on to say, `Having this in mind, the parties have now come to this agreement.' Therefore, the court is able to make an assessment of the document itself. Is that what you are envisaging by the term `registered'?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is something very close to that if not that. We anticipate a system whereby—and I think we could do it by the rules of the court—the form of the agreement and some of those prerequisites can be incorporated. Obviously, you and I would not want to then go to the next step of ensuring that there are benchmarks in terms of what the agreement then provides in individual cases. In relation to the points you have raised, they are the sorts of points that would be covered by the prerequisites for the registration. It would be information based rather than a prescription as to the outcome.

—I say to Senator Spindler that his amendment relating to the question of registration and assessment being included initially attracted me. If registration includes the points that the minister has mentioned would that satisfy you, Senator Spindler? Provided the rules of registration require that information has to be included by which the court could make its decision—that is, the age of the children, where they have been living, how long the parties have been separated, who earns the money, where the children spend their time—and if there was—
—An agreed statement.
—an agreed statement of facts in the preamble to the agreement, would that be satisfactory?

—What we were attempting to do was leave the hands of the court untied as to the procedure that the court would follow in assessing and registering the agreement. I thought it was clear to actually have the word `assessed' in there. It is not imposing a duty on the court to assess the plan. I think that duty is imposed by 63D(1)(c).

PARA.TAB: Subsection (3) simply deals with giving the court the capacity to make rules as to how the plan should be assessed and registered. It simply means that if the court wishes to ask the registrar to use a checklist as a first step it may do so. We are not tying the hands of the court. If the court should decide that at a certain point these lists may be referred to it by the registrar it could do so through the rules of court. With respect, I think the minister is reading into the wording of my amendment something which is not there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, do you wish to respond?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that I do at this stage. I think Senator Vanstone might want to say something. What I am proposing is that we accept the first part of Senator Spindler's amendment, which is to basically delete the word `legal' in subsection (b), then delete paragraph (c) and leave the third part as it is.
—No.

—I know Senator Spindler does not want that. It is question of what `assess' means. You and I have different interpretations of it. By going down the track that you were suggesting earlier that covers most of your concerns.

—I will clarify what I think is happening so we understand what is going on here. We have moved an amendment to try and ensure that both parties get some independent legal advice. That is the first thing we want. The second thing we want is for the court to be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan promote the interests of the child. There are two things to be looked at here.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the first matter, Senator Spindler is now saying that it does not have to be independent legal advice and that it can be independent advice. As I understand it, he is saying that it could be a legal practitioner that offers that advice or it could be a court counsellor. He is suggesting that amendment because he is persuaded by Senator Cooney's argument—do not be so humble Senator Cooney and shake your head—that the cost to legal aid might be so phenomenal that we should not insist that lawyers come in at this stage and that a court counsellor has some experience in these matters, et cetera.

That is the point I want to address. I would be interested in hearing the views of Senator Spindler, the minister and Senator Cooney when I rephrase what you are saying to see whether you still agree with it when it is put the other way. You are basically saying that you are happy to focus on the weaker party, and we all agree that it is in the best interests of the child that it be looked at. We might argue about the point at which that should happen, but we all agree.

I ask you now to focus on the question of both parties coming to make this agreement and there being a weaker party involved. You are happy for the rights, duties and obligations of the weaker party to be registered as a court order without that weaker party having independent legal advice. The consequence of saying yes to that is that you are happy to set up court counsellors as paralegals that can take over advising in custody and access law unless there is going to be a dog fight, or until there is a dog fight, and then the lawyers come and clean it up—and I realise that some people would say that the lawyers made it worse in the beginning.

But the consequence of what you are doing is to say that in custody and access matters people need to get some advice and you frankly do not care if it is from a court counsellor, who might have training in social work or psychology—I am not sure what training they do have—but who, as I understand it, is not required to be a family law practitioner. You are happy for them to have that independent advice from someone on the basis of cost, which I understand. But what I see happening of a morning is a court counsellor with a list of 30 of these things going tick, tick, tick, tick.

If you are happy with that, Senator Spindler, and if that is the way that we can get this amendment, we will agree. But I do want to isolate the fact that you are actually saying that you will allow non-legally trained people to give what is in essence legal advice. You do not make it non-legal advice because you scratch that word out here. That is what they need: advice as to their rights, duties and obligations if they sign an agreement and as to whether they could get a better deal for themselves if they held out further.

You are saying that it is satisfactory for court counsellors to give that advice. You are setting up a sort of paralegal profession for advice on custody and access matters provided the parties in the end agree and a family law practitioner might say that what they really mean is `provided the parties don't know any better'. Once they do know better, because they think they have been done over and could have got a better deal in the beginning, or once the circumstances change, then they will require legal advice.

The question I then put to you is: why do you not allow the court counsellor to advise later when there is some disagreement? Why is the court counsellor's capacity suitable to bring the parties to agreement but not satisfactory when that agreement falls apart? What skills do they not have at the later stage that you somehow think they had at the earlier stage? That is what I would be interested in. I think Senator Cooney might have an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the strength of your argument, Senator Vanstone, is—
—A stich in time saves nine.

—It is. The strength of your argument is in terms of the weaker party. You are saying, and it is absolutely true, that there should be, if possible, an equality between the parties. I do not anticipate what Senator Spindler will say but I understood him to be saying that one way of giving strength to a weaker party would be to give some moral support, which a person who is not a lawyer would be able to do. So a party who comes into strained circumstances, who feels that they do not have the support they might otherwise have, can get that support through a non-lawyer.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone has been talking about being denied legal advice. I do not want to deny anybody legal advice. If somebody wants legal advice, they should be able to get it. What I am talking about, though, is the situation where people are forced to get legal advice, when they are told they cannot come to an agreement unless they have legal advice. It is that compulsion on having legal advice that I thought Senator Abetz addressed very well.

Remember, this is in the circumstances of judicial proceedings. It is not an issue of people who need social help. They may need social help but this is not a position where people go for help in terms of their social position, their psychological position or any other position. This is about a couple who are going before the courts of this land and, as Senator Abetz said, the courts of this land have a particular function—that is, to dispose of disputes. We have to be very careful that we remember that fact.

Weaker parties are an issue that has to be faced not only in the Family Court but also in courts generally. One of the great tragedies is that people plead guilty in magistrates courts day after day without legal advice, which has the consequence of imprisonment. There are problems with weaker parties and stronger parties. They should be balanced in so far as they can be. I think Senator Spindler would be the last to concede that people should not get legal advice if they want it. If they do not want it, and if they are happy to go ahead on this basis, why shouldn't they?

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the question Senator Vanstone raised—and I thank Senator Cooney for his contribution, which I think well illuminated the issue—no, of course I do not think the amendment that is now under consideration, which I suggested, would deprive anybody of legal advice if they felt they needed it. I would draw the committee's attention to the clause, first of all, in line two of subsection (b) which says that each party is able to obtain whatever advice they choose. That is really what my amendment provides—that is, choice.

PARA.TAB: If one of the parties, or both parties individually, to the pending agreement is of the view that they would be more comfortable with a lawyer, they choose a lawyer. They get advice and the signature from the lawyer on that document. If they feel that it is not at that level, that they are happy to obtain the advice of a court counsellor at considerably less cost—possibly no cost—that choice is open to them. It is in that context that I still believe the amendment has merit. I will pursue it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just crystallise my approach to this amendment having regard to previous speakers. In relation to the first part of Senator Spindler's amendment dealing with section 63D(1)(b), I would see the merit in that it affords the opportunity for a person to be advised independently by either a lawyer or a court counsellor.

PARA.TAB: When a person makes an application to a court in relation to custody, before the first turn date there is a requirement that they have to attend a court counsellor in any event. Here, Senator Spindler's amendment is saying that, if that is the case, and if the person wants to have the parenting plan approved by the court, why not have independent advice from a court counsellor? The person still has the choice of course as to whether they have legal advice or not. But that perhaps gives some aspect of choice. It reflects a situation which is in existence to some extent at the present time. Also, I think it could perhaps alleviate any potential burden placed on the legal aid resources, which are currently taxed to the limit.

To that extent, I can see merit in it. I cannot agree with the deletion of section 63D(1)(c) which the minister mentioned. It states that the court must be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child. I think it is important that that be kept in there and that it remain a guide—more than a guide: a beacon, as it were—to the court in how it exercises its powers under this section.

I know that there is an overarching requirement that the best interests of the child should be looked at, but it does not hurt to state the obvious. I know that we will come to this argument when we get to the Greens' amendments in relation to inserting the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child. In any event, this is an area where the court is exercising its powers directly in relation to how children are looked after and how parents who have separated deal with how the children should be looked after. I think the inclusion of paragraph (c) is important.

With respect to the second part of Senator Spindler's amendment dealing with the registration and assessment of a plan and how the rules might cater for it: I am satisfied by the minister's answer that in the registration of a plan the rules of the court could provide for the provision of adequate information by which the court can be satisfied. That is self-regulating. In its own rules the court can state what it feels is necessary to provide for that aspect. By way of preamble it can say what the parties need to put in their plan.

It does not prescribe what sort of agreement they come to. It prescribes as a prerequisite for registration what information the parties bring to the court. That is essential. That is in the registration aspect. I think that that could well provide an adequate safeguard in relation to the court exercising its powers in this regard. On that basis, I would be quite happy with just the word `registered' remaining as is and the aspect of assessment not being included, but on the proviso that these rules will provide for that.

I have every faith that the Family Court of Australia knows only too well what is needed to be provided in these forms and what needs to be provided in these plans for registration to take place. It would be a requirement that the court would not even proceed to registration unless those prerequisites were met. I think that is sufficient.

I understand that Senator Vanstone has indicated that what I have said really reflects the position of the coalition. I rely on Senator Vanstone to put the coalition's point of view in that regard. That is how I see it at this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been having some discussions with the minister and I apologise to Senator Ellison that I did not hear everything he said. What I did hear sounded close to the mark, if not spot on. The minister might like to canvass the option he has just raised. While he is doing that, I will discuss the matter with my colleagues and see if we can get some agreement and get on with this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am looking at, and what I have asked the officers to look at is a plan submitted for registration accompanied by:

SPEECH.PARA: (i) a statement, in relation to each party, to the effect that the party has been provided with independent legal advice as to the meaning and effect of the plan and that is signed by the legal practitioner who provided the advice; or
(ii) a statement to the effect that the plan was developed after consultation with a family and child counsellor or a family and child mediator and that is signed by the parties.

We have those two legs. I have maintained the leg of the mediator, which I know Senator Spindler is not inclined to support at this stage. In his subsection (3) Senator Spindler asks that the court be satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interest of the child. Senator Vanstone has put to me—and I think this is Senator Spindler's view as well—that we are not talking about a full-blown hearing in respect to each one; we are talking about a process where a form 12A can be asserted.

PARA.TAB: I am suggesting that, instead of Senator Spindler's words, we pick up the empowering words in the current legislation which provide for the form 12A process so that we have consistency in that respect as well. We can pick up the court's interaction and intervention by a similar process to the form 12A. It is going to take a little time to work that out and it might be best if we defer this particular aspect until tomorrow morning.

In essence, we pick up Senator Spindler's plank about the court having a role similar to the form 12A approach. We maintain the aspect of legal advice and also, in terms of what we want on this side of the house in order to have a consensual outcome, have provision to allow for a signature by either a child and family counsellor or a child and family mediator. In essence, each one of us would be giving a little bit and taking a little bit and at the end of the day we may finish up with the most comprehensive system.

That is what I am suggesting. I do not know whether Senator Spindler has any response to that formula. I hope it appeals to him and I hope it appeals to the other side as well. Of course, we will have to get it drafted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand, Minister, that you are following this written statement which is headed `proposed government amendment'. That statement omits 63D(1)(c), which states that the court is satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child. As far as I am concerned, that must remain.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did mention that that particular aspect of your proposal is one that we should work on to get similar wording to what is in the act already for the process that applies to property—the form 12A—to ensure that we have consistency. I accept the principle of the court having a form 12A-type process as opposed to a full-blown hearing. I did say that we had to draft it because it is not embodied in my floated proposal at this stage.

—I am a bit uncomfortable with narrowing the process simply to a form 12A process. It seems to me that the formulation that we have—the rules of the court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court—gives the court the possibility to use the form 12A process at one stage, but it does not exclude the court saying, `If the form 12A discloses a problem we want to have it looked at by the court.' In other words, it is a little more flexible. I would be uncomfortable with simply limiting it to that process and setting it in concrete.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask a question. I would like the question to be confirmed by the officers. It is the question that was asked by Senator Ellison. In the formulation that we had before, where the rules of court may deal with how the plan may be registered in a court, it enables the court to make rules as to the manner in which the parenting plan is to be assessed. In other words, does it give the court the possibility to have a rule which says in the first instance that a form—call it 12A—will be assessed by the registrar, and then subsequently the court may say that it needs to come before the court if the registrar reports that the plan is not satisfactory? I would just like to clarify whether the wording `registered in a court' enables the court to make a rule that provides several options.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think, Minister, you might be able to answer this point. Just before we go off on a possible goose chase, you might be able to advise the us, with the assistance of your advisers, whether the amendment as we had it with respect to the best interests of the child is in the equivalent form and would require the court to give the same attention as it does to consent orders. Is that not correct? If that is correct, then the wording we have put does not require a full hearing. That is my understanding, but your advisers might offer a different view. I think that is correct; that it is like a consent order.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know that we have actually picked it up here. We have been talking about form 12A, and apparently 12A is about consent orders. But I cannot at this stage say whether your wording is identical to the wording of the consent order. That is the point you are trying to pick up, isn't it?
—Yes. The point I am trying to make—and Senator Spindler might have a different view—is that I do not think Senator Spindler is actually suggesting that he is requiring a hearing.
—No, of course not. I never said that.

—No, and equally I think we were of the view that the words we had did not require a hearing. The only reason we are accepting your suggestion that you go away and come up with some alternative that is close to 12A is because you think the words we have would require some sort of drawn-out hearing. That is the only basis on which we say, `Why don't you go and have a look at the form 12A?' But the initial position we had and the advice we were offered this morning by some of your advisers is that the combination of words we had made it akin to consent orders—and that, I think, is what we are suggesting.

—Whilst the minister is considering these questions, can I add another one to the list. If we are to delete subsection (c), the requirement that the court is satisfied that the arrangements set out in the plan are likely to promote the best interests of the child, where in the government's proposal is the court required to be guided in that manner in registering this plan? If it is not in this amendment, maybe elsewhere in the bill there is a provision I have missed. Could the minister point me to where the court is still under that direction to consider the best interests of the children?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —First questions first, Senator. I think what we have got at this stage is a common desire in respect to the registration process, whether it is form 12A or consent orders—
—We had it in the beginning.

—I do not know that we had it at the beginning. What we need to clarify is the form of wording we need to give effect here to the same sort of process that applies for consent orders. That is what you are getting at?
—Yes.
—I think that is what people are getting at. I think that is something we can work on between now and when we resume tomorrow morning to get the wording right.

PARA.TAB: You might be right; your wording might be the right wording. But when I discussed it earlier, we all were working on the basis that it wasn't and that the form 12A empowering wording might have been more appropriate. But anyway, I think there is a common goal at least on these two sides, and I think Senator Spindler is in the cart as well on this. So let us try to work out the wording overnight between advisers and see if we can get that.

In respect to your point, Senator Ellison, all I can say is that we are talking about two different concepts here. You are talking about imparting something in the process at the start; we have been resisting that in terms of external legal advice and all that. We what we have in the legislation as an alternative is subsection 63E(5), which states that the court must not enforce the child welfare provisions if it considers that to do so would be contrary to the best interests of a child. That has been our response so far, and we are obviously moving away from that in the discussions we have had in the last half hour or so.

Can I also say that we will finish up with an inconsistency here, because in the legislation, for instance, agreements for maintenance can be lodged without all this prerequisite of advice and whatever. Just recognise that we will be setting up a two-tier system: one in respect of child planning arrangements and another in respect of maintenance arrangements—both of which would encompass maintenance arrangements or could potentially do so. Anyway, that is the path the chamber wants to go down and we will try to facilitate the wording and, hopefully, come up with it by the morning. I do not know if there is much more we can discuss on this, Senator. If there isn't, we can flick it off and move on to the next of Senator Spindler's amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed section 63D on the sheet headed `Proposed government amendment' tells us that a parenting plan may—and I think the important word is `may'—be registered in a court having jurisdiction under this part. Possibly by tomorrow morning your advisers can come back to us and tell us whether that word `may' is mandatory on the court to register.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that gives the court a discretion and that it would not have to register a parenting plan if it were dissatisfied with the information provided to it. In any event, I would have thought the court would have had an inherent jurisdiction to call the parties before it to seek further information.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding both from Senator Neal and also the advisers is that that particular provision refers to the capacity of the parents to register, not the obligation of the court to either register or not. The `may' confers power capacity on parents to do so, if they so choose—remembering, of course, that in a huge range of cases parents choose not to so register.

PARA.TAB: One of the problems I have got with the proposal being put up this afternoon is that, in my mind, it will force a lot of people not to go through this extra process and they will not register the agreements with the court. Senator Spindler does not seem to be concerned about this. He is more concerned about providing jobs for lawyers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just pursue that further. Minister, are you saying that the law is that, even if the parenting plan is of such a shonky nature that the court or registrar is concerned about it, they would still have to sanction it? Surely there is an inherent—and that was the second limit in the question—jurisdiction within the court to make a determination.

PARA.TAB: If I can draw on my own experience, I have filed consent applications to the court where accidentally paragraphs have been left out or the registrar is concerned as to the meaning of a particular paragraph and makes a court appointment for the parties to come along to discuss and clarify certain aspects of it. I would have thought there would be an inherent jurisdiction in the court in any event to check these matters out. But I would just like to have that clarified.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I can do that as well. You have to look at this in the context of the totality of the picture—that is, some people choose to register; some don't. In terms of registration, the process that has been anticipated here is one that would allow for formal lodgment, for instance. It would only be when a person—parent or otherwise—had problems with the actual parenting plan being enforced that there would be capacity for the court to knock a plan out.

PARA.TAB: Proposed section 63(5) states that the court must not enforce the child welfare provision if it considers that to do so would be contrary to the best interests of the child. What Senator Abetz is saying in one sense is right. It is an automatic system of registration. Enforcement is the part where the court has a role to play when people are not happy with the enforcement capacity.

But this is not in isolation. We are talking about other aspects of this act, which have been in force for quite a long time, where the process allows for the automatic registration of forms of arrangements. It is only when they come a cropper that people then go back to court and seek to revisit them or not have some aspects of them enforced. For instance, the maintenance arrangements fall in that category. Remember that, when it comes to children—I would be hazarding a guess—a huge number of arrangements made in respect of them are not lodged in any formal way with the courts. It is a bigger picture. What the committee tried to do in its deliberations in putting this aspect up was to focus on the court having the capacity to intervene when people are not happy with what they may have committed themselves to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the government to consider this overnight: if this parenting plan is to have the effect of a court order and all the sanction that goes with it, there should be some obligation on the court to have regard to the best interests of the children. In section 87 of the Family Law Act, a maintenance or property agreement cannot be approved unless the court deems that the agreement with respect to financial matters is a proper one. There is a requirement that it be a proper one.

PARA.TAB: If we are doing that with property, why can we not do it for children? I do not see that any undue burden would be placed on the court. Senator Abetz has approached this argument, if I may be so bold as to speak about his approach, by saying that there is an inherent jurisdiction in the court to have regard to the best interests of the children.

The minister is now telling us that a parenting plan can be sanctioned by the court and that it does not have to have regard to the best interests of the child. That only arises if there is a punch-up between the parents. If that is the case, I would be greatly concerned about that. I wonder whether overnight the government cannot look at it and see whether we can put in a provision which states that the court have regard to the best interests of the child at all times in the registration of such a parenting plan. That would reflect proposed subsection C, which was originally in Senator Vanstone's proposed amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —You have to work out what you are trying to do here. The first point Senator Ellison raised relates to property. There is a major distinction between dealing with children as opposed to property. Dealing with property can hopefully and normally be concluded in a short time. That is why there is that capacity.

PARA.TAB: When are you dealing with children, take it from me that it is an ongoing process. There is always a need to revisit how one handles the interaction between former spouses in respect of children. That is why there is the capacity for an ongoing trigger to allow the court to revisit in cases where someone feels that the order would not be in the best interests of the child.

Another point is that we are talking about a voluntary system. People do not have to register planning arrangements for children. You have to be careful that, in imposing a process which could be expensive and cumbersome, you may be driving a lot more people out of this net that you would want to be in it. There is some value not just for the people involved in their being able to have their agreements registered. For instance, some schools would like to have evidence of which parent they should contact so that children can be picked up. The planning registration system allows for that to act as a basis for notification.

You are moving to something that I thought a little while ago we had all moved from. I thought we had moved to a system of registration which was not the one you are now suggesting. From what I can see is being suggested, that system would involve an assessment of each individual case. You are talking about 2,500 cases per year—possibly more, but maybe less—if you go ahead with these sorts of amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —If not now, then overnight could the government give consideration to this question: section 43 of the Family Law Act states that the Family Court, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under the act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under the act, shall in the exercise of that jurisdiction have regard to the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare. Can the minister tell me whether section 43C would apply to the registration of parenting plans as proposed in this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is obviously one, if not the, primary objective of the legislation. You then go on through section after section to work out how that is met. In the registration we are talking about, there would be a particular process to meet it.

—I may be confusing the issue. I wonder whether Senator Ellison's question was addressed by the next proposed new section, 63E(2), where it says that variation in the parenting plan in relation to the best interests of the child is possible. I would have thought that that might have covered it rather than having to include it in D as well.
—That is after the event, I think.
—It is after the event. I would have imagined that—
—I am talking about before.
—To prevent it being registered; is that what you are saying?
—That is right.
—You want it in both. I wanted to clarify whether that was covered.

—I accept that the parenting plans would be voluntary. If you want the sanction of the court—and we are talking about it in terms of consent orders, such as property consent orders—you can submit all your papers, but if the court is of the view that it is not necessarily a fair and reasonable one, the registrar or the judge can call the parties in before signing the consent orders in relation to the property settlement to satisfy himself that the parties fully understand the impact of the orders being made.

PARA.TAB: If I am now learning through the minister that the court will not be able to do that if they are concerned about the documentation placed before the court, I would have to revisit my approach to the legislation. I was always under the impression that at the end of the day the court would still have an inherent jurisdiction and that it would not simply be a rubber stamp. In the event that there was something noteworthy on the documentation that would alert it, the court could call the parties in and seek further clarifying information and would not be duty-bound to simply sanction the paper that is placed before it.

Whilst I have some concerns about involving third parties if the parents can agree, I can see the benefit of saying to parents that, prior to their proposed agreement being sanctioned, a third party will look through it not so much from a legal perspective but simply from a practical perspective. Many parties that I have personally tried to assist have come up with arrangements with their former spouse and then, when you ask them about the practical outcomes, realised that it might not be as easy as they originally thought.

There would be some benefit in a third party just bouncing around the practicalities with them so that they fully understood, because as soon as it is registered, if you want to change it you have to go through the court process. So it is better to get it right.

I would like to have thought at the beginning that the court would have had that inherent jurisdictional oversight that if they thought there was something outstanding in the particular parenting plan that warranted further discussion, they would not have to put their rubber stamp on it, they could delay, ask the parties to come before them, discuss it and see whether it was exactly what the parties had considered appropriate or whether there had been an oversight. But if that is not going to occur, then the argument for 63D(1)(b)(i) and (ii) become very strong indeed. However, I would hope that there would have been that discretion within the court and I had assumed that there would be that discretion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a final comment on the Minister's suggestion that what is proposed is cumbersome and expensive and, in particular, his comment that I want to create work for legal practitioners.
—Very worthy.

—On the contrary. Senator Abetz, I do not agree that that would be a worthy cause in itself. On the contrary, I have offered the minister the option of the individual parties, at their choice, obtaining advice either from a legal practitioner or from a court counsellor. In these circumstances and in the interests of arriving at a satisfactory conclusion in this fairly complex and difficult area, with respect, I would appreciate it if the Minister did not indulge in cheap shots.
