SPEECH.PARA: This report attempts to paint a rather positive picture of the state of the Department of Social Security. But, unfortunately for them, it is a picture with a large number of cracks. On a closer inspection of the report—it is a rather large report that we only received today along with about 70 other reports, as my colleague said—we find a lot of waste, and goals or aims which have not been met.

PARA.TAB: This annual report comes hot on the heels of the Auditor-General's efficiency audit that was tabled last Tuesday, which exposed massive inefficiency and the potential to save millions upon millions of dollars. In fact, it said that in the range of $30 million to $80 million could be saved just through efficiency improvements within regional offices—the offices out there in the local communities. The audit report also revealed that if those efficiencies were taken on board and achieved, there would also be efficiencies in client services. So not only would there be savings in money but also the clients would not have to stand in queues, go from one queue to the other or fill out innumerable forms. There are a number of ways in which those savings could be made, and I talked about those when the Auditor-General's report was released.

I turn to the report of the Department of Social Security where it refers to performance standards for 1994-95. We see, for example, that the national standard for teleservice centres is one minute from initial response to be referred to an action officer. In 1994-95, a target was set that 85 per cent of cases would at least get to an action officer in one minute. In 1993-94, the actual achievement was 57 per cent; this year, it was 38 per cent—they have gone down. Anybody who has tried to ring the Department of Social Security would know that you are just put on hold. The other day when I tried to ring up to make an inquiry—they did not know I was a senator—I was told, `You're in a queue and there's an 18-minute wait at least with 35 calls ahead of you.' So much for the one-minute response time! We have seen that in 1994-95 the achievement rate with the standard has gone down on the year before.

The standard of reply time for ministerial correspondence has also gone down. The 1994-95 target for answering parliamentary questions was 100 of them. In 1993-94 it achieved 83 and this year it was 70. The target for meeting the standard for financial recovery prosecutions was 70. In 1993-94 it achieved 58 and this year it was 47. This is a department that received a two per cent pay increase in anticipation of productivity gains. What were they going to do? They were going to be more efficient and they were going to have fewer sick leave days.

I tried to find out about absenteeism in the report. If I go to the index at the back, do I find absenteeism? No, I do not find anything about absenteeism. When I search through I find absenteeism on page 310. We were told in estimates that absenteeism was on average something like 10 days a year before that productivity payment of two per cent. The departmental representatives said, `We'll get back to eight per cent, Senator. That'll give us a $6 million saving. The productivity payment cost $12 million. So we'll get half of it from getting our absenteeism back by two days.'

But what did Social Security do? It went up to something like 12 days on average. For that productivity payment we got two more days of sick leave on average. We see in the report that the department says it is concerned about the increasing levels of absenteeism. It looks as though the department really has not got very far with absenteeism either.

It is not a very happy report. I suppose the only area where I have seen some improvement is with the number of overpayments which were waived `due to administrative error and were in good faith'. Last year, the overpayments waived were $10.1 million and this year, $5.4 million—we have still had $15 million worth of errors in two years. The only place where I can see any gain in Social Security is in overpayments. The people handling that area ought to have credit where credit is due, but the rest of it leaves a lot to be desired. It says that, after 13 years, this Labor government has yet to bring in efficiencies that would make the Department of Social Security an efficient organisation.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw attention to the question of consultants employed by departments. In this case, there has been a considerable decrease in the consultant numbers and costs compared with the Defence annual report for the previous year. The total paid for consultants in the latest financial year to 30 June 1995 was $12.5 million. Unfortunately, the report does not detail the comparable figure for the previous year, but it does state:
The significant decrease in the consultant numbers and costs compared to the Defence Annual Report 1993-94 is due to the following:

. the definitions for Consultants and Professional Service Providers (Contractors), were more clearly defined during the FY 1994-95 and approved by the Attorney-General's Department. This redefinition was to better reflect the reporting requirements and remove the confusion that previously existed in separating contractors and consultants.

I must say in passing that it seems to me extraordinary that there would be no strict comparison using the same criteria with the previous year so that the Senate can take a view of whether there has been either a genuine increase or a genuine decrease. I think it is grossly improper of the department to fail to do so. The next matter in justification for the significant decrease is as follows:
. the Defence Financial Management Information System, which records all Defence payments—
has simply lumped together, in terms of numbers, the total contract value of consultants because—
. . . In previous annual reports, the total contract number value was reported, thus showing possible amounts payable over future years.

That is, rather than individual years. As I say, it would be nice if we had a strict comparison. This leads me to the general question as to why on earth there is no list of consultants. This report says:
The total number of consultants engaged has been reported, as opposed to individual consultancies reported in previous years . . .

This appears to follow the decision by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet that there be changes made in the way organisations report various matters in their annual reports. One of these is to take consultancy services out of the annual report and make it material available on request.

PARA.TAB: The committee of which I am a member—the Senate Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Legislation Committee—expressed concern about this tactic. It is a tactic which clearly is aimed at not having these matters so up front as they have been in the past. Sure, they are available on request, but it seems to me that this is information that should be very publicly available either in the annual report or in an attachment to the annual report. In the estimates report of our committee last year—when this matter came up before us—we said:

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the information that may be held separately instead of included in annual reports consists of basic orientating and cross referencing information, which would add only a few pages to most annual reports such as relevant legislation and information on statutory authorities, non-statutory bodies and government companies in the portfolio. The committee considers that to omit this information from annual reports is a retrograde step. For example, the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration has several times commented on the difficulty of knowing what government controlled companies exist. The new rule in practice is likely to make it harder.

There is no doubt about that. This new rule is offensive. There is a failure to provide details of consultancy services in annual reports. The departments are taking this prime ministerial departmental edict that they need not report as an instruction not to report. That is an improper interpretation.

PARA.TAB: I ask the departments to include this vital information in their reports in future or the Senate might be asked to take action to require departments to provide material, if not in their annual reports at least in attachments to their annual reports when they are tabled in the Senate. Naturally, I will be making that recommendation through our party room, in the hope that the Procedure Committee will require departments to come clean. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make some comments in relation to this report. In particular, I wish to comment on what the report says about the east coast tuna and billfish fishery on pages 29 to 32. I am glad that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) is in the chamber because these are matters on which he should have some knowledge.

PARA.TAB: I wish to advise him that what is contained in the report is not accurate and is, I believe, deliberately misleading. It is not the minister's fault that it is misleading. I believe that the account in relation to the east coast tuna and billfish fishery which is contained in this report has been written in such a way as to gloss over the fact that AFMA has refused to act on one of the recommendations of the East Coast Tuna Management Advisory Committee.

At page 31, the report says very clearly that the objective was to develop and implement a management plan for the east coast tuna and billfish fishery under the Fisheries Management Act 1991. It then goes on to say:

A number of major management issues were unresolved in the ECT&BF and this led to a delay in the finalisation of a draft Management Plan for the fishery. Part of the difficulty in finalising future management arrangements was the sudden growth in the pelagic longline sector, in terms of new vessels entering the fishery through activation of latent effort and an expansion of commercial effort in the Coral Sea fishery.

SPEECH.PARA: It then says, and this is important:

PARA.TAB: ECTUNAMAC addressed these issues through extensive public consultation and lengthy deliberations. June 1995 marked the finalisation of these issues and the recommencement of the drafting of a Management Plan for the fishery. A revised date of June 1996 has been set for the introduction of the Management Plan.

SPEECH.PARA: This is deliberately misleading, because ECTUNAMAC made a number of recommendations to AFMA in June of this year. I think the press release came out on about 21 June.

PARA.TAB: One of those recommendations related to the taking of billfish by commercial tuna operators. That recommendation was very clear. The recommendation was that commercial tuna operators should be prohibited from taking billfish anywhere, either inside any of the management zones or outside any of the management zones—for example, inside or outside area E—if they were operating as commercial tuna fishermen; the reason being that we have seen a spate of cases where people have come into port with marlin in the boat and have said, `We caught the marlin outside area E.'

AFMA has very limited resources to enforce the regulations. There is nobody on the boats. It would be ridiculous to expect somebody to be on the boats all the time, but there are no spot checks on operators and what they do in the areas. Anybody could make up this story and get away with it.

The recommendation went to AFMA, although I understand the committee was divided on the matter along the lines of self-interest. AFMA has done absolutely nothing about it but defer it and defer it. It has accepted the other recommendations, but not this one.

I want to know how this report can say that June 1995 marked the finalisation of these issues. The issues have not been finalised. AFMA has not accepted the recommendation. This is, quite plainly put, a lot of hogwash. If we are going to allow AFMA to put this sort of nonsense in a report when they know it is not the case, I believe the whole system falls down.

I put AFMA on notice that I intend to follow up the matter in much more detail very shortly. I hope Senator Bob Collins will take note of my concerns. He is a man of his word. If he says he is going to look at it, I am sure he will take steps to see that AFMA follows this up and that what is in here is correct or a correction is made and the parliament is informed accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to make some remarks about what is becoming an unseemly debate between Sydney, on the east coast of this great nation, and Perth, on the other side of this great nation, over where the real little Aussie battler, the good ship Australia II, should rest. Australia II, having scored what—in the opinion of this senator—was one of the greatest sporting victories in the history of the world, not just to mention Australia, clearly is not being allowed to rest in peace.

PARA.TAB: She has, of course, been found a home in the National Maritime Museum in Sydney—a most appropriate place for the old Australia II—and certainly a lot of money has been put into creating that home for her. That home having been found for Australia II, we find that in the Creative Nation statement—which was launched by the minister, Michael Lee, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) earlier this year—and without any consultation with the board of the National Maritime Museum, the decision was made to relocate Australia II to Fremantle.

Mr President, you and I are both proud Western Australians. Some might certainly call me parochial, and I think even you might be called that as well. I think we would have to say that Fremantle would make a great home for Australia II. But tonight I want to propose an alternative answer to the—

TALK.START.PARA: —Alice Springs!

—No, Senator Collins, not Alice Springs. You can have your Todd River Regatta, but that does not match sailing off Fremantle. I am going to float tonight—excuse the pun—a proposal that would ensure that Australia II ends up exactly where her designer, Ben Lexcen, and the builder of that yacht, Steve Ward, another proud Western Australian, originally intended that yacht to be—that is, in the water.
—You are going to float that idea, are you?

—I have. I have used that pun already, Senator Baume. You missed it. It does not get better, so I will leave it at that. The proposal—and it is only a broad proposal at this stage, and it is something that I have discussed privately with Kay Cottee, who is actively advocating that Australia II stay in Sydney—is that, under the auspices of the National Maritime Museum, we create an Australia II foundation quite similar in structure to the Endeavour Foundation, which is now operating the Endeavour replica that is moving around the ports of Australia and attracting very large crowds wherever she goes.

PARA.TAB: That foundation would be charged with the responsibility of putting Australia II back in the water and supporting Australia II with an appropriate jinker or trailer—to use a term which most people would understand—or an appropriate piece of prime mover type equipment, to move Australia II from port to port, because she is certainly not designed to sail at great lengths at sea. She was unlike the old America's Cup yachts. The modern 12-metre yachts are designed to go out and sail for short periods in offshore courses, but they are certainly not designed for overnight expeditions.

That equipment would be provided so that Australia II could be moved from port to port—not only capital city ports but also the many great regional ports we have around Australia—and, indeed, be recommissioned so that she could sail. I am proposing that the federal government would allocate to the Australia II foundation that I am proposing an amount of money equal to that which would have been involved under the Creative Nation proposal to meet the expenses of shifting Australia II across to Fremantle.

The important aspect of the proposal I put here tonight is that any sailing boat that is locked up in a museum is certainly not going to provide the inspiration or the appreciation of Australia's maritime or sporting history that a yacht that is in active service will provide. I was reminded in a conversation with a good friend of mine from Sydney just a few minutes ago that at Newport at the bicentenary of the New York Yacht Club where they held a regatta in the middle of last year, virtually all the great United States entrants in the America's Cup for the past many decades were out there racing each other: the Courageouses, the Stars and Stripes—all the boats going back some decades, but still in active service.

It is not to say that Australia II is in the same category with those; she is a remarkable yacht which achieved a remarkable sporting feat. For Australia, she is the only yacht that has been able to win the America's Cup in the United States. She broke the longest running hold on an international sporting trophy in the history of mankind. So Australia II is special. But I believe the great benefit of having Australia II move around from port to port is that so many more people will be able to appreciate the beauty and history of the boat and, very importantly, will gain the inspiration that Australia II can provide.

Even though parochial Western Australians such as me like to claim the America's Cup win as a Western Australia victory, it is simply not accurate. There were many great Western Australians who contributed to the victory. If it was not for the vision of Alan Bond and his dedication to the pursuit of the holy grail of yachting over so many decades of his life, it would not have been possible. If it had not been for the dedication of other Western Australians such as the boat builder, Steve Ward; John Longley or Chink as he is known to his sailing mates and who was involved in all of the challenges; Skippy Lissiman; Ken Judge and Scotty McAllister—and I have probably forgotten some of my Western Australian sailing friends—we would not have won the cup off Newport on that famous and memorable morning in 1983.

Of course, there were contributions made by great Australians from other parts of the country. We would not have won the cup if it had not been for the Victorian John Bertrand who was the exceptional skipper of that boat. We would not have won without the incredible commitment to the pursuit of that trophy by Sir James Hardy—from Senator Bolkus's state—over all his life. There were Sydneysiders such as Ben Lexcen—I have already mentioned him—a brilliant and great Australian, Hugh Treharne, the tactician and sail maker and another great Australian; and Phil Smidmore. I have probably forgotten lots, but I make the point that it was an Australian effort.

I well remember those ads that Westpac ran with the great silver spanner that it designed to unbolt the cup. It would not have been possible without the national sponsorship of organisations such as Westpac. It was a national effort and I believe that rather than having a fight between Sydney and Perth about where Australia II should rest, we should look very closely at the idea of establishing this foundation so that Australia II can become a live exhibit, rather than gathering dust.

There are a number of practical difficulties with the proposal, but none that cannot be overcome with the same sort of dedication that was required to win the America's Cup in the first place. Clearly, it will require maintenance and a good crew of people to ensure that the yacht is preserved for future generations.

I envisage that Australia II could be used for sail training purposes and to inspire younger Australians to increase sports participation. Also, programs could be developed to ensure that disadvantaged young Australians could have access to Australia II and share the inspiration that win gave us back in 1983. There are many young Australians who will not remember those bleary nights and early mornings ten years ago when we watched the images of Australia II crossing the finish line in the fog to win that great trophy.

The other great advantage—and I will conclude on this because my time in the debate is about to expire—is that Australia II being mobile could be taken to strategic points in Australia where other great events may be on and where Australia II could add to Australia's international reputation. One of the most significant of those will clearly be the Olympics in the year 2000 in Sydney. I think it is only sensible that she be there for that time. I commend this idea to the Senate and hope that the National Maritime Museum, all political parties, the federal government, the governments of Western Australia and New South Wales, and the private sector will give this idea very strong consideration. I think it could be good for our nation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen C.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to continue some remarks that I commenced on an earlier occasion regarding the Western Australian Court government's first wave industrial relations legislation. In particular, I want to examine the principles that underline it and the experience of workers in my state under those policies. I do this because of the endorsement expressed by Mr Howard, the coalition leader, in the parliament recently of those principles, and the expectation that federal Liberal policy will mirror the Western Australian example.

PARA.TAB: Tonight, I would like to give an example of an experience in a private child-care centre in Western Australia, which I will refer to as example F. Workers were previously employed under the Children's Services (Private) Award 1990, but have been subject to offers of workplace agreements throughout this year. They have been spreading throughout private child-care centres—mainly to untrained workers because, in fact, trained workers are in high demand and enjoy considerable bargaining powers as a result. These workplace agreements have been used to target young, untrained women who are readily available in the current employment market.

While the workplace agreements offered reflect different wage rates, many see the offer as a move to free up workers' terms and conditions as private centres look to expand their opening hours to include Saturdays and Sundays, and evenings. One of the major problems in this industry is that under the legislation employers are allowed to employ persons as casuals for periods of 10, 15, or 20 years. There is no limit on the time a person can be employed as a casual.

As a result of that, employees are not entitled to sick leave, annual leave or any of the other normal conditions of employment that we have come to expect as part of the normal minimum entitlements of workers in Australia. In addition, the agreements seek to downgrade other conditions or eliminate them in the workplace agreement as compared with the award. These are having a major impact on the income that workers can earn under this arrangement.

The ordinary hours of work under the award are 38 hours per week between 7 a.m. and 6 p.m. Shifts are up to a maximum of eight hours. Work in excess of those hours is paid as overtime. Under the workplace agreement, ordinary hours are increased to 40 hours per week, to be worked at any time, Monday to Friday inclusive. There is no time limit on the length of the shift. Under the award, overtime rates are paid where more than eight hours are worked in a day, or where more than an average of 38 hours are worked in a week. Rates start at time and a half for the first two hours followed by double time. The workplace agreement provides for time off in lieu where more than 40 hours are worked in a week, but there is no overtime rate or, in fact, any wage rate for overtime hours. So, if you work more hours, there is no overtime provision at all. The only option under this agreement is that you may get time off in lieu.

I will give an example of a woman, say, called Paula who is an untrained child-care worker. She signed a workplace agreement because that is what was offered at her workplace. It seemed that it was not going to make too much difference because the hourly rates were fairly similar. However, two weeks later her shifts were changed from eight hours from Monday to Friday to 10 hours on any four days of the week, Monday to Friday. The award provided that for working these shifts she would have received $432.60 per week, including the overtime rate. Under the workplace agreement, Paula earned only $391.50, representing nearly a 10 per cent loss in her income as a result of her signing the workplace agreement.

In terms of public holidays, penalty rates are double time and half under the award, but public holidays are not included in the workplace agreement. The workplace agreement is for a period of five years with annual wage reviews, but the basis of the review is not detailed. The 17 1/2 per cent loading on annual leave—which is contained in the award—is not contained in the workplace agreement, which pays annual leave only at the ordinary rate.

In terms of sick leave, while both the award and the agreement provide for 10 days paid sick leave per year, leave not taken accumulates under the award, but it is forfeited each year under the workplace agreement. Generally, the award does not require medical certificates for an absence of two days or less. Medical certificates must be provided under the workplace agreement for any absence, including part of a day. One of the largest sections in the workplace agreement relates to the conditions that apply to unpaid annual leave. What it recognises is that a large majority or a large number of these workers will be classified as casuals and will not be entitled to annual leave, no matter how long they work for one employer. The document goes to great lengths to set out the conditions under which people will be allowed access to the only leave they will be able to get, which is unpaid annual leave. That is another example of what is occurring to workers in Western Australia.

As I said, these workers are mainly young women without any particular training. They are at the mercy of an employer saying, `You either sign this workplace agreement and accept these conditions or there is no job here for you.' There is no choice for them to go onto an award. In fact, as I highlighted earlier, the Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Western Australia is sending out to employers wage rates which contain information of how to pay under the award. But in a big box at the top of the wages schedule, it says, `You can replace this award with a workplace agreement.' Therefore they are making sure that employers understand that they do not have to pay the award in Western Australia; they do not have to be bound by these minimum wage rates; they can just replace them with workplace agreements. The schedule, of course, makes no mention of minimum employment conditions; it just advises them that if they do not like the award they can get out of it.

In the short time available to me, I want to address some of the Liberal Party paranoia about the ALP television advertisement, launched in Western Australia recently, about the Liberals' policy on industrial relations. The coalition has continued to assert that it is Labor's lies, but I have here the transcript of what the ad actually says. It makes a number of assertions, but there are two major ones. Firstly, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Court Liberal government has set the minimum weekly wage at $317.10. A family can't live on that!

Quite frankly, I do not think anyone would dispute that. The Western Australian minister had a minimum wage recommended to him by the Industrial Relations Commission and by an independent expert. He cut the recommended rate—reduced it and set it at $317.10, despite the recommendation from his own expert and from the independent umpire of the Industrial Relations Commission. So I do not see why people would be upset by that assertion. The second major assertion is:
Penalty rates. Sick leave. Unfair dismissal protection. And Superannuation . . . could all go—with no compensation.
These are under a heading `Under a John Howard Liberal Government'.

PARA.TAB: I am happy to debate that assertion in this chamber at any time with those opposite. The exhibits that I table today of workplace agreements that are actually in force in Western Australia prove that penalty rates, sick leave and any entitlements to overtime and shift penalties have all been eroded under the Western Australian Liberal government's industrial relations system. I have set out in chapter and verse where those workers have had those entitlements to penalty rates, annual leave and sick leave removed from them. They have been made to sign workplace agreements; they have been told to sign or resign or told, `Sign or you don't get the job.' They no longer have paid annual leave, penalty rates or paid sick leave. That is a fact.

Despite the secrecy surrounding the Court Liberal government's workplace agreements—it is very hard to get copies of these things because they have very strict secrecy provisions—it is on the record in this parliament of what has occurred to workers in Western Australia. For the Liberal Party to take genuine offence at the ad, they have to establish that it is not true. Clearly, it is true: registered workplace agreements take away workers' penalty rates and sick leave and reduce their unfair dismissal protection. In terms of superannuation, I am not sure what the Liberal Party is saying. But certainly the second wave industrial legislation introduced into the state parliament attacks the worker's right to choose. It gives the employer a veto over the choice of superannuation funds by employees, particularly over any collective choice that they currently enjoy.
The last assertion in the ALP advertisement is:

SPEECH.PARA: Working people simply can't afford to go backwards with the Liberals.

Quite frankly, that is established by the record. John Howard has endorsed the WA principles and the WA industrial relations approach. It has been proven that people are suffering, that their incomes are being reduced and that the things that we took for granted in this country, such as paid sick leave and paid annual leave, are not being granted to workers, some of whom have worked five or 10 years with the same employer. They have lost those rights under the Liberals' IR policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about the Affirmative Action Agency annual report for 1995 which was tabled in the parliament yesterday. In that report it was claimed by the Affirmative Action Agency that the RSPCA, of which I am the patron, had not complied with section 19 of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act because it did not provide adequate information in its progress report. In fact, the RSPCA did provide the information in consultation with an adviser, R.B. Bailey of Employee Relations Pty Ltd, who advised that the information provided would be adequate. But the Affirmative Action Agency appeared not to be happy with that.

PARA.TAB: Section 3(4) of the act states that employees are not required to take any action which is incompatible with the principle that employment matters should be dealt with on merit. I think everyone would agree that in this case—I will elaborate on it in a minute—people have been dealt with on merit within the RSPCA and that there are more affirmative action programs going there than just about anywhere else. The RSPCA has consulted with the Affirmative Action Agency all through this process and it can only be assumed that even the best results are not good enough for the agency.

The Affirmative Action Agency was established in the main to `improve career opportunities for women in business'. On any scenario the RSPCA provides more career opportunities than any business or charity. Why is the RSPCA being singled out when, clearly, it is a good affirmative action organisation? Far from being praised for its efforts, it is being labelled as a non-complying organisation.

The RSPCA employs some 190 people, of whom 120 are female. The organisation has eight shelters and clinics around New South Wales, all of which are headed and managed by women. The RSPCA employs more women at all levels of management than does anyone else. For example, it has a board of nine people of whom five are women. The chair of the board is a woman. By the way, the executive director of the RSPCA is a male but the deputy director is a female.
The RSPCA has been branded by the Richard Morecroft program as `keeping women in the "pink ghetto"'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Affirmative Action Agency have named organisations, including the RSPCA and NBN Newcastle . . .
These extracts have come from Media Monitors. Another item is from an Adelaide radio station which stated:
More than 100 Australian companies have been publicly exposed for not complying with affirmative action programmes. Among the companies named were Franklins, RSPCA, . . .
The RSPCA has been mentioned in other articles. For example, an item on the AAP wire service states:
But AAA director Catherine Harris warned that too many women were still stuck in the "pink ghetto" of low paid, unskilled and unappreciated employment.

I take the agency to task over that as far as the RSPCA is concerned. There are more women than men working in the organisation. There are more women than men in the top levels of management of that organisation. I think the agency has got it wrong in some ways.

PARA.TAB: This has an effect on charity organisations like the RSPCA. A letter signed by Catherine Harris, the Director of the Affirmative Action Agency, arrived yesterday at the same time as this report was being tabled. The third paragraph of that letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth Government has a policy of contract compliance. The effect of this policy is that Commonwealth Government departments and agencies will not purchase goods or services from your organisation and your organisation is also ineligible to apply for specified forms of industry assistance.
This organisation is being discriminated against because of a report that I believe has been wrongly put together. It has been assumed that the RSPCA will not be eligible for industry assistance.

PARA.TAB: This has put the RSPCA in a very difficult position. This organisation relies on donations. It looks after the welfare of animals in New South Wales. One of the other patrons besides myself is the Premier of New South Wales. There are three patrons of that organisation. I believe the RSPCA has been defamed by this report.

There a lot of nice people in the community who like to give donations to the RSPCA—there are lots of women who like to give donations—and if this inference has been placed on it by the Affirmative Action Agency then those donations may not come in as freely as they did in the past. I believe the only way the damage from this defamatory attack can be eliminated is for the Affirmative Action Agency to publicly apologise to Charles Wright, the Executive Director of the RSPCA in New South Wales.

The report should be put together using the facts. The facts are that the RSPCA employs 190 people of which 120 are female and 70 are males. The chairman of the board is a female. The managers of all the clinics around New South Wales are females. I believe they have complied with the thrust of the affirmative action legislation. I do not think the RSPCA should have been singled out the way it was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to firstly express some concerns about what I read in the paper yesterday concerning some clergy signing a letter to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) relating to activities of old-growth logging or logging of native forests. I am somewhat amazed at the 18 people who signed this particular letter. I am very pleased to see that the churches essentially have distanced themselves from that position.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me in this debate on the forest industry and the use of native forests, be they old-growth or any age, is the fact that a particular group of conservatives or green groups have chosen to try and employ and maybe cajole certain people within the church to lend support to their argument. I think that that is a very sad and sorry state of affairs.

I think that this is a very important debate. To go to that end to try and gain assistance for your cause is unfair on many members of the public in this country. It is a very difficult issue to understand and one that needs a lot of explaining. I do not think they have been fair on the people that they have sought to get involved in this process.

It is very pleasing to see that some church leaders have come out and distanced themselves from this position. I think Archbishop Eric D'Arcy from Tasmania made a very pertinent point when he said that there is a serious onus of proof on anyone who wants to put an end to another person's employment. Quite frankly, I think that the people who signed the letters that went to the two leaders missed the point with regard to the role of Christianity which they seek to espouse.

Jesus Christ was a carpenter. I am sure at that time in history that the wood that Jesus Christ used to work with came from native forests and probably old trees. I am not quite sure whether they are taking a hypocritical stance or whether they have been misled into lending support to a campaign that is currently in the public fora. I think it is appropriate to read parts of the letter into the record. It says:
It is clear to us that Australia's old-growth forests are both ecologically precious and of great natural beauty . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That defies the principle I spoke about before because it was in the early days that we used much more than we use today in terms of a per capita operation. They go on to say:

PARA.TAB: They are also home to rare and endangered species. As such, they mirror the creativity of God.

SPEECH.PARA: Again I remind them of the fact that many human beings in the early days relied very heavily on the use of timber for their homes. I do not think it is a sin to provide your family and yourself with a home whether it be built from timber or some other material. It goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Therefore, to continue to log them for whatever purpose must be considered ethically and even morally wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise with those people—and not the churches generally because they have generally distanced themselves from this particular letter and the claims in it—that if it is morally wrong, when they go to the church in which they conduct their sermons they should have a look around them and study the furniture and fittings within the church. They are very beautiful and in a majority of cases would have been made from timber—timber that has come from old-growth or native forests.

PARA.TAB: The signatories to the letter also said that they were speaking as individuals and were not giving an official view of the church. That is good because it would be very concerning if it was an official position of a church, as Archbishop D'Arcy said, to take the position of putting an end to a person's employment.

As I said, it is a sad state of affairs that at least some members or clergy of the church have become entwined in this national debate with regard to what we do in terms of the preservation of our forests on the one hand and the utilisation of them on the other. I do not think those people would have necessarily signed the letter had they been fully versed and fully aware of all the circumstances and all the parts of the debate.

It must be recognised by all of Australia that this government has embarked upon a process that will put in place the world's most comprehensive representative and reserved stands of forests vis-a-vis European settlement in this country. It will set a world standard of 15 per cent of forests with regard to after European settlement.

Also, we are endeavouring to deliver to the people working and the companies operating in the forest industry an industry that is both sustainable and can actually be developed into a bigger and better industry. We need to do that because we know that there is an ever increasing demand for timber product and, I stress, an ever decreasing capacity to meet that demand.

Australia is essentially just a small supplier in the world timber market yet we have the capacity to far better utilise the forests that grow in this country whether they be native forests or, indeed, whether they be plantation forests. We have a capacity to increase markedly the plantation forests and ultimately see them developed as a replacement for native forest harvesting.

Mind you, we have not been without our mistakes. We have seen in many areas many forest types wiped out of existence. That is very unfortunate and very sad but we are making the right moves, albeit many people will disagree with that. This country is a democracy. I accept the right even of the 18 clergy who signed the letter to express a view. But I think it is unfortunate that they have chosen to express the view they have in the way they have.

The government, as senators will know, is considering the issue of woodchip licences. The people of Australia generally do not like to export woodchips because of the perception that has been created by a very successful public campaign. Nevertheless, it is an integral part of an overall forest operation that ensures that we can utilise to the nth degree the wood we take from the forest. We have the capacity to much improve the way in which we utilise the wood we take from our forests and also much increase the value that is placed upon those trees that we take from the forests.

When the government finally makes its decision with regard to how we issue the new woodchip licences for 1996, it is imperative that that fact is fully taken account of and we issue those licences in a way that will maximise the social and economic benefit not only to this country but also to each state as each state has different forest industry applications. I would just like to say in closing that I hope the people who signed the letter will reconsider their position in light of the concern that has been expressed by the churches themselves and by other leaders within the church.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I want to say that I am very concerned about the fact that the new reporting requirements imposed by the Department of Finance on various Commonwealth departments, such as the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, mean that the list of Australian organisations and people receiving grants is no longer published. For example, the sports rorts would not be publicly presented to this parliament under the new rules that apply.

PARA.TAB: I have already mentioned consultancy services being hidden under the new rules but now we have the situation where, for example, the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories has a page in its annual report headed `Material available on request' and underneath is the word `grants'. They have decided not to print, for example, the $1,700,000 provided to 61 national state and regional conservation organisations this year. All we get is the fact that these grants are being made. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Details are available from the Department on request.

Quite frankly, one should not have to ask and wait to find out from the department what these sorts of grants are. As a general reporting principle it is grossly inadequate simply to say what the grants are for this year because one wants to see the comparison with the previous year. In this annual report that comparison is not given. For example, the department states:
Details of consultants engaged . . . are available from the Department on request. The total number of consultancies engaged was 349 at a total cost of $8 609 628.
There is no comparison and, as I said, no list of who they were. This is of particular importance because I noticed last Sunday's Sun-Herald stated in an article:

New reporting rules are helping Canberra bureaucrats hide the number of consultants hired—despite a report showing they cost a staggering $342 million last year with their numbers rising by almost 500 per cent in the past decade.

There is no doubt this is the year of the consultant. It has also been the decade of grants, particularly grants to people who are `friendly' to the Labor Party. We have seen continual grants which effectively bind votes, and they are not to be revealed in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What development cooperation commitments has the Australian Government entered into with other countries for each budgetary year from the 1996-97 financial year up to and including the 2000-2001 financial year.
(2) Can the forward commitments be provided by country, value, project and the nature of the agreement through which the assistance was pledged.

(3) What contractual arrangements has the Australian Government entered into under the Development Import Finance Facility for each year of the budgetary years from 1996-97 financial year until the 2000-2001 financial year.

(4) Can the total amount contracted for each budgetary year, including a breakdown of the annual contracts by reference to contracting party, project under consideration and value of the project, be provided.
(5) What percentage of projected overall development cooperation funds has been committed already for each of the budgetary years from the 1996-97 financial year until the 2000-2001 financial year.

(6) What percentage of projected overall expenditure on the Development Import Facility has already been committed by contractual agreements for each of the budgetary years from the 1996-97 financial year through to the 2000-2001 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's questions:

PARA.TAB: It is only possible to provide an interim reply at this time. The level of detail that Senator Minchin has sought through these questions regarding the development cooperation program requires a significant amount of material to be retrieved and collated in AusAID. A full reply is expected to be available by 20 November 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: How much did the department spend on domestic travel in the 1985-86, 1986-87, 1987-88, 1988-89, 1992-93 and 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The information you have sought prior to 1988-89 is not available as departmental expenditure records have been destroyed in accordance with the Archives Act 1983.

Since the creation of the Department of Transport and Communications in July 1987 there have been a number of organisational changes, which would make a comparison between financial years of limited value. These include the establishment of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority on 1 January 1991 and the Spectrum Management Agency on 1 July 1992, and the separation of the Communications functions from Transport in December 1993.
The department spent the following amounts on domestic air travel:
1988-89—Department of Transport and Communications—$2,862,475.62 (Functions—Aviation, Broadcasting, Communications, Land, Maritime and Corporate)
1992-93—Department of Transport and Communications—$2,493,057 (Functions—Aviation, Broadcasting, Communications, Land, Maritime and Corporate)
1994-95—Department of Transport—$1,225,540 (Functions—Aviation, Land, Maritime and Corporate)
